Meaning Mnemonic: When something is <kanji>all</kanji> <kanji>perfect</kanji> it is <vocabulary>complete</vocabulary>. Not only that, but it's <vocabulary>perfect</vocabulary> (because it's ALL perfect, not just partially so).
Reading Mnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.
Context 1-EN: Tofugu is approaching perfection little by little every day.
Context 1-JP: <jp>トーフグは日々少しずつ完全のいきに近づいている。</jp>
Context 2-EN: Unfortunately, Koichi has a perfect alibi.
Context 2-JP: <jp>残念ながら、コウイチには完全なアリバイがあります。</jp>
Context 3-EN: Oh jeez! Now you’ve completely distracted me. What was it that you wanted to talk about... office dog, was it?
Context 3-JP: <jp>ああ、もう！お前のせいで完全に気が散っちゃったじゃないか！話したいことって何なんだよ。オフィスで飼う犬だっけか？</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: When something is <kanji>close</kanji> <kanji>close</kanji> (the <jp>々</jp> character repeats the kanji that was before it) it will happen <vocabulary>before long</vocabulary>.
Reading Mnemonic: The reading is the kun'yomi reading twice; that's the one you learn with the vocab word <jp>近い</jp> from the previous level. The second <jp>近</jp> gets converted to <jp>ぢか</jp>, though, so take note of that.
Context 1-EN: I think there will be an announcement about it soon.
Context 1-JP: <jp>それについては、近々はっぴょうがあると思いますよ。</jp>
Context 2-EN: We're supposed to get snow soon, so if we get a lot, I will make a snow igloo.
Context 2-JP: <jp>近々雪がふるはずなので、たくさんつもったらかまくらを作ります。</jp>
Context 3-EN: You’ll get cancer before long if you keep smoking.
Context 3-JP: <jp>もしタバコを吸い続けるなら、あなたは近々癌を発症するでしょう。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: Remember how <jp>揚げる</jp> can mean "to deep fry?" Something that was deep fried and then put in front of you is <vocabulary>deep fried</vocabulary>.
Reading Mnemonic: The reading is <jp>揚げる</jp> and <jp>出す</jp>'s reading.
Context 1-EN: Here is a plate of delicious deep fried tofu I just made.
Context 1-JP: <jp>これは出来たてホカホカの美味しい揚げ出し豆腐ですよ。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: When something has <kanji>become</kanji> <kanji>perfect</kanji> it has reached <vocabulary>completion</vocabulary>.
Reading Mnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.
Context 1-EN: Can you get me up before it's completed?
Context 1-JP: <jp>完成前に起こしてもらえますか？</jp>
Context 2-EN: Tofugu has accomplished a great deal in the last few days.
Context 2-JP: <jp>トーフグはこの数日間で、かなりのりょうを完成させた。</jp>
Context 3-EN: Our new Japanese learning app will be completed in a month or so.
Context 3-JP: <jp>我々の新しい日本語学習アプリは、あと一ヶ月程で完成します。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: <jp>叫ぶ</jp> is "to shout" and "to scream." This is the noun version. This is a <vocabulary>shout</vocabulary> or <vocabulary>scream</vocabulary>.
Reading Mnemonic: The reading comes from <jp>叫ぶ</jp>.
Context 1-EN: If you put triple A batteries in this toy and turn on the power, he will scream.
Context 1-JP: <jp>この人形に単四電池を入れて電源を入れると、叫び出すんです。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: <jp>握り</jp> is a "grip." When you add <jp>お</jp> it's elevated a bit. For some reason it becomes a <vocabulary>rice ball</vocabulary> (aka <vocabulary>onigiri</vocabulary>). To make a rice ball, you use your grip to make them into a ball shape, which is probably where it comes from.
Reading Mnemonic: The reading comes from <jp>握り</jp>.
Context 1-EN: I forbade my son from eating convenience store rice balls.
Context 1-JP: <jp>私は息子がコンビニのお握りを食べることを禁止しました。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: This word consists of kanji with hiragana attached. Because the hiragana ends with an <jp>う</jp> sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means <kanji>"choose"</kanji>, so the verb version is <vocabulary>to choose</vocabulary>.
Reading Mnemonic:
Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. You didn't learn that reading with this kanji, so here's a mnemonic to help you: 

You have the opportunity <vocabulary>to choose</vocabulary>. You choose, and a bright sign lights up reading "<reading>error</reading>" (<jp>えら</jp>).
Context 1-EN: I can't choose who to kill.
Context 1-JP: <jp>だれを殺人するかなんて、選べないよ。</jp>
Context 2-EN: I stopped listening to my teacher and just kept thinking about which girl to choose.
Context 2-JP: <jp>先生の話を聞かずに、ずっとどっちの女の子を選ぼうか考えていました。</jp>
Context 3-EN: You chose a great Fugu costume.
Context 3-JP: <jp>良いフグのコスチュームをお選びになりましたね。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: This word consists of kanji with hiragana attached. Because the hiragana ends with an <jp>う</jp> sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means <kanji>sad</kanji> so the verb form of that is <vocabulary>to be sad</vocabulary>. Boohoo.
Reading Mnemonic: If you're going <vocabulary>to be sad</vocabulary> about something right now, it will be <reading>kana</reading> (<jp>かな</jp>). Don't use kana when you're trying to learn kanji! You'll be sad forever if you're stuck using kana your whole life, so don't let that habit start now, friend.
Context 1-EN: She got dumped and she's very sad.
Context 1-JP: <jp>かの女は失れんしてとても悲しんでいます。</jp>
Context 2-EN: Animals, as well as humans, are saddened by the deaths of their friends.
Context 2-JP: <jp>人間だけではなく、動物も仲間の死を悲しみます。</jp>
Context 3-EN: Don’t be sad. Your Japanese is good enough for now. Just don’t stop learning and you’ll improve little by little.
Context 3-JP: <jp>そう悲しむなって。お前の日本語は今はそれで十分だよ。ただ、勉強することを投げ出さずに、少しずつ上手くなればいいさ。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: A <kanji>weak</kanji> <kanji>insect</kanji>. This is what people call <vocabulary>weakling</vocabulary>s in Japan. This is a good word to know if you're a bully, or something.
Reading Mnemonic:
The reading for this one is a weird one. It uses the kun'yomi readings for both, meaning you'll have to pull your knowledge of the word <jp>弱い</jp> from earlier and apply it here. <jp>虫</jp> should be okay, though, as this is the reading you learned with the kanji.

Just remember, only weak bugs use kun'yomi, and that weak bug is you in this instance.
Context 1-EN: My son, who was such a weakling and a crybaby, is already an adult.
Context 1-JP: <jp>あんなに弱虫でなき虫だったむす子も、もう一人前の大人です。</jp>
Context 2-EN: Many Americans are cowards who can't even eat a bit of natto.
Context 2-JP: <jp>多くのアメリカ人はなっとうごときが食べられない弱虫です。</jp>
Context 3-EN: Cowards should be treated like hairy caterpillars - picked up and thrown out!

Meaning Mnemonic: Something that is <kanji>special</kanji> and <kanji>separate</kanji> from the rest is, well, <vocabulary>special</vocabulary>.
Reading Mnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.
Context 1-EN: I got a special coupon for the new Tarantino film.
Context 1-JP: <jp>タランティーノの新作の、特別ゆう待けんをもらいました。</jp>
Context 2-EN: Is this the special car designed by Tofugu?
Context 2-JP: <jp>これがトーフグデザインの特別な車ですか。</jp>
Context 3-EN: Even though she isn't especially cute, she is very popular among boys, yeah?
Context 3-JP: <jp>あの子って、特別かわいいわけではないのにモテるよね？</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.
Reading Mnemonic: The reading is the same as the kanji. Now that is true kanji <vocabulary>love</vocabulary>.
Context 1-EN: The cactus flower is a symbol of maternal love.
Context 1-JP: <jp>サボテンの花は、母性愛のしょうちょうです。</jp>
Context 2-EN: I like fantasizing about office romance and in my latest fantasy, love grew between Koichi and Viet.
Context 2-JP: <jp>社内恋愛をもう想するのが好きなんですけど、一番最近の私のもう想の中ではコウイチとビエトの間に愛がめ生えちゃったんです！</jp>
Context 3-EN: I think money is more important than love. They often say, "love can move mountains," but in reality you can’t do that without money.
Context 3-JP: <jp>私はお金は愛より大切だと思います。よく「愛があれば山でも動かせる」なんて言いますが、実際はお金が無いとそんなことできないでしょ。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: You've seen <jp>飲む</jp>, so you know this has to do with <kanji>drink</kanji>ing <kanji>alcohol</kanji>. Someone who's known as someone who drinks alcohol is an <vocabulary>alcoholic</vocabulary>, a <vocabulary>boozer</vocabulary>, or a <vocabulary>drunkard</vocabulary>.
Reading Mnemonic: The readings are the vocab words <jp>お酒</jp> and <jp>飲む</jp> combined together into one. You can guess it's a kun'yomi reading because of the <jp>み</jp> on the end of <jp>飲</jp>, which should make you think back to vocab words that use these kanji and the kun'yomi readings. If you can do that, you can read this word (and many others, probably!).
Context 1-EN: He likes dried cuttlefish, even though he is a kid, eh? He could be a boozer in the future.
Context 1-JP: <jp>子どものくせにスルメがすきだなんて、こりゃぁこの子はしょう来酒飲みになるねぇ。</jp>
Context 2-EN: Koichi likes drinking, but he isn't like an alcoholic.
Context 2-JP: <jp>コウイチはお酒は好きだけど、酒飲みってほどじゃあないですよ。</jp>
Context 3-EN: He’s a heavy drinker but he doesn’t like red wine.
Context 3-JP: <jp>彼は大酒飲みだが、赤ワインが苦手だ。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: This is simply a <kanji>blue</kanji> <kanji>sky</kanji> (aka a <vocabulary>blue sky</vocabulary>!).
Reading Mnemonic:
You'd think that this word would use on'yomi readings to read it, but it doesn't (shake that angry fist at the kanji gods!). Instead, it's double kun'yomi, probably because this word is really like two separate words put together, "blue" and "sky." In the previous level you unlocked these two separate words, learning their readings. That means you should be able to read this as well. 

One quick note is the rendaku-fication of <jp>空</jp> as well. It becomes <jp>ぞら</jp>.
Context 1-EN: Is the ocean blue because of the blue sky?
Context 1-JP: <jp>青空のせいで海は青いの？</jp>
Context 2-EN: Let our future generations have the same beautiful sky as we do.
Context 2-JP: <jp>未来の子どもたちに、今と同じくらいうつくしい青空をのこしてあげましょうよ。</jp>
Context 3-EN: Today, it was sunny all day and the blue sky was above us.
Context 3-JP: <jp>今日は一日中晴れて、青空が広がっていました。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: Your job is to <kanji>take</kanji> <kanji>material</kanji>s from a bunch of different people because you're <vocabulary>covering an event</vocabulary>. This <vocabulary>data collection</vocabulary> needs to be thorough, so you try to take all the materials you can from as many people as you can find.
Reading Mnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.
Context 1-EN: I'm wondering if you would allow us to get an interview?
Context 1-JP: <jp>取材にご協力いただけませんか。</jp>
Context 2-EN: The clip where I was interviewed by a TV crew and I said that money isn't everything was used for a news program.
Context 2-JP: <jp>テレビの取材を受けた時に、金が全てではないと答えたところが、ニュース番組に使われていました。</jp>
Context 3-EN: I know it’s difficult, but isn’t there any way that I could collect some data on your husband? If you could help me set up the interview, I would really really appreciate it.
Context 3-JP: <jp>無理は承知なんですが、どうにかご主人を取材させてもらうことはできないでしょうか？もし何とかして頂ければ、本当に本当に感謝します。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: The <kanji>hot water</kanji> of <kanji>tea</kanji>. That is part of the ceremony that goes into the <vocabulary>tea ceremony</vocabulary>.
Reading Mnemonic: The readings are both the readings you learned with the kanji. Now you can spend a little more time drinking tea at a tea ceremony and a little less time trying to remember kanji readings.
Context 1-EN: I'm looking for a shop where I can buy tools for tea ceremonies.
Context 1-JP: <jp>茶の湯の道具が買えるお店をさがしています。</jp>
Context 2-EN: This water is known to be good for tea ceremony.
Context 2-JP: <jp>この水は、茶の湯にてきした水として知られています。</jp>
Context 3-EN: In the world of tea ceremonies there is a saying, "Ichi-go ichi-e," which means "to treasure every encounter." This saying was also used as the subtitle for Japan’s release of Forrest Gump.
Context 3-JP: <jp>茶の湯の世界には、「一つ一つの出会いを大切に」という意味の「一期一会」という言葉があります。この言葉は、映画「フォレスト・ガンプ」の副タイトルとしても使われました。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.
Reading Mnemonic:
Since this word is made up of a single kanji, it should use the kun'yomi reading. When learning the kanji, you didn't learn that reading, so here's a mnemonic to help you with this word: You go up to <vocabulary>Buddha</vocabulary>. You want to rub his head for good luck, because that's what you hear is good to do. Right before you touch him, he backs off and says, "Whoa! I'm <reading>hot, okay</reading>?" (<jp>ほとけ</jp>). You touch him and it burns your hand clean off. 

Imagine saying "hot, okay?" in a strange accent to help you to remember.
Context 1-EN: Viet has decided to leave the Yakuza group and follow the teachings of Buddha.
Context 1-JP: <jp>ビエトはヤクザをやめて、仏の道に入ることを決意しました。</jp>
Context 2-EN: Koichi is always as cool as Buddha and as strict as Enma, the King of Hell.
Context 2-JP: <jp>コウイチは、いつも仏のようにれいせいで、えんま大王のようにきびしい。</jp>
Context 3-EN: There are some proverbs related to Buddha like, "what you don’t know can’t hurt you," and, "the crushed worm will turn."
Context 3-JP: <jp>「知らぬが仏」や「仏の顔も三度まで」など、仏に関する諺はいくつかありますね。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: <kanji>Evidence</kanji> that you <kanji>say</kanji> is <vocabulary>testimony</vocabulary>. Hopefully you won't have to give too much of this in your lifetime.
Reading Mnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.
Context 1-EN: All of the Tofugu workers testified that they had seen Koichi eat Viet's meatball.
Context 1-JP: <jp>全トーフグ社員が、コウイチがビエトのミートボールを食べるのを見たと証言しました。</jp>
Context 2-EN: Only Michael refused because he didn't want to testify against Koichi.
Context 2-JP: <jp>マイケルだけは、コウイチに不利な証言はしたくないと言って、証言を拒否しました。</jp>
Context 3-EN: When Fugu was suspected of placing some puffer fish poison on the teacher’s apple, all his classmates testified that he was innocent.
Context 3-JP: <jp>フグが先生の林檎に河豚毒を塗ったと疑われた時、クラスメート全員が彼は無実だと証言した。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: When you have a <kanji>feeling</kanji> (<jp>気持ち</jp>) that is <jp>いい</jp> (that means "good" by the way), you have a <vocabulary>good feeling</vocabulary>.
Reading Mnemonic: The reading comes from the vocab word <jp>気持ち</jp>, so if you know that (or the vocab words <jp>気</jp> and <jp>持ち</jp>) you should be A-okay on this one. Maybe even <vocabulary>feeling good</vocabulary> about it?
Context 1-EN: This down duvet feels really good.
Context 1-JP: <jp>この羽毛ぶとん、気持ちいい。</jp>
Context 2-EN: Doesn't it feel good to have a clean house?
Context 2-JP: <jp>家がきれいだと気持ちいいよね！</jp>
Context 3-EN: This massage feels good. I'm enjoying this good pain!
Context 3-JP: <jp>このマッサージ、気持ちいい。このいた気持ちよさがたまらない。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.
Reading Mnemonic: Since this word is made up of a single kanji, it should use the kun'yomi reading. When learning the kanji, you didn't learn that reading, so here's a mnemonic to help you with this word: You smell someone's <reading>icky</reading> (<jp>いき</jp>) <vocabulary>breath</vocabulary>. It's gross. Your skin crawls and your eyes roll back in your head from the icky, icky smell. You might die.
Context 1-EN: Your breath is so stinky that I could die.
Context 1-JP: <jp>あんたの息、死ぬほどくさいよ。</jp>
Context 2-EN: You knocked the breath out of me!
Context 2-JP: <jp>びっくりしすぎて、息が止まるかと思ったよ。</jp>
Context 3-JP: <jp>水中で息はしないでください。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: This word consists of kanji with hiragana attached. Because the hiragana ends with an <jp>う</jp> sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means <kanji>quit</kanji> so the verb vocab version is <vocabulary>to quit</vocabulary>.
Reading Mnemonic: Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. You didn't learn that reading with this kanji, so here's a mnemonic to help you: "Hey, you going <vocabulary>to quit</vocabulary>?" "<reading>Yah</reading> (<jp>や</jp>) man, I'm going to quit."
Context 1-EN: I followed the doctor's advice and quit my job.
Context 1-JP: <jp>医者のアドバイスにしたがって、仕事を辞めました。</jp>
Context 2-EN: Who said Michael resigned as chief editor?
Context 2-JP: <jp>マイケルがへん集長を辞めたなんて、だれが言ったの？</jp>
Context 3-EN: Since Fugu quit, I’m thinking about getting him a swim ring as a farewell gift. If anyone wants to join in on my idea, let me know.
Context 3-JP: <jp>フグが会社を辞めるので、お餞別に浮き輪を買おうと思っています。一緒に買いたい人は連絡ください。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: The <kanji>night</kanji> <kanji>meal</kanji> is the meal you eat at night. That is <vocabulary>dinner</vocabulary>.
Reading Mnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.
Context 1-EN: Tonight's supper is salted, sun-dried flounder.
Context 1-JP: <jp>今日の晩ご飯のオカズは、天日干しで作ったカレイの干物です。</jp>
Context 2-EN: Before the dinner, I drank down a glass of beer in one gulp.
Context 2-JP: <jp>晩ご飯の前に、ビールを一気にグビッと飲み干しました。</jp>
Context 3-EN: Koichi almost went insane when he saw how messy the kitchen was after supper.
Context 3-JP: <jp>晩ご飯の後の散らかった台所を見て、コウイチは気が狂いそうだった。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: A <kanji>private</kanji> <kanji>iron</kanji> (remember how <jp>鉄</jp> often has to do with railroad tracks and the like? Same goes here) is a <vocabulary>private railway</vocabulary>. There are a good number of these in Japan.
Reading Mnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.
Context 1-EN: Private railways in Tokyo are too complicated to understand.
Context 1-JP: <jp>東京の私鉄はふくざつでよく分かりません。</jp>
Context 2-EN: When you arrive at Shinjuku Station by JR, please transfer to a private railway.
Context 2-JP: <jp>JRで新宿駅まで行ったら私鉄に乗りかえてください。</jp>
Context 3-EN: I work for one of the major private railway companies in Japan.
Context 3-JP: <jp>私は、とある日本の大手私鉄会社で働いております。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: A <kanji>new</kanji> <kanji>sprout</kanji> is a <vocabulary>sprout</vocabulary> or <vocabulary>bud</vocabulary> or <vocabulary>shoot</vocabulary>. All sprouts are new, after all.
Reading Mnemonic: The reading is the readings you learned with the kanji, combined.
Context 1-EN: At this rate, it will be impossible to finish picking all the tea sprouts by evening.
Context 1-JP: <jp>このペースじゃ、夕方までにお茶の新芽を摘み終わるのは無理じゃないかな。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: A <kanji>shout</kanji> <kanji>voice</kanji> is a <vocabulary>shout</vocabulary> or a <vocabulary>yell</vocabulary>.
Reading Mnemonic: The reading comes from <jp>叫ぶ</jp> and <jp>声</jp>, put together. Careful of the rendaku.
Context 1-EN: Mami lifted the bacon up and down while she screamed.
Context 1-JP: <jp>マミは叫び声を上げながら、ベーコンを上下に動かしました。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: <kanji>Suffering</kanji> and <kanji>labor</kanji>. Sounds like the kind of thing these soft hands wouldn't want to deal with. These are <vocabulary>hardships</vocabulary> and <vocabulary>troubles</vocabulary>. Hopefully you don't have too much of this with kanji anymore!
Reading Mnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.
Context 1-EN: My life was full of hardships until I came across WaniKani.
Context 1-JP: <jp>ワニカニに出会うまでは、おれの人生は苦労ばかりだった。</jp>
Context 2-EN: "I spent a great deal of time and effort on Koichi's autograph." "Good work on that!"
Context 2-JP: <jp>「このコウイチのサイン、苦労してやっと手に入れたんだよ。」「それはご苦労なことですね。」</jp>
Context 3-EN: Since the shower head’s position is fixed in my bath tub, it’s such a pain to rinse the tub out when I wash it.
Context 3-JP: <jp>うちのお風呂って、シャワーの位置が固定されちゃってるから、浴槽を洗って流すときにかなり苦労するんだよね。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: Remember <jp>焦る</jp>, which means "to be in a hurry" or "to be impatient"? This is the noun version, which is <vocabulary>impatience</vocabulary>.
Reading Mnemonic: The reading comes from <jp>焦る</jp>.
Context 1-EN: I had a terrible cramp in my leg and I couldn’t move it at all even though I had to go to a meeting, so I felt really impatient.
Context 1-JP: <jp>会議に行かなくちゃいけなかったのに、脚がやばいくらいつって全然動けなかったので、焦りを感じましたよ。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: This word consists of kanji with hiragana attached. Because the hiragana ends with an <jp>う</jp> sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means <kanji>laugh</kanji> so the verb vocab version is <vocabulary>to laugh</vocabulary>.
Reading Mnemonic: The reading is the same as the one you learned with the kanji. You can laugh freely, now!
Context 1-EN: That adventurer laughed and said he wants to leave his name to posterity.
Context 1-JP: <jp>その冒険家は、後世に名を残したいんだと笑って言った。</jp>
Context 2-EN: Kristen demanded an apology from Koichi while she laughed.
Context 2-JP: <jp>クリステンは、笑いながらコウイチに謝ざいを要求しました。</jp>
Context 3-EN: "I had a date with Fugu last night." "How did it go?" "It was fun. I laughed a lot."
Context 3-JP: <jp>「昨夜、フグとデートをしたの。」「どうだった？」「楽しかった。めちゃくちゃ笑ったわ。」</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: When you <kanji>exit</kanji> and <kanji>come</kanji>, apparently it means <vocabulary>to be able to do</vocabulary>. I think of it like you're leaving a location (<jp>出</jp>) to do a task and then you come (<jp>来る</jp>) back after you did it. Perhaps you were waiting in a room training like someone from Dragonball. When you leave the room, you are ready to fight the enemy and win. You train in that room <vocabulary>to be able to do</vocabulary> whatever you need to do, and only leave and come back alive because you were able to do it.
Reading Mnemonic: The readings are a bit strange. Both kun'yomi, where <jp>出</jp> is <jp>で</jp> and <jp>来る</jp> is <jp>きる</jp>. This is different from the reading you learned with <jp>来る</jp> (<jp>くる</jp>), though, so be careful. If you can remember that and remember the kun'yomi readings from the previous vocab, you should be able to learn this one's reading as well.

Meaning Mnemonic: This has the same meaning as the kanji. The little <jp>り</jp> thrown on there is just a little <vocabulary>remainder</vocabulary> sticking off the end of the kanji. No need to pay attention to that.
Reading Mnemonic: Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. You didn't learn that reading with this kanji, so here's a mnemonic to help you: You're waiting inside. The <vocabulary>remainder</vocabulary> of your forces are out there, fighting. You don't know who will survive... or if they even will. You have a secret <reading>knock</reading> (<jp>のこ</jp>), though, that you use to find out if it's one of the remaining forces outside or the enemy, broken through. You hear a knock. What is it? Is it your men or theirs? Imagine it out, focusing on the knock conversation that happens between you and the remainder.

Meaning Mnemonic: The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well. Can also refer to a <vocabulary>hostel</vocabulary>.

Meaning Mnemonic: The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well. You can also use this word to talk about someone's <vocabulary>age</vocabulary>.
Reading Mnemonic:
Since this word is made up of a single kanji, it should use the kun'yomi reading. When learning the kanji, you didn't learn that reading, so here's a mnemonic to help you with this word: 

This <vocabulary>year</vocabulary> you plan on <reading>tossi</reading>ng (<jp>とし</jp>) out all your old stuff as a New Year's resolution. You pronounce it "toshing" though, because it has more vigor that way.

Meaning Mnemonic: The <kanji>devil</kanji>'s <kanji>method</kanji> is <vocabulary>magic</vocabulary> and <vocabulary>witchcraft</vocabulary>. That's their method of doing things, after all.

Context 1-JP: <jp>わぁ、A級の新しい魔法を習得中なの？上手くいけば、万歳ものだね！</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: This word consists of kanji with hiragana attached. Because the hiragana ends with an <jp>う</jp> sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means <kanji>move</kanji> so the verb vocab version is <vocabulary>to move</vocabulary>.
Reading Mnemonic: Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. You didn't learn that reading with this kanji, so here's a mnemonic to help you: Someone is telling you <vocabulary>to move</vocabulary>. They are saying "<reading>you go</reading> (<jp>うご</jp>) over there. Move! Move!" If it helps, have them pronounce "You go" more like "Ugo."

Context 1-JP: <jp>あそこで何か動いたよ。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: The <kanji>root</kanji> of your <kanji>roof</kanji> is still your <vocabulary>roof</vocabulary>. If it helps, imagine roots growing out of your roof. They protect you from the rain.
Reading Mnemonic: This word uses the kun'yomi readings. The kun'yomi for <jp>根</jp> is <jp>ね</jp>. For a mnemonic, we'll use the sound a horse makes, <reading>neigh</reading> (<jp>ね</jp>). Why is the horse neigh-ing? It's stuck on the <vocabulary>roof</vocabulary>.
Context 1-EN: We have to fix our roof next year.
Context 1-JP: <jp>来年、屋根をしゅう理する必要があります。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: The <kanji>East</kanji> <kanji>Capital</kanji> in Japan is <vocabulary>Tokyo</vocabulary>. If you look on a map and compare it to <jp>京都</jp> (Kyoto, the other capital in history), you'll see it's East of Kyoto, making it the East Capital, Tokyo.
Reading Mnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.
Context 1-EN: We will take a train from Tokyo station to Nakagawa station, and then we will take a bus from Nakagawa station to Mikan mountain.
Context 1-JP: <jp>東京えきから中川えきまででんしゃで行って、中川えきからみかん山までバスで行きます。</jp>
Context 2-EN: I have to go to Tokyo now, so may I have the bill, please?
Context 2-JP: <jp>今から東京に行かなくてはいけないので、そろそろお会けいおねがいします。</jp>
Context 3-EN: As soon as I arrived in Tokyo, I went to McDonald’s.
Context 3-JP: <jp>東京についてすぐに、マクドナルドに行った。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: A "company" (<jp>会社</jp>) <kanji>member</kanji> is someone who works at a company. This is a <vocabulary>company employee</vocabulary>. There are many of these in Japan. Most of them are drunk.
Reading Mnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.
Context 1-EN: My husband is just an ordinary office worker.
Context 1-JP: <jp>わたしの夫は、ごくふ通の会社員です。</jp>
Context 2-EN: We're people before we are employees.
Context 2-JP: <jp>わたしたちはみんな、会社員である前に、一人の人間なんですよ。</jp>
Context 3-EN: That employee got busted for drug possession.
Context 3-JP: <jp>あの会社員は麻薬所持で逮捕された。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: You know that the word <jp>付ける</jp> means "to attach" and you know that the kanji <jp>付</jp> means <kanji>attach</kanji>. So, this word probably has something to do with attaching. This is the intransitive version, though, where something is attached (and you're not doing the attaching). You can use the <jp>く</jp> as a hint. You see something attached on the wall. You say "Coo'"
Reading Mnemonic: The reading can be derived from <jp>付ける</jp>, a word you should have seen a few levels ago. If you know that word's reading you should be able to figure out this word's reading as well (and vice versa).
Context 1-EN: If you buy this computer now, you’ll get something thrown in, so it’s a deal.
Context 1-JP: <jp>今このパソコンを買うと、オマケが付くので、おとくですよ。</jp>
Context 2-EN: Michael's t-shirts have a lot of salad dressing stains on them.
Context 2-JP: <jp>マイケルのTシャツにはドレッシングのしみがたくさん付いています。</jp>
Context 3-EN: What’s that thing attached to your earlobe?
Context 3-JP: <jp>あなたの耳たぶに付いてるそれ、何？</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: A <kanji>dormitory</kanji> <kanji>student</kanji> (comes from <jp>学生</jp>) is a <vocabulary>boarding student</vocabulary> or a <vocabulary>boarder</vocabulary>. This is a student who lives in a dormitory.
Reading Mnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.
Context 1-EN: "Is the new boarding student sexy?" "Yup, she is. Fugu’s got the hots for her already."
Context 1-JP: <jp>「新しい寮生はセクシー？」「ああ、セクシーだよ。フグなんて、すでに彼女に熱を上げているよ。」</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: Your <kanji>special</kanji> <kanji>skill</kanji> is your <vocabulary>specialty</vocabulary>. So, what is your <jp>特技</jp>?
Reading Mnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.
Context 1-EN: My specialty is boiling water. I don't have a single skill outside of that.
Context 1-JP: <jp>わたしの特技は、お湯をわかすことです。それ以外の特技は何一つありません。</jp>
Context 2-EN: The guy in the blue shirt about six people behind me in the line was one of my classmates in high school and he has a specialty where he can play the Sailor Moon theme song with his farts.
Context 2-JP: <jp>私の六人ぐらい後ろにならんでる青い服の男の子、高校の同級生なんだけど、なんとオナラでセーラームーンのテーマをかなでるという特技を持ってるのよ。</jp>
Context 3-EN: Koichi’s specialty is making desserts. He said he likes making them because he likes seeing everyone’s happy faces.
Context 3-JP: <jp>コウイチの特技はお菓子作りです。お菓子作りが好きな理由は、みんなの嬉しそうな顔を見るのが好きだからだそうです。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: This is the same as the kanji, <vocabulary>rather</vocabulary>. Can also mean <vocabulary>better</vocabulary> or <vocabulary>instead</vocabulary>.
Reading Mnemonic: Just think: <vocabulary>rather</vocabulary> than a <reading>bug</reading> (<jp>むし</jp>), how about an animal?
Context 1-EN: I’d rather be a cat than a princess.
Context 1-JP: <jp>お姫様よりも寧ろ猫になりたい。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: The <kanji>remainder</kanji> of time that you work at the ol' <kanji>business</kanji> is extra time that you're working (above the normal work hours). This is <vocabulary>overtime</vocabulary>!
Reading Mnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.
Context 1-EN: If I get paid properly I don't mind working overtime.
Context 1-JP: <jp>ちゃんときゅう料が支はらわれるなら、残業してもいいですよ。</jp>
Context 2-EN: While I was working overtime, the wood fell and I narrowly escaped death.
Context 2-JP: <jp>残業中に、材木がおちてきて、九死に一生をえることになりました。</jp>
Context 3-EN: After working overtime I went to an Italian restaurant alone. I felt pretty lonely lol.
Context 3-JP: <jp>残業後にイタメシ屋でお一人様しちゃったよ〜。なかなか寂しかったぜぃ(笑)</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: <jp>盆</jp> refers to either the <kanji>lantern festival</kanji> or a <kanji>tray</kanji>. The <jp>お</jp> just makes it higher status. The meanings stay the same, though. So, depending on the context, this means <vocabulary>Lantern Festival</vocabulary>, aka <vocabulary>obon</vocabulary> and <vocabulary>obon festival</vocabulary>, or a <vocabulary>tray</vocabulary>.
Reading Mnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.
Context 1-EN: Today’s homework is to make an explanation of what Obon is in English.
Context 1-JP: <jp>今日の宿題は、英語で「お盆」の説明を考えてくる事です。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: If you <kanji>tie</kanji> the <kanji>bureau</kanji> up with your delays this may not get done this year <vocabulary>after all</vocabulary>.
Reading Mnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well. Note the <jp>けつ</jp> gets changed to <jp>けっ</jp> as <jp>つ</jp>s in this situation often do.
Context 1-EN: I didn't end up making umeboshi.
Context 1-JP: <jp>結局、梅干しはつけませんでした。</jp>
Context 2-EN: I woke up to the alarm once, but I eventually fell back asleep.
Context 2-JP: <jp>目覚まし時計で一たんは目が覚めたが、結局またねむりに落ちてしまいました。</jp>
Context 3-EN: I went to buy some Valentine's chocolates for my friends, but in the end I only got some for myself.
Context 3-JP: <jp>バレンタインの友チョコを買いに行ったんだけど、結局自分用チョコしか買わなかったわ。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: When your <kanji>eye</kanji> is on the <kanji>target</kanji> you know your <vocabulary>purpose</vocabulary>. You also have your eye on the <vocabulary>goal</vocabulary> (that's the target, after all!).
Reading Mnemonic: The reading is a reading for <jp>目</jp> that's abnormal. You've seen this reading with <jp>目標</jp> and <jp>目次</jp>, though, so hopefully it won't be too hard at this point. Just imagine telling someone your <jp>目的</jp>, only to have them laugh in your face and begin <reading>mock</reading>ing <jp>もく</jp> you for it. Now you're not so sure if your goal is going to work.
Context 1-EN: What the heck is your goal?
Context 1-JP: <jp>一体、目的は何なんですか？</jp>
Context 2-EN: I started working at this fancy Japanese-style restaurant with my motive being the ability to wear kimono.
Context 2-JP: <jp>着付けが出来るようになるのが目的で、この料ていで働き始めました。</jp>
Context 3-EN: Our goal is to make you all have fun while studying Japanese together.
Context 3-JP: <jp>私たちの目的は、一緒に楽しみながら皆さんに日本語を勉強してもらうことです。</jp>

Meaning: Middle Of The Night,Late At Night
Meaning Mnemonic: The <kanji>deep</kanji> <kanji>night</kanji> is the <vocabulary>middle of the night</vocabulary>. It doesn't get any deeper than that before you start coming out of the night to start the next day.
Reading Mnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.
Context 1-EN: What's up this late at night?
Context 1-JP: <jp>こんな深夜に、どうしたの？</jp>
Context 2-EN: I got a bit hungry in the middle of the night.
Context 2-JP: <jp>深夜に小ばらが空いてきた。</jp>
Context 3-EN: The environmental refugee bears crossed the border late in the night to find something to eat in a new country.
Context 3-JP: <jp>環境難民となった熊たちは、新しい国で食べ物を探すため、深夜、国境を越えた。</jp>

Meaning: To Meet By Chance,To Meet Unexpectedly,To Come Across,To Encounter,To Run Into
Meaning Mnemonic: You <kanji>exit</kanji> your house and you <kanji>meet</kanji> someone. You didn’t mean to meet them, but it happened anyway. That’s why this word means <vocabulary>to meet by chance</vocabulary>.
Reading Mnemonic:
The reading is that of the word <jp>出る</jp> and the word <jp>会う</jp>, both of which you've hopefully seen. The <jp>出</jp> portion may be confusing, but you can usually assume that if one part of the word is kun'yomi / vocab reading, the other part is too, which is why <jp>出</jp> uses the vocab reading.

Oh by the way, this word can be written like this too: <jp>出合う</jp>. It’s not as common, but you may come across it every now and then, so it’s good to know!
Context 1-EN: It looks like we happened to run into each other a little too early.
Context 1-JP: <jp>わたしたち、ちょっと出会うのが早すぎたみたいね。</jp>
Context 2-EN: Last night, I met a guy who's looking for no strings attached fun at a club and I know I shouldn't be into him, but he was really my type.
Context 2-JP: <jp>きのうの夜、クラブで、れんあいかんじょうぬきでただ楽しみたいっていう男に出会ってさ、ハマっちゃいけないのは分かってるけど、めちゃくちゃタイプだったんだよね。</jp>
Context 3-EN: "Are you seeing anyone now, Nicole?" "Yes, I’ve been seeing Eric for a year." "Wow, where did you guys meet?"
Context 3-JP: <jp>「ニコールって、今、付き合っている人いるの？」「ええ。エリックと1年間付き合っているわ。」「そうなんだ！彼とは、どこで出会ったの？」</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: Your <kanji>father</kanji> <kanji>parent</kanji> is your <vocabulary>father</vocabulary>.
Reading Mnemonic: The reading here is pretty weird. It's all kun'yomi. My guess is this translates literally to "father parent" (two different words, therefore uses the other readings). You should know the readings of these two separate words, though. It is <jp>父</jp> (<jp>ちち</jp>) and <jp>親</jp> (<jp>おや</jp>).
Context 1-EN: My father is a wrestler.
Context 1-JP: <jp>わたしの父親はレスラーです。</jp>
Context 2-EN: This morning, I saw my father secretly farting in his room.
Context 2-JP: <jp>今朝、父親が部屋でこっそりオナラをするのを見てしまいました。</jp>
Context 3-EN: Everyone in my family loves my dad.
Context 3-JP: <jp>うちの家族はみんな父親のことが大好きです。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: <kanji>Fall</kanji> into the life of a <kanji>degenerate</kanji> and you'll probably get involved in lots of <vocabulary>corruption</vocabulary>. Stealing, stabbing, money laundering, that kind of stuff.
Reading Mnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.
Context 1-EN: My brother nearly drowns in women and alcohol, and is buried in his horribly corrupted life.
Context 1-JP: <jp>兄は酒と女に溺れ、敢然に堕落した生活を送っています。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.
Reading Mnemonic: Since this word is made up of a single kanji, it should use the kun'yomi reading. When learning the kanji, you didn't learn that reading, so here's a mnemonic to help you with this word: You're looking at a natural <vocabulary>spring</vocabulary> in the ground. Water is bubbling up, but then something changes. It looks a bit clogged... something is poking out. Then, all of a sudden, Mario flies out of the springs, falls in front of you and yells: "<reading>izumeeeee</reading> (<jp>いずみ</jp>), Mario!"
Context 1-EN: We're drinking water from the spring.
Context 1-JP: <jp>わたしたちは、泉からのわき水を飲んでいます。</jp>
Context 2-EN: There are a lot of geese in that spring.
Context 2-JP: <jp>その泉にはがちょうがたくさんいます。</jp>
Context 3-EN: Wow! You look beautiful! Did you go on a special diet? Or did you find the Fountain of Youth?
Context 3-JP: <jp>わぁ！すごく綺麗。何か特別なダイエットでもしたの？それとも、若返りの泉でも見つけたとか？</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: A <kanji>large</kanji> <kanji>Buddha</kanji> doesn't make sense if you don't know the context. There are giant statues of Buddha, and these are called Daibutsu, making this word translate to the <vocabulary>Great Buddha</vocabulary> or <vocabulary>Giant Buddha Statue</vocabulary>.
Reading Mnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.
Context 1-EN: I visited the Great Buddha at Nara yesterday.
Context 1-JP: <jp>昨日、ならの大仏をおとずれました。</jp>
Context 2-EN: Who is that guy staring at the giant Buddha statue so seriously?
Context 2-JP: <jp>大仏をすんげーしんけんに見つめてるあの男、だれ？</jp>
Context 3-EN: "She’s dating Mr. Giant Buddha Statue." "You could have fooled me. He's old enough to be her father."
Context 3-JP: <jp>「彼女、大仏さんと付き合っているのよ。」「とても信じられないわね。だって、彼女の父親と言ってもいいくらい年上でしょ？」</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: <kanji>Politics</kanji> and <kanji>government</kanji>. They are needed to keep the <vocabulary>government</vocabulary> rolling.
Reading Mnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.
Context 1-EN: The U.S. government says that we must strengthen our defenses on the border.
Context 1-JP: <jp>アメリカ政府は、国きょうのぼうびを固めなくてはいけないと言っています。</jp>
Context 2-EN: The government keeps their secrets very well, but they don't keep their promises to the people at all.
Context 2-JP: <jp>政府は、自分たちのひみつは固く守るが、国民との約束はちっとも守らない。</jp>
Context 3-EN: We can’t believe that the government has prohibited our articles from being published. Tofugu has the right to criticize the government.
Context 3-JP: <jp>私達の記事が政府から出版を禁止されているなんて信じられません。Tofuguには政府を批判する権利があります。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: A <kanji>street</kanji> <kanji>rather</kanji> than a not-street. That's what I'm offering you to walk on. It's much nicer this way. I am being <vocabulary>polite</vocabulary> and <vocabulary>courteous</vocabulary> by offering you this street.
Reading Mnemonic: The reading for <jp>丁</jp> is an unexpected one. It's <jp>てい</jp> instead of <jp>ちょう</jp>, so think about how the street is lined with <reading>ta</reading>ter (<jp>てい</jp>) tots, and how you can eat from them as you walk along on your trek. How <vocabulary>polite</vocabulary> of someone to leave them there for you!
Context 1-EN: Even though she is a celebrity, she politely answered my questions and I was really impressed.
Context 1-JP: <jp>有名人なのに、私の説明に丁寧に答えてくれて、すごく感激しました。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well. The <jp>〜</jp> is there to show this attaches onto things, like <jp>東京弁</jp>, meaning "Tokyo Dialect."
Reading Mnemonic: The reading is the same as the one you learned with the kanji. Because it's normally attached to other words it uses the on'yomi reading like a jukugo word normally would.
Context 1-EN: Is Tohoku dialect the most interesting Japanese dialect?
Context 1-JP: <jp>日本語で一番面白い方言は東北弁でしょうか？</jp>
Context 2-EN: I am bilingual because I can speak standard Japanese as well as the Kansai dialect.
Context 2-JP: <jp>私は日本語の共通語も関西弁も話せるからバイリンガルなんですよ。</jp>
Context 3-EN: I think women who speak with a Hakata accent are really cute.
Context 3-JP: <jp>博多弁で喋る女性はとても可愛いと思います。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: <kanji>Teach</kanji> and <kanji>nurture</kanji>. That's what your <vocabulary>education</vocabulary> is supposed to do.
Reading Mnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.
Context 1-EN: The place we are going today is the education center.
Context 1-JP: <jp>今日行くのは教育センターです。</jp>
Context 2-EN: In Japan, education is mandatory through elementary and junior high school.
Context 2-JP: <jp>日本では、小学校教育と中学校教育がぎむ教育です。</jp>
Context 3-EN: Do you remember who said, "It is a thousand times better to have common sense without education than education without common sense?"
Context 3-JP: <jp>「教育があって常識がないよりも、教育がなくて常識がある方がはるかによい。」って誰の言葉だっけ？</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: The thing your <kanji>heart</kanji> <kanji>request</kanji>s is what your heart wants. This is your <vocabulary>heartfelt desire</vocabulary>.
Reading Mnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.
Context 1-EN: We are touched by Salmon's prayer.
Context 1-JP: <jp>サーモンの心願には心が打たれますね。</jp>
Context 2-EN: My heartfelt wish is that the damage caused by the hurricane is less this time.
Context 2-JP: <jp>今回のハリケーンのひがいが少なくてすむようにというのがわたしの心願です。</jp>
Context 3-EN: I bought a charm at the shrine to help fulfill my heart’s desires.
Context 3-JP: <jp>私はその神社で心願成就の御札を買いました。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: The <kanji>right</kanji> side of your body is the side you <kanji>profit</kanji> most from. So, you use it a lot more. That's because you're <vocabulary>right handed</vocabulary>.
Reading Mnemonic: Both kanji use the kun'yomi vocab readings. So, think to the words <jp>右</jp> and <jp>利く</jp> to learn how to read this one. It probably reads like this because it's two separate words come together (right + handed) rather than one word.
Context 1-EN: My son is not right-handed.
Context 1-JP: <jp>わたしの息子は右利きではありません。</jp>
Context 2-EN: Although I am left-handed, my mom bought a right-handed baseball glove by mistake.
Context 2-JP: <jp>ぼくは左利きなのに、お母さんが間ちがえて右利きのグローブを買っちゃったんだ。</jp>
Context 3-EN: I really liked her but I was turned off when I found out that she was right handed. I don’t know why.
Context 3-JP: <jp>彼女のこと、すごく好きだったんだけど、右利きだって分かってから冷めちゃったんだよね。どうしてかは分からないけど。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.
Reading Mnemonic: The reading is the same as the one you learned with the kanji.
Context 1-EN: Koichi turned pale when he learned that his precious cardboard box had been thrown away.
Context 1-JP: <jp>コウイチは、大切にしていたダンボール箱がすてられたことを知って、顔面そう白になりました。</jp>
Context 2-EN: My husband bought tomatoes by the crate and we're having trouble eating them all.
Context 2-JP: <jp>夫がトマトを箱で買ってきて、食べきれなくてこまっています。</jp>
Context 3-EN: The box that arrived at the Tofugu office was crammed with dictionaries and dead puffer fish.
Context 3-JP: <jp>トーフグのオフィスに届いた箱の中には、辞書と死んだフグが詰まっていた。</jp>

Meaning: How To Make,Way To Make,Way Of Making
Meaning Mnemonic: This is the <kanji>way</kanji> to <kanji>make</kanji> something. This is <vocabulary>how to make</vocabulary> something. You'll see this for directions on building something.
Reading Mnemonic: You should know the kun'yomi readings for both of these from lower level vocab. Use that knowledge to remember the reading for this word as well.
Context 1-EN: Please teach me how to make delicious macaroni and cheese.
Context 1-JP: <jp>おいしいマカロニチーズの作り方を教えてください。</jp>
Context 2-EN: There are three ways to make barley tea; steeping it in boiling water, steeping it slowly in boiled water, and steeping it slowly in cold water, and each comes with pros and cons.
Context 2-JP: <jp>麦茶の作り方には、おゆでわかしながらに出す方ほう、ふっとうさせたおゆでジワジワおゆ出しする方ほう、つめたい水でジワジワ水出しする方ほうの三しゅるいありますが、それぞれメリットデメリットがあります。</jp>
Context 3-EN: Do you want to know how to make a ninja star?
Context 3-JP: <jp>手裏剣の作り方を知りたいですか？</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: The <kanji>reality</kanji> is that it's <kanji>black</kanji>. Like, so black that it's beyond fake black, it's reality black. This is so black it's <vocabulary>pitch black</vocabulary>.
Reading Mnemonic: The reading for the <jp>真</jp> is the vocab kun'yomi reading. Think of what is pitch black. It's your poor <reading>Ma</reading> (<jp>ま</jp>). She is so dark that she sucks in light, like a black hole... wait, she is a black hole, it explains why your Ma is pitch black.
Context 1-EN: Koichi loves pitch black garlic and he often eats it so much that his tongue bleeds.
Context 1-JP: <jp>コウイチは真っ黒なニンニクが好きで、よくしたから血が出るまで食べています。</jp>
Context 2-EN: Viet got such a deep tan on the beach in Hawaii that he looked like burnt toast.
Context 2-JP: <jp>ビエトはハワイのビーチで真っ黒に日やけして、まるでこげたトーストのようでした。</jp>
Context 3-EN: OMG, I just came across the cutest pitch black dress.
Context 3-JP: <jp>やばい、超絶に可愛い真っ黒なワンピース見つけちゃったんだけど。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: The <kanji>first</kanji> of something you'll do several or many <kanji>times</kanji> is <vocabulary>the first time</vocabulary>.
Reading Mnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.
Context 1-EN: I got the first-press limited edition of Koichi's new song.
Context 1-JP: <jp>コウイチの新曲の、初回げん定ばんのCDを手に入れました。</jp>
Context 2-EN: We have a special offer for first time customers!
Context 2-JP: <jp>初回のお客さまには、特別かかくでごていきょうしています。</jp>
Context 3-EN: Oh, is this your first time attending our Japanese language club? Okay everyone, he’s a newbie, so let’s go easy on him.
Context 3-JP: <jp>えっ、君が日本語学習クラブに参加するのは今回が初回なんだ？よし、みんな。彼は初心者だから手加減してあげようぜ。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.
Reading Mnemonic: The reading is the same as the one you learned with the kanji, so you can read this one!
Context 1-EN: Let's race and see which one of us can make it to that boulder first.
Context 1-JP: <jp>あの岩のところまでどっちが先に着けるか競争しよう！</jp>
Context 2-EN: At Tofugu, there is a rule that people should leave Koichi alone when his face looks like a boulder.
Context 2-JP: <jp>トーフグにはコウイチが岩みたいなかおをしている時は、話しかけないでそっとしておくという決まりがあります。</jp>
Context 3-EN: Koichi woke up as a huge boulder fell toward him in a dream.
Context 3-JP: <jp>コウイチは、夢の中で大きな岩が頭上に落ちてくるところで、目が覚めた。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: You know that you're <kanji>throw</kanji>ing something that is <kanji>attach</kanji>ing to something else. How else can you say that? The best way would be to say <vocabulary>to throw against</vocabulary> or <vocabulary>to throw at</vocabulary>.
Reading Mnemonic: The readings just come from two vocab words you've hopefully seen already: <jp>投げる</jp> and <jp>付ける</jp>. So long as you know the readings for those words, the reading for this word should be no problem for you.
Context 1-EN: My daughter threw a vase at my head and gave me a serious injury that needed seven stitches.
Context 1-JP: <jp>むすめから、頭に花びんを投げ付けられて、七はりをぬう大けがを負いました。</jp>
Context 2-EN: On the Setsubun, we threw dried beans at Koichi and chased the evil spirits away.
Context 2-JP: <jp>せつ分の日にコウイチにまめを投げ付けてじゃ気をはらいました。</jp>
Context 3-EN: "Salmon, I’m mad about you." "Fugu, I’m actually mad at you! Why did you throw garlic at me? "S..sorry I’ve heard that salmon like the smell of garlic."
Context 3-JP: <jp>「サーモン、僕は君に夢中なんだ。」「フグ、私はあんたに怒り心頭よ。どうして私に向かってニンニクなんて投げ付けるのよ！」「ご…ごめん。鮭はニンニクの臭いが好きって聞いたことがあったんだ。」</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: This is a single kanji with an <jp>い</jp> on the end, meaning you know it's probably an adjective. What's the adjective form of <kanji>sad</kanji>? It's <vocabulary>sad</vocabulary>, sadly.
Reading Mnemonic: You learned this reading with <jp>悲しむ</jp>, hooray!
Context 1-EN: That's too sad.
Context 1-JP: <jp>それは悲しすぎるね。</jp>
Context 2-EN: Sadly, I feel like I've just used up all my luck for it.
Context 2-JP: <jp>悲しいけど、今ので運を使い切ってしまった気がする。</jp>
Context 3-EN: When you feel sad, Momo, neither your dad nor myself are happy.
Context 3-JP: <jp>桃ちゃんが悲しい気持ちの時は、お父さんもお母さんも辛い気持ちになってしまうのよ。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: When you have the <kanji>same</kanji> <kanji>feeling</kanji> as someone else, you have <vocabulary>sympathy</vocabulary> for them, because you know how they feel. How kind of you!
Reading Mnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.
Context 1-EN: I empathize with Koichi's views.
Context 1-JP: <jp>わたしはコウイチの意見に同感ですね。</jp>
Context 2-EN: I've never agreed with someone so much.
Context 2-JP: <jp>今までにこんなに同感したことがないぐらい、思いっきり同感しています。</jp>
Context 3-EN: "I hate Fugu." "I feel the same way."
Context 3-JP: <jp>「私、フグのこと嫌い。」「同感だわ。」</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: A <kanji>sick</kanji> <kanji>pillar</kanji> is the pillar that holds up the side of the building that's made for sick people. That's a <vocabulary>hospital ward</vocabulary>.
Reading Mnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.
Context 1-EN: Did you see any hot guys in your hospital ward?
Context 1-JP: <jp>あんたの病棟で、かっこいい男は見た？</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: You <kanji>need</kanji> this <kanji>request</kanji> to happen, so you don't just request it, you <vocabulary>demand</vocabulary> it.
Reading Mnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.
Context 1-EN: Laborers demanded higher wages.
Context 1-JP: <jp>労働者たちは、ちん上げを要求した。</jp>
Context 2-EN: The company's demands were feudalistic and disgust me.
Context 2-JP: <jp>会社からの要求が前近代的すぎて気持ち悪いんだけど。</jp>
Context 3-JP: <jp>この要求はいくらなんでも無茶だ。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: The <kanji>surface</kanji> of a <kanji>drawing</kanji> is a <vocabulary>screen</vocabulary>. Just imagine your computer screen. On its surface is a drawing, right? It just happens to move around all the time, but it's still a screen!
Reading Mnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.
Context 1-EN: If you stare at computer screens for a long time, your eyesight will get worse.
Context 1-JP: <jp>ずっとコンピューターの画面ばかり見ていると目が悪くなるよ。</jp>
Context 2-EN: Lately, an obscene image of dogs keeps automatically appearing on our monitor, so yeah, we're having some issues.
Context 2-JP: <jp>最近、よく犬のエッチな画像が自動で画面に出てくるからみんなこまっているんだよね。</jp>
Context 3-EN: It’s weird. Viet is sitting glued to a screen for hours as usual, though his actual screen has been completely black since this morning.
Context 3-JP: <jp>変なんだよ。ビエトはいつも通り画面に釘付けになって何時間も座ったままでいるんだけど、肝心の画面は今朝から真っ黒なんだよね。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: This word consists of kanji with hiragana attached. Because the hiragana ends with an <jp>う</jp> sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means <kanji>clear up</kanji>, so the verb vocab version is <vocabulary>to clear up</vocabulary>. It also means <vocabulary>to become sunny</vocabulary> as well.
Reading Mnemonic: The reading you learned with the kanji is the one you use here. One of those words where the kun'yomi's going to be more useful.
Context 1-EN: It's raining right now, but I think it will clear up by two.
Context 1-JP: <jp>今は雨がふってますけど、二時までには晴れると思いますよ。</jp>
Context 2-EN: It was good that it ended up being very sunny yesterday.
Context 2-JP: <jp>昨日はよく晴れて良かったですね。</jp>
Context 3-EN: I’m finally getting married to Fugu and I want you to be at our wedding. I’ll send you an invitation with all the details later. The reception will be outside, so I hope it’s sunny that day.
Context 3-JP: <jp>ようやくフグと結婚することになったので、是非式に来てほしいなと思っています。詳細を同封した招待状を後ほどお送りしますね。パーティーは野外の予定なので、当日晴れるといいんだけどな。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: <kanji>I</kanji>, my <kanji>comrade</kanji> (which is me), is <vocabulary>I</vocabulary>, it's <vocabulary>myself</vocabulary>, it's <vocabulary>me</vocabulary>. This is a weird way to say "I" and has a hint of arrogance to it.
Reading Mnemonic: The reading comes from the readings you learned with the kanji readings.
Context 1-EN: Please forgive me for not writing to you in such a long time.
Context 1-JP: <jp>吾輩が貴殿に久しく手紙を書いていなかったことをどうかお許しください。</jp>

Meaning: To Look Back At,To Look Back On,To Look Back
Meaning Mnemonic: Your <kanji>see</kanji>ing is <kanji>return</kanji>ing on something. This is when you look back at something you've already looked at before. This word means <vocabulary>to look back at</vocabulary>.
Reading Mnemonic: The readings are just <jp>見</jp> and the vocab word <jp>返る</jp>, combined together. So long as you know both of those you should be able to combine them into the reading for this word.
Context 1-EN: I don't have time to look back on the past.
Context 1-JP: <jp>か去を見返ってるひまはないんだよ。</jp>
Context 2-EN: The figure of the baby looking back at me is just too cute and totes adorbs.（*´▽｀*）
Context 2-JP: <jp>赤さまの見返るおすがたがただただかわいすぎてモエまくっておりまする（*´▽｀*）</jp>
Context 3-EN: There was a huge crash and I involuntarily looked behind me.
Context 3-JP: <jp>ガシャーンと大きな音がして、私は思わず後ろを見返った。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: A <kanji>child</kanji> of a <kanji>man</kanji> is no man, it is a <vocabulary>boy</vocabulary>.
Reading Mnemonic: If you know the kun'yomi readings of both of these kanji you should be okay. You have two separate single-kanji words put together by a <jp>の</jp>. That's why it's the kun'yomi reading - they're separate.
Context 1-EN: The boy in front of them is Okada’s child.
Context 1-JP: <jp>まえにいる男の子は、おか田さんの子どもです。</jp>
Context 2-EN: Congratulation, mom. It's a cute baby boy!
Context 2-JP: <jp>おめでとうございます、お母さん。かわいい男の子ですよ。</jp>
Context 3-EN: That boy has so much energy. He just threw twenty eggs at his aunt’s head and managed to run away.
Context 3-JP: <jp>あの男の子は元気が良すぎる。今さっきも叔母さんの頭に卵を二十個投げつけて、うまく逃げ切ったんだ。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: Something that has <kanji>slice</kanji>d <kanji>new</kanji>ness into the world is a <vocabulary>novel idea</vocabulary>. It is <vocabulary>original</vocabulary> and <vocabulary>novel</vocabulary>. Just imagine the world as a place of things that are already done. If you want to get something new and novel in there, you have to slice that oldness open to make space for the new.
Reading Mnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.
Context 1-EN: I prefer the former idea to the latter because it is a much more original idea.
Context 1-JP: <jp>すごく斬新なアイディアなので、後者よりも最初の案の方がいいと思います。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: If you go towards something and <kanji>hurry</kanji> while you do it, you are doing it <vocabulary>suddenly</vocabulary>.
Reading Mnemonic: The reading is the same as what you learned with the kanji. <vocabulary>Suddenly</vocabulary> you can read a new word!
Context 1-EN: A matchbox abruptly dropped from the sky.
Context 1-JP: <jp>急に空からマッチ箱が一箱ふってきたんです。</jp>
Context 2-EN: Oh, Kristen! Even if you tell me something like that immediately, I'm at a loss...
Context 2-JP: <jp>えっ、クリステン！急にそんなことを言われても、困るよ...。</jp>
Context 3-EN: Family Guy is famous for its random and stupid flashbacks.
Context 3-JP: <jp>ファミリー・ガイは、急に馬鹿げた回想シーンを使うことで良く知られている。</jp>

Meaning: Killing With A Sword,Putting To The Sword
Meaning Mnemonic: A <kanji>slice</kanji> <kanji>kill</kanji> is a <vocabulary>killing with a sword</vocabulary>. You don't want to hear this, if at all possible.
Reading Mnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.
Context 1-EN: My favorite anime character was slaughtered.
Context 1-JP: <jp>僕のお気に入りのアニメキャラクターが斬殺されてしまった。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: You think about the <kanji>concept</kanji> of a certain number of <kanji>times</kanji>, each time thinking of each time you've thought about this concept before. Each time you look back, that is <vocabulary>retrospection</vocabulary> on that concept. You look back more and more times until there are no more times to look back on.
Reading Mnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.
Context 1-EN: I really like this retrospective scene in the movie.
Context 1-JP: <jp>この映画のこの回想のシーンがすごくすきなんだよね。</jp>
Context 2-EN: Koichi was reminiscing incoherently with his cat on the veranda.
Context 2-JP: <jp>コウイチはえんがわでネコと一しょにとりとめのない回想にふけっていた。</jp>
Context 3-EN: I know that Viet sometimes reminisces about his yakuza days during work hours.
Context 3-JP: <jp>ビエトが時々、仕事中にヤクザ時代のことを回想しているのをわたしは知っている。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: Something that is <kanji>not</kanji> <kanji>convenience</kanji> is <vocabulary>inconvenient</vocabulary>.
Reading Mnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.
Context 1-EN: Not having a car around here is really inconvenient.
Context 1-JP: <jp>この辺りでは、車を持っていないとかなり不便ですよ。</jp>
Context 2-EN: How is WaniKani working out for you? Have you experienced any issues?
Context 2-JP: <jp>ワニカニの使い勝手はいかがですか？ご不便はございませんか？</jp>
Context 3-EN: Welcome to my man cave. Beers are in the refrigerator. It may be a bit inconvenient for you, but you’ve got to go outside to smoke.
Context 3-JP: <jp>俺の隠れ家へようこそ。ビールは冷蔵庫に入ってるぜ。ちょっと不便かもしれねぇが、煙草は外で吸ってくれよな。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: Remember <jp>一番目</jp>? This is just like that, but with three, making it the <vocabulary>third thing</vocabulary> or simply <vocabulary>the third</vocabulary>.
Reading Mnemonic: Use your knowledge of the reading for <jp>一番目</jp> to remember the reading for this word as well.
Context 1-EN: This is probably my third favorite Beatles's song.
Context 1-JP: <jp>この曲、ビートルズの中で三番目くらいにすき。</jp>
Context 2-EN: If you are looking for Koichi, he's reading Harry Potter on the third toilet from the left.
Context 2-JP: <jp>コウイチなら左から三番目のトイレでハリーポッターを読んでるよ。</jp>
Context 3-EN: Did you know that Japan has the third highest number of inhabited islands in the world, after Indonesia and the Philippines?
Context 3-JP: <jp>日本の有人島の多さは、インドネシア、フィリピンに次いで、世界で三番目だってこと、知ってた？</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.
Reading Mnemonic: Since this word is made up of a single kanji, it should use the kun'yomi reading. When learning the kanji, you didn't learn that reading, so here's a mnemonic to help you with this word: You take your <kanji>cloth</kanji> and put it on top of your head. It's there because right at <reading>noon</reading> (<jp>ぬの</jp>) the sun is in the middle of the sky and burns your scalp. So, you cover it with a cloth. Imagine yourself setting an alarm for noon to help you to focus on the noon part.
Context 1-EN: Can you change out this cloth for a new one?
Context 1-JP: <jp>その布、新しい布に変えてもらえるかな？</jp>
Context 2-EN: The cloth got caught in my zipper and it won't move right.
Context 2-JP: <jp>布が絡んじゃって、チャックがうまく開かないのよ。</jp>
Context 3-EN: I’ve heard that cloth diapers are better for your health than disposable ones.
Context 3-JP: <jp>布おむつの方が紙おむつよりも健康にいいと聞いたことがあります。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: When you <kanji>arrange</kanji> something according to <kanji>reason</kanji>, the result is an <vocabulary>arrangement</vocabulary>.
Reading Mnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.
Context 1-EN: This apartment's residents' rooms are all neatly arranged.
Context 1-JP: <jp>このアパートの住民の部屋はみんなきちんと整理されています。</jp>
Context 2-JP: <jp>整理整とんすることは大切です。</jp>
Context 3-EN: I organized the photos from my field trip.
Context 3-JP: <jp>修学旅行で撮った写真を整理しました。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: You know the single word <jp>時</jp>, right? It means <kanji>time</kanji>. This is that twice. So you have one time, and you have another time. They are separate. Things don't happen in every of these times you have. They happen <vocabulary>sometimes</vocabulary>.
Reading Mnemonic: The reading is the vocab word <jp>時</jp> twice, with the second one getting rendaku'd.
Context 1-EN: Sometimes I read Tofugu articles in a restaurant on the top floor of the Tofugu hotel.
Context 1-JP: <jp>私は時々トーフグホテルの最上階のレストランでトーフグの記事を読みます。</jp>
Context 2-EN: At the beach, sometimes a pleasant breeze would gently caress my cheek.
Context 2-JP: <jp>はま辺では、時々、そよ風がわたしのほほをやさしくなでていった。</jp>
Context 3-EN: Tofugu gets into trouble with its customers at times. One time it even led to a fist fight that ended in a death, so you should be careful with them, really.
Context 3-JP: <jp>トーフグって、時々お客さんともめるんだよね。あるトラブルが、死人を出すなぐり合いのけんかになったこともあるから、ほんと、気を付けた方がいいよ。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic:
The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well. It also refers to <vocabulary>cooked rice</vocabulary>, because you gotta eat cooked rice with every meal, so it's basically synonymous with "meal" itself.

This word has a slightly gruff feel to it so it's used mostly in informal situations.
Reading Mnemonic: Since this word is made up of a single kanji, it should use the kun'yomi reading. When learning the kanji, you didn't learn that reading, so here's a mnemonic to help you with this word: You're eating a <vocabulary>meal</vocabulary>... MMmm, delicious! What are you eating? Well, it's a <reading>Mesh</reading> (<jp>めし</jp>) net. Taste the mesh net. It tastes terrible. This is a bad meal. Feel it in your mouth. It's weird and meshy.
Context 1-EN: Oh no. I forgot to cook rice.
Context 1-JP: <jp>しまった！飯をたくのをわすれてた。</jp>
Context 2-EN: Koichi would rather work for Tofugu than eat.
Context 2-JP: <jp>コウイチは三度の飯よりトーフグの仕事をするのが好きです。</jp>
Context 3-EN: Those were some really stinky-smelling meals! I never want to go back to prison.
Context 3-JP: <jp>あそこの飯は本当に臭かったぜ。二度と塀の中には戻りたくねえな。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: Something that's <kanji>not</kanji> <kanji>good</kanji> is <vocabulary>bad</vocabulary>. Alternatively, it can be <vocabulary>substandard</vocabulary>.
Reading Mnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.
Context 1-EN: It feels like Viet kind of has bad-boy hair today, don't you think?
Context 1-JP: <jp>ビエト、今日はちょっと不良な感じのかみがただね。</jp>
Context 2-EN: Substandard potato chips were sold at half price, so I bought one and ate it. Then I got diarrhea.
Context 2-JP: <jp>ひんしつ不良のポテトチップスが半額で売ってたので買って食べたらおなかをこわしました。</jp>
Context 3-EN: That delinquent girl’s grades suddenly dropped drastically and then she joined a gang.
Context 3-JP: <jp>あの不良少女は、急に成績が大幅に下がった後、ギャングの一員になったんです。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.
Reading Mnemonic: The reading is the same as the one you learned with the kanji, so no need to think too hard.
Context 1-EN: I bought that pine tree and yet I had to wait twenty minutes to get it.
Context 1-JP: <jp>その松買うのに、二十分間も待ったんだよ。</jp>
Context 2-EN: A pine cone fell off a pine tree and hit my head.
Context 2-JP: <jp>松の木から松ぼっくりが落ちてきてわたしの頭に当たった。</jp>
Context 3-EN: In my elementary school, classrooms were labeled "pine class" and "bamboo class" rather than "1st class," "2nd class," and so on.
Context 3-JP: <jp>わたしの小学校では、クラスを一組、二組、とは分けずに、松組、竹組で分けていました。</jp>

Meaning: Garbage Can,Garbage Bin,Trash Can,Trash Bin,Waste Can,Waste Bin,Rubbish Bin
Meaning Mnemonic: <jp>ゴミ</jp> means "garbage." Add a <kanji>box</kanji> to it and you have a garbage box aka a <vocabulary>garbage can</vocabulary> or <vocabulary>garbage bin</vocabulary>.
Reading Mnemonic: The reading is just the kun'yomi reading, the one you learned with the kanji. Be sure to pay attention to the rendaku though. <jp>はこ</jp> changes to <jp>ばこ</jp>.
Context 1-EN: There were boxed fresh fish in the garbage can.
Context 1-JP: <jp>ゴミ箱に、新せんな箱づめの魚がすてられていました。</jp>
Context 2-EN: I had weakly hoped to find the wedding ring in the trash can.
Context 2-JP: <jp>そのゴミ箱の中にけっこん指輪があるかもしれないというかすかな希望がありました。</jp>
Context 3-EN: I think you are so sexy when you empty the garbage can— could you empty the garbage can for me please?
Context 3-JP: <jp>ゴミ箱のゴミを捨てる時のあなたってとってもセクシーだと思うのよね。だから、ちょっと私のためにゴミ箱のゴミを捨ててくれないかな？</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: What does <kanji>self</kanji> and <kanji>awake</kanji> mean in combination? This refers to <vocabulary>consciousness</vocabulary>, <vocabulary>awareness</vocabulary>, or having a <vocabulary>realization</vocabulary>.
Reading Mnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.
Context 1-EN: My mother-in-law told me I lack an awareness for maternal responsibilities and that made me super upset.
Context 1-JP: <jp>ぎりの母から、母親としての自覚が無いって言われて、すっごくはらが立ちました。</jp>
Context 2-EN: Please be aware that you are a great WaniKani user, and study Japanese hard.
Context 2-JP: <jp>自分がすばらしいワニカニユーザーなんだという自覚を持って、日本語の勉強にはげんでください。</jp>
Context 3-EN: I’ve stopped smoking for three months now, but I still get the urge to smoke a cigarette every once in a while. Interestingly, when I really want to smoke, I’m not really aware of it. I only just realize it when I find myself chewing on my index finger.
Context 3-JP: <jp>禁煙して三ヶ月になるけど、まだ時々煙草を吸いたいという衝動に駆られるね。興味深いことに、煙草が吸いたくなる時、自分ではそれをあまり自覚してないんだ。自分の人差し指を噛みしめているのに気づいて、ようやく自覚するんだよ。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: The <jp>気持ち</jp> (feeling) is <kanji>bad</kanji>. So, you can imagine how you feel isn't good, it's a <vocabulary>bad feeling</vocabulary>. You're <vocabulary>feeling terrible</vocabulary>, in fact.
Reading Mnemonic: The readings come from the words <jp>気持ち</jp> and <jp>悪い</jp>. Hopefully you've seen both and can combine them together to know the reading automatically. No bad feelings with this word, right?
Context 1-EN: I'm hungover, I have a bad headache, and I feel terrible. This is awful.
Context 1-JP: <jp>二日よいで、頭はガンガンするし、めっちゃ気持ち悪いし、最悪だよ。</jp>
Context 2-EN: Koichi called out to Viet with his sickly sweet voice.
Context 2-JP: <jp>コウイチは気持ち悪いネコなで声で、ビエトをよんだ。</jp>
Context 3-EN: Stop bending your arms like that. It’s seriously weirding me out.
Context 3-JP: <jp>ちょっと、そんな風に腕を曲げるのやめてくれない？めちゃくちゃ気持ち悪いんだけど。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: The <kanji>river</kanji> <kanji>pig</kanji> is what's known as <vocabulary>fugu</vocabulary> or <vocabulary>blowfish</vocabulary>. That's the mascot for our best friend, the Tofugu!
Reading Mnemonic: The reading makes no sense, really. Neither kanji readings work. But, if you remember that a river pig is a fugu, you can know the reading is <reading><jp>ふぐ</jp></reading> as well! YOU ARE A BLOWFISH, JESSE!
Context 1-EN: "I’ll have a blowfish and tofu sandwich." "I’ll have the same."
Context 1-JP: <jp>「豆腐と河豚のサンドイッチをお願いします。」 「同じく。」</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: The <kanji>plan</kanji> <kanji>inside</kanji> this piece of paper is the <vocabulary>guide</vocabulary> you'll be using. It's a plan. It's inside. Use it as your guide!
Reading Mnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.
Context 1-EN: "Do you have a table for two?" "It will be just a moment before I will guide you to your seats."
Context 1-JP: <jp>「二人なんですが、席は空いていますか？」「お席にご案内するまで少しお待ちください。」</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: You've hopefully seen <jp>消化</jp> by now and know that it means "digestion." If you know that, then you can see that the "digestion" is <kanji>not</kanji> <kanji>good</kanji>. When your digestion is not good, what do you have? <vocabulary>Indigestion</vocabulary>. Excuse me, I have to run to the restroom...
Reading Mnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well. Knowing <jp>消化</jp> and <jp>不良</jp> will help as well.
Context 1-EN: I'm looking for indigestion meds.
Context 1-JP: <jp>消化不良のくすりをさがしています。</jp>
Context 2-EN: I asked Koichi out, but his answer was very unclear and it's making me frustrated and giving me indigestion.
Context 2-JP: <jp>コウイチくんにこく白したんだけど、返事が全然はっきりしなかったから、消化不良ですごくモヤモヤしてるんだよね。</jp>
Context 3-EN: I am suffering from indigestion. I have heartburn, bloating, and I feel sick to my stomach. Please leave me alone.
Context 3-JP: <jp>今、消化不良で苦しんでるの。胸焼けもするし、膨満感もあるし、すごく気持ち悪い。しばらく放っておいてくれない。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: Remember <jp>細い</jp> and how it means "thin." Well, this is another adjective that comes from the kanji <jp>細</jp> with a similar but different meaning (sorry!). If you think about something that's very thin, though, there isn't much surface area. In order to use this very thin thing (say, to put your favorite model railroad on) you have to zoom way in and get incredibly <vocabulary>detailed</vocabulary> with it. It's super <vocabulary>small</vocabulary> and <vocabulary>fine</vocabulary>, so get your magnifying lens out! You can remember that this one is "detailed" or "fine" because the <jp>かい</jp> makes you think of <reading>coy</reading>otes. You put a ton of work into this detailed and fine model railroad on a very thin piece of land. Then, a coyote comes in and trashes it all, because you made the mistake of making it out of meat.
Reading Mnemonic:
This word has a different reading from the ones you've learned so far (sorry), so here's a mnemonic to help you:

After the coyote wrecks your pretty train things he bites you on the head, sending you into an indefinite <reading>coma</reading> (<jp>こま</jp>).
Context 1-EN: Then, finely chop this cabbage please.
Context 1-JP: <jp>じゃあ、このキャベツを細かくきざんでください。</jp>
Context 2-JP: <jp>細かいお金しかありません。</jp>
Context 3-EN: You can’t see the wood for the trees. Don’t just focus on the details, look at the bigger picture.
Context 3-JP: <jp>木を見て森を見ず、だぜ。細かいことにばかり気をとられずに、もっと大きいスケールで物を考えてくれよ。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: You have such <kanji>abundant</kanji> <kanji>luck</kanji>! When you have abundant luck, most people probably would think you also have a lot of <vocabulary>wealth</vocabulary>, because lots of wealth equals lots of luck, right?
Reading Mnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.
Context 1-EN: As if the depression was someone else's problem, Koichi became wealthier and wealthier.
Context 1-JP: <jp>不けい気を尻目に、コウイチはどんどん裕福になっていった。</jp>
Context 2-EN: I think Viet comes from a wealthy family.
Context 2-JP: <jp>ビエトって、裕福な家庭の出身だと思うんだよね。</jp>
Context 3-EN: My parents are not super rich but they are relatively wealthy.
Context 3-JP: <jp>僕の両親はド金持ちって訳じゃないけど、比較的裕福な方ではあります。</jp>

Meaning: To Cut Down,To Slice Off,To Lop Off
Meaning Mnemonic: Because the hiragana ends with an <jp>う</jp> sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means <kanji>slice</kanji> and the verb vocab version means <vocabulary>to cut down</vocabulary> or <vocabulary>to slice off</vocabulary> or <vocabulary>to lop off</vocabulary>. This word mainly refers to cutting people with a sword, if you haven't figured it out yet.
Reading Mnemonic: The reading is the same as <jp>切る</jp>, which means "to cut." Similar meaning, same reading.
Context 1-EN: The samurai told me he would cut off my tongue if I couldn’t say the tongue twister properly.
Context 1-JP: <jp>その侍は、早口言葉が上手く言えなければお前の舌を斬るぞ、と私に言いました。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: A <kanji>criticism</kanji> is when you <kanji>judge</kanji>. It is still just a <vocabulary>criticism</vocabulary>.
Reading Mnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.
Context 1-EN: Sometimes you can’t help but be the subject of criticism.
Context 1-JP: <jp>批判の的となっても仕方がないと思っている。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: You remember how <jp>載る</jp> is "to be published"? This one is <vocabulary>to publish</vocabulary>, as in you do it yourself. You know this because you <reading>sel</reading>f (<jp>せる</jp>) publish, which makes it so you're able to publish something (no publishers would accept that rubbish about the vampires, sorry).
Reading Mnemonic: The reading is shared with <jp>載る</jp>, so as long as you remember that you can remember this.
Context 1-EN: I’m a little uncomfortable publishing my own picture on the Internet.
Context 1-JP: <jp>自分の写真をインターネットに載せるのには、ちょっと抵抗があります。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: <kanji>Somebody</kanji> who is <kanji>alone</kanji> is <vocabulary>single</vocabulary> or <vocabulary>unmarried</vocabulary>.
Reading Mnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.
Context 1-EN: I’m single and looking for someone I can marry. That’s really it for now. But please do not hesitate to contact me if you need any further information about me.
Context 1-JP: <jp>私は独身で、婚活中です。とりあえずそんな感じですが、何か他に聞きたいことがあれば、遠慮なくご連絡ください。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: I <kanji>exist</kanji>, I <kanji>suppose</kanji>... this is the kind of <vocabulary>existence</vocabulary> I have. I'm not really sure either way, and I don't care. Existence is futile, I suppose.
Reading Mnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.
Context 1-EN: There were no existing flood-control measures in this town to begin with.
Context 1-JP: <jp>そもそも、この町には水害防止対さくが存在していなかったんだよ。</jp>
Context 2-EN: So does that mean there were no holes in the ozone layer originally?
Context 2-JP: <jp>じゃあ、最初はオゾンそうに穴は存在していなかったんですか？</jp>
Context 3-EN: "I can’t believe Koichi exists..." Fugu said.
Context 3-JP: <jp>「コウイチさんが存在するとは思えない…」とフグは言った。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: Hopefully you've seen <jp>暗記</jp> before now. It means "memorization." So, turn that into a verb and you have <vocabulary>to memorize</vocabulary>.
Reading Mnemonic: The reading comes from <jp>暗記</jp>. It also is the reading you learned with the kanji too.
Context 1-EN: Kristen knows the lyrics of the Sailor Moon's theme song by heart.
Context 1-JP: <jp>クリステンはセーラームーンのテーマ曲の歌しを暗記している。</jp>
Context 2-EN: I have to memorize every single line in the script by tomorrow.
Context 2-JP: <jp>明日までに、台本に書いてあるセリフを一つ残らず暗記しなければいけません。</jp>
Context 3-EN: Memorizing sentences is more efficient than memorizing words by themselves.
Context 3-JP: <jp>文を丸ごと暗記する方が、単語だけを暗記するより効率がいい。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: Remember blood pressure (<jp>血圧</jp>)? Well, now the blood pressure is <kanji>tall</kanji>... so you have "tall blood pressure." Well that's dumb. Let's call it <vocabulary>high blood pressure</vocabulary> instead.
Reading Mnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.
Context 1-EN: The cause is high blood pressure.
Context 1-JP: <jp>原因は高血圧です。</jp>
Context 2-EN: Who the heck is spreading the false rumor that Koichi has high blood pressure?
Context 2-JP: <jp>コウイチが高血圧だというデマをあちこちで飛ばしているのは一体だれなんだ？</jp>
Context 3-EN: Fugu has high blood pressure and was told that he must stick to a low-salt diet by a doctor.
Context 3-JP: <jp>フグは高血圧で、塩分の少ない食事を取る必要があるとお医者さんから言われた。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: A <kanji>stocks</kanji> <kanji>ritual</kanji> is the dance we do in the modern world around <vocabulary>stocks</vocabulary> and <vocabulary>shares</vocabulary> of different companies. Buy! Sell! Buy! Sell!
Reading Mnemonic: The readings are the ones you learned with the kanji.
Context 1-EN: The news that the stock market seemed to go into a bottomless decline was a great blow to him.
Context 1-JP: <jp>株式市場が底なしの下落に陥ったようだというニュースは、彼に大きな精神的ダメージを与えた。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: <kanji>Two</kanji> time <kanji>ten</kanji> <kanji>years old</kanji> is <vocabulary>twenty years old</vocabulary>.
Reading Mnemonic: The reading for twenty years old, specifically, is a really weird reading. It's <jp>はたち</jp>. When you turn <vocabulary>twenty years old</vocabulary> you become a hater of cheese. A <reading>hater cheese</reading> (<jp>はたち</jp>) kinda person.
Context 1-EN: "I’ll be company president before I’m twenty years old." "I hope you’re right about that."
Context 1-JP: <jp>「僕は二十歳になる前に社長になるよ。」「そうだといいけどね。」</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: A <kanji>chair</kanji> <kanji>child</kanji> is for some reason just a <vocabulary>chair</vocabulary>. Not sure why it's a child, but it is.
Reading Mnemonic: The reading for <jp>子</jp> is weird. It's <jp>す</jp>, so think about how you sat on this chair and it broke, so you <reading>sue</reading>d (<jp>す</jp>) the person who made the chair (who happened to be a child).
Context 1-EN: Do you have this chair in any other colors?
Context 1-JP: <jp>この椅子の色違いは置いてますか？</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic:
The <kanji>law</kanji> of <kanji>move</kanji>ment is governed by <vocabulary>rhythm</vocabulary>. Imagine moving around to a boss beat. As you move, you start to feel the rhythm in your step. Go ahead and walk around your room and feel this rhythm. 

Note that <jp>リズム</jp> is probably going to be more common of a word to use for <vocabulary>rhythm</vocabulary>, but this is a kanji learning site after all. One thing you will see more often is <jp>律動的</jp> which means "rhythmic."
Reading Mnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.
Context 1-EN: This morning, I saw a lot of rabbits jumping rhythmically in my garden.
Context 1-JP: <jp>今朝、たくさんの兎が庭で律動的に飛び跳ねているのを見ました。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: <kanji>Years old</kanji> in <kanji>month</kanji>s shows <vocabulary>time</vocabulary> in <vocabulary>years</vocabulary>. Just imagine counting time by months and years... You kind of do anyways, right? How old are you? 5 years old. Or, 5 and a half years old (that's five years six months). So, it makes some sense.
Reading Mnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.
Context 1-EN: After fifty years had passed and I was almost starting to forgot about him, we ran into each other in a tiny bakery.
Context 1-JP: <jp>それから半世紀の歳月が流れ、彼のことなんてほとんど忘れかけていた時に、私達は小さなパン屋さんで偶然再会したんです。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.
Reading Mnemonic: The reading is the same as the one you learned! Now you just have to make sure you know what a Wisteria is... This word is often found in names, like a lot, so look out for it in that way.
Context 1-EN: What’s this Wisteria Combo on the menu?
Context 1-JP: <jp>メニューにある、この藤セットって何ですか？</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: A <kanji>superior</kanji> <kanji>haiku</kanji> requires someone really famous and well known to read it... it's just on that level. Who is super well known and who deserves to read this superior haiku? A great <vocabulary>actor</vocabulary>, perhaps?
Reading Mnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.
Context 1-EN: My boyfriend is the actor performing the part of the horse.
Context 1-JP: <jp>私の恋人は、この芝居で馬の役を演じている俳優よ。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: Take a look at this <kanji>scene</kanji> and the <kanji>condition</kanji> it’s in. This is the climate of the situation, but more specifically the <vocabulary>business climate</vocabulary>. This word is really only used to talk about the state of business and economic stuff.
Reading Mnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.
