Context 1-EN: It is only in the far away future that Japan’s situation will soar.
Context 1-JP: <jp>日本の景況感が大きく上向くのは、まだまだ先のことだろう。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: It's <kanji>public</kanji> <kanji>establish</kanji>ment. It is <vocabulary>public</vocabulary>.
Reading Mnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.
Context 1-EN: If you travel to Okinawa, you should go to Makishi Public Market.
Context 1-JP: <jp>もし沖縄を旅行するなら、牧志公設市場に行った方がいいよ。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: <kanji>Both</kanji> <kanji>side</kanji>s is <vocabulary>both sides</vocabulary>. Which side? Both sides.
Reading Mnemonic: The first kanji takes the on'yomi reading and the second takes the kun'yomi reading. Luckily you know both of them already!
Context 1-EN: Both of my ears itch immensely.
Context 1-JP: <jp>両側の耳がかゆくてむずむずします。</jp>
Context 2-EN: Two dogs nuzzled against me from both sides.
Context 2-JP: <jp>二ひきの犬が、両側から私に鼻をすりつけてきました。</jp>
Context 3-EN: A picture of Viet, with girls on both sides of him, was sold to the paparazzi.
Context 3-JP: <jp>両側に女の子をはべらせたビエトの写真がパパラッチに売りつけられた。</jp>

Meaning: To Make Sure Of,To Verify,To Confirm,To Make Certain
Meaning Mnemonic: Like with <jp>確か</jp>, which means <kanji>certain</kanji>, this is the verb version of that. So when you "do certain" you are going <vocabulary>to make sure of</vocabulary> something or you're going <vocabulary>to verify</vocabulary> something.
Reading Mnemonic: This one is kun'yomi followed by okurigana. If you remember the reading you learned with <jp>確かに</jp>, you should know this one!
Context 1-EN: You should make sure the door is properly locked.
Context 1-JP: <jp>ちゃんとドアに鍵をかけたかどうか確かめた方がいいですよ。</jp>

Meaning: To Provide,To Furnish,To Equip,To Prepare For
Meaning Mnemonic: Because the hiragana ends with an <jp>う</jp> sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means <kanji>provide</kanji> so the verb vocab version is <vocabulary>to provide</vocabulary>.
Reading Mnemonic: Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. You didn't learn that reading with this kanji, so here's a mnemonic to help you: You have <vocabulary>to provide</vocabulary> your friends with their own <reading>sauna</reading> (<jp>そな</jp>) because they don't want to use your shower. This requires you to go out and buy a sauna for your house (very expensive) just so you can provide your needy friends with what they want (a sauna). Feel angry you have to provide this.
Context 1-EN: Brace yourself and prepare for your opponent’s attack!
Context 1-JP: <jp>気持ちを引き締めて敵の攻撃に備えろ！</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: What's <kanji>below</kanji> your <kanji>shoes</kanji>? Your <vocabulary>socks</vocabulary>.
Reading Mnemonic: This word uses the kun'yomi readings for both kanji. You've learned them already, so you should be able to read this word too!
Context 1-EN: I tried to reach the top shelf to get a pair of pink socks, but I wasn’t tall enough.
Context 1-JP: <jp>ピンクの靴下を取ろうと一番上の棚に手を伸ばしたが、背丈が足りずに届かなかった。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.
Reading Mnemonic: The reading is the same as the one you learned with the kanji, no extra salt needed.
Context 1-EN: It might be better with a little more salt.
Context 1-JP: <jp>もう少し塩が多い方が良いかもしれませんね。</jp>
Context 2-EN: Until your baby turns one, you shouldn't give them any salt.
Context 2-JP: <jp>一才になるまで赤ちゃんには塩をあげない方がいいですよ。</jp>
Context 3-EN: Oh my God! I can’t believe you could be so stupid! Switching the salt and the sugar is not funny at all, even if it’s April Fool’s Day today. You are the fool!
Context 3-JP: <jp>けしからん！一体どうやってそんなに馬鹿なことが出来るんだ？砂糖と塩を入れ替えるなんて、いくら今日がエイプリルフールだからといっても、ちっともおもしろくないぞ。馬鹿！ </jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: If you're <kanji>anti</kanji> <kanji>conserve</kanji>, I'm going to ask you to do some heavy <vocabulary>reconsideration</vocabulary> and <vocabulary>reflection</vocabulary>, and see if that's really the right way to be. Think long and hard, okay?
Reading Mnemonic:
The reading for <jp>反</jp> is all good. The reading for <jp>省</jp> is an on'yomi reading you haven't seen yet. Here's a mnemonic:

I'm standing in front of you, forcing a <vocabulary>reconsideration</vocabulary> of your anti conserve stance, with my <reading>sa</reading>ber (<jp>せい</jp>) to your throat. I better see some reflection on your face or you won't have one in a second.
Context 1-EN: I’ve been reflecting on it, so please don’t be so hard on me.
Context 1-JP: <jp>反省しているので、そんなにきつく当たらないでください。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: A <kanji>noun</kanji> (<jp>名詞</jp>) that <kanji>has</kanji> <kanji>hard</kanji>ness is a noun that can't be budged. It's a big noun, so big that you have to capitalize these kinds of nouns in English. It is a <vocabulary>proper noun</vocabulary>.
Reading Mnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well. It will help to know the word <jp>名詞</jp> as well.
Context 1-EN: You can’t use proper nouns in the game Shiritori.
Context 1-JP: <jp>しりとりに固有名詞は使えません。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.
Reading Mnemonic: The reading is the same as the on you learned with the kanji. Have a seat and relax.
Context 1-EN: I'm afraid that we request that seated customers please order something from the menu.
Context 1-JP: <jp>おそれ入りますが、お席をご利用されるさいは、メニューから何か一つご注文をお願いします。</jp>
Context 2-EN: Let's put everybody's bags on the seat to the right of me.
Context 2-JP: <jp>私の右側の席にみんなの荷物をおきましょう。</jp>
Context 3-EN: "Excuse me. Could you move over and let me sit down, please?" "I’m sorry, this seat is taken."
Context 3-JP: <jp>「すみませんが、席を詰めて私を座らせてもらえませんか？」「申し訳ないんですが、この席は空いてないんです。」</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: <kanji>Law</kanji>s are <kanji>standard</kanji> in society. You must have <vocabulary>laws</vocabulary> and <vocabulary>regulations</vocabulary> in society.
Reading Mnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.
Context 1-EN: Is there a book about the international laws concerning naval hostility in this library?
Context 1-JP: <jp>海戦に関する国際法規について書かれた本は、この図書館にありますか。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: This <kanji>shinto shrine</kanji> you're staying at? Turns out you go inside and it is magically turned into this amazing <vocabulary>palace</vocabulary>. Wow! I'm totally becoming a Shinto monk.
Reading Mnemonic: The reading is the same as the kanji reading you learned.
Context 1-EN: My husband is so busy with the imperial court service that I haven’t seen him for four weeks.
Context 1-JP: <jp>主人は宮仕えでとても忙しくしており、私は四週間も顔も見ていません。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: The <kanji>superior</kanji> person <kanji>win</kanji>s. They will win the <vocabulary>championship</vocabulary> and be able to claim <vocabulary>victory</vocabulary> over all others.
Reading Mnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.
Context 1-EN: Although the Giants got their butts kicked big time last year, they won the championship this year.
Context 1-JP: <jp>ジャイアンツは去年はボロ負けだったが、今年はリーグ優勝を果たした。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: Go ahead and <kanji>present</kanji> then <kanji>exit</kanji>. This will be your <vocabulary>presentation</vocabulary> of the materials.
Reading Mnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.
Context 1-EN: Could you tell me what a Tofugu writer applicant needs to submit and what skills are required?
Context 1-JP: <jp>トフグライターへの応募者の提出物について教えて頂けますか？また、必要なスキルは何ですか？</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.
Reading Mnemonic: This vocab uses the same reading as the one you learned with the kanji. Well played!
Context 1-EN: There’s gum stuck to the bottom of your shoe.
Context 1-JP: <jp>くつの底にガムがついてるよ。</jp>
Context 2-EN: It's ridiculous to go swimming in the bottomless swamp.
Context 2-JP: <jp>底無しぬまに泳ぎに行くなんて、無茶だよ。</jp>
Context 3-EN: Thanks to Tofugu, I'm now fluent in Japanese. I thank them from the bottom of my heart.
Context 3-JP: <jp>トーフグのお陰で、日本語がペラペラになりました。心の底から感謝しています。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: <kanji>Each</kanji> <kanji>self</kanji> refers to <vocabulary>each person</vocabulary> or <vocabulary>individual</vocabulary>.
Reading Mnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.
Context 1-EN: You need to bring your own bento box, snacks, and water bottle for the school trip.
Context 1-JP: <jp>遠足には、各自お弁当とお菓子、水筒を持参してください。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: This is where the <kanji>bus</kanji> (<jp>バス</jp>) halts. It's the <vocabulary>bus stop</vocabulary>.
Reading Mnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.
Context 1-EN: Is this bus going to stop at the bus stop? Hey, is this bus going to stop at the bus stop!? Yo, bus driver! Are you deaf?
Context 1-JP: <jp>このバス、あのバス停で止まるのか？おい、このバス、あのバス停で止まるのかって聞いてんだよ！バスの運転手さんよお！お前、耳が聞こえねえのか！</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: A <kanji>lowly</kanji> person who <kanji>yield</kanji>s to everyone is really <vocabulary>subservient</vocabulary>. They'll do everything people tell them because they don't have the nerves to speak up and just say no.
Reading Mnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.
Context 1-EN: Why do you immediately become subservient?
Context 1-JP: <jp>どうしてすぐに卑屈になるの？</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.
Reading Mnemonic:
Since this word is made up of a single kanji, it probably uses the kun'yomi reading. You did not learn this reading, so here's a mnemonic to help you to remember: 

<vocabulary>Demon</vocabulary>s are mean. This particular demon bites you on the knee, creating an "O" shape on your knee. He tells you he has cursed you with the <vocabulary>"O" knee</vocabulary> (<jp>おに</jp>).
Context 1-EN: Hey! Stop this weak act and show us your true form, you demon!
Context 1-JP: <jp>おい！下手な芝居はやめて正体を現せ！この、鬼め！</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: A <kanji>quality</kanji> <kanji>problem</kanji> is worth a <vocabulary>question</vocabulary>. A low quality problem however... don't ask the question. There are stupid questions, after all.
Reading Mnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.
Context 1-EN: He flinched at the unexpected question from an audience member.
Context 1-JP: <jp>彼はある観客からの予想外の質問にたじろいだ。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: See this on the end of a word, and you know that it is a ______<kanji>symptom</kanji>. When you have a _____symptom, you have some kind of <vocabulary>disease</vocabulary> or <vocabulary>sickness</vocabulary> (otherwise why would you have a symptom of some kind?).
Reading Mnemonic: Since this is attached to things, it's treated like a jukugo word, so the on'yomi reading is used here.
Context 1-EN: I should consult a doctor about my wife’s neurotic hysteria.
Context 1-JP: <jp>妻の神経性ヒステリー症について、医者に相談しなくてはいけません。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: <kanji>Write down</kanji> a <kanji>record</kanji> of the events so we have a <vocabulary>record</vocabulary>, please. Don't want people to forget about this momentous occasion, when King Felix got his perfect game.
Reading Mnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.
Context 1-EN: She set the world record for the person thrown farthest by a motorcycle accident.
Context 1-JP: <jp>彼女は、バイク事故で投げ飛ばされる飛距離の世界記録を樹立した。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: Because the hiragana ends with an <jp>う</jp> sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means <kanji>alive</kanji> and the verb version means <vocabulary>to exist</vocabulary> or <vocabulary>to be</vocabulary>, for anything that is alive and moving, like people and animals.
Reading Mnemonic: Do you know the word <jp>いる</jp>? This is the kanji version! If you've been studying Japanese up to this point you probably already know that word. You can associate these two things together into one and remember the reading at the same time!
Context 1-EN: Our cat is usually in our bedroom upstairs.
Context 1-JP: <jp>うちの猫は大抵二階の寝室に居るんです。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: The people who <kanji>exit</kanji> their <kanji>seat</kanji>s at the end of the show are the number of people who showed up, not counting empty seats. This is the true <vocabulary>attendance</vocabulary>.
Reading Mnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well. Just note the <jp>しゅつ</jp> gets changed to <jp>しゅっ</jp>, as many <jp>つ</jp>s do in this situation.
Context 1-EN: I'm afraid that my attendance will probably be irregular.
Context 1-JP: <jp>申しわけありませんが、出席は不定期になると思います。</jp>
Context 2-EN: I'm not planning to attend Koichi's birthday party.
Context 2-JP: <jp>コウイチのたん生日パーティーには、出席しない予定です。</jp>
Context 3-EN: Could you put me on another flight? I really have to attend the annual G8 leaders summit.
Context 3-JP: <jp>別の便に乗せていただけますか？どうしても、主要国首脳会議に出席しなくてはならないんです。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: Your <kanji>present</kanji> <kanji>location</kanji> is the <vocabulary>scene</vocabulary> of the crime! And you're on the scene to check out what's currently going on.
Reading Mnemonic: The reading is a combination of the on'yomi and kun'yomi readings. That being said, both readings for both kanji are the readings you learned already, so you should be able to read this.
Context 1-EN: Let’s hope that what actually happened at the scene of the crime will come to light soon.
Context 1-JP: <jp>あの犯罪現場で実際に何が起きたのかがすぐに明るみに出ることを期待しよう。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: The <kanji>failure</kanji> <kanji>someone</kanji> (person) is the <vocabulary>loser</vocabulary> or <vocabulary>the defeated</vocabulary>.
Reading Mnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.
Context 1-EN: We still have a consolation match left for the defeated.
Context 1-JP: <jp>まだ敗者ふっ活戦が残っていますよ。</jp>
Context 2-EN: That dentist was born to be a loser.
Context 2-JP: <jp>その歯医者は、生まれながらの敗者であった。</jp>
Context 3-EN: Whenever you watch sports, you identify with the underdog that tried their best. Is that fun? Do you feel like you achieve something? What’s the point? No point, right? You have to change yourself from a loser to a winner.
Context 3-JP: <jp>スポーツを見るとき、全力を尽くした負け犬と自分を重ね合わせてみなよ。それって楽しい？達成感はある？何か意味はあるの？意味無いよね？敗者から勝者に生まれ変わらなきゃ。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: Because the hiragana ends with an <jp>う</jp> sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means <kanji>suck</kanji> so the verb vocab version is <vocabulary>to suck</vocabulary>, but it's usually used to talk about what you do to cigarettes, so a better translation I think is <vocabulary>to smoke</vocabulary>.
Reading Mnemonic: Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. You didn't learn that reading with this kanji, so here's a mnemonic to help you: You smoke too much, and that gives you cancer. You decide to <reading>sue</reading> (<jp>す</jp>) the cigarette makers.
Context 1-EN: I’m going to quit smoking once and for all.
Context 1-JP: <jp>これを最後に、きっぱりとタバコを吸うのを止めるつもりなんだ。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: Please <kanji>enter</kanji> what you've <kanji>obtain</kanji>ed in here. We'll divvy it all up later. But we have to enter it all here so we know our <vocabulary>income</vocabulary>.
Reading Mnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.
Context 1-EN: If I take the job overseas, my income will probably be half what it is now.
Context 1-JP: <jp>その海外での仕事に就けば、おそらく収入が半分になるだろう。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: Remember how <jp>時計</jp> is <kanji>watch</kanji>? An <kanji>arm</kanji> is now there too, making this a <vocabulary>wristwatch</vocabulary>.
Reading Mnemonic: The readings are the words <jp>腕</jp> (same reading as what you learned with the kanji) as well as the reading for <jp>時計</jp>. Just don't forget that rendaku!
Context 1-EN: Can we talk about my missing wristwatch for a second? I won’t take up too much of your time.
Context 1-JP: <jp>俺の無くなった腕時計についてちょっと話がしたいんだけど、いいか？あまり時間は取らせないよ。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: When the <kanji>fee</kanji> is <kanji>nothing</kanji> it is <vocabulary>free</vocabulary> and <vocabulary>without charge</vocabulary>!
Reading Mnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.
Context 1-EN: I like walking around eating free samples at Costco.
Context 1-JP: <jp>コストコで無料のサンプルを食べ歩くのが好きです。</jp>
Context 2-EN: WaniKani is available for free until level three.
Context 2-JP: <jp>ワニカニは、レベル三まで無料で利用できます。</jp>
Context 3-EN: I don’t want to be alone for Christmas, have you made plans already? If not, I have two Paul McCartney concert tickets and I could give you one for free.
Context 3-JP: <jp>クリスマス、一人ぼっちで過ごしたくないんだけど、もう予定立てちゃった？もしまだなら、ポール・マッカートニーのチケットが二枚あるんだけど、無料で一枚プレゼントするよ。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: This is like <jp>続く</jp> except for now you're the one doing the continuing. Unfortunately, there's no good way to differentiate the two "continues" using just the meaning, but you can think of it this way: With <jp>ける</jp>, you really <reading>care</reading> about continuing this thing so you are continuing it (doing the action of continuing). With <jp>く</jp> you're just like "that's <reading>coo'</reading> if it continues, but I don't really care...
Reading Mnemonic: The reading is the same as <jp>続く</jp>, so be sure to know that so you can know this.
Context 1-EN: Weekends are awesome because I can continue to sleep all day long.
Context 1-JP: <jp>一日中寝続けられるので、週末は最高だ。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: Because the hiragana ends with an <jp>う</jp> sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means <kanji>give</kanji> so the verb vocab version is <vocabulary>to give</vocabulary> or <vocabulary>to grant</vocabulary>.
Reading Mnemonic:
Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. You didn't learn that reading with this kanji, so here's a mnemonic to help you: 

You go <vocabulary>to give</vocabulary> a bone to your dog. <reading>Atta</reading> (<jp>あた</jp>) boy, Sparky! <reading>Atta</reading> boy.
Context 1-EN: Let me start off by thanking you all for coming and giving me such a great opportunity to show my presentation.
Context 1-JP: <jp>まず初めに、お忙しい中足をお運び頂き誠に有り難うございます。また、このような素晴らしいプレゼンテーションの機会を与えて頂いたことにも、感謝申し上げます。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: If you <kanji>discuss</kanji> the <kanji>suspicious</kanji> you're talking about something that may or may not be real. One of those things you could be discussing is a <vocabulary>ghost story</vocabulary>... you know that one with the hook?
Reading Mnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.
Context 1-EN: Are there any famous school ghost stories in America?
Context 1-JP: <jp>アメリカで有名な学校の怪談はありますか。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: An <kanji>individual</kanji> <kanji>room</kanji> just for you is your own <vocabulary>private room</vocabulary>. How nice!
Reading Mnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.
Context 1-EN: When you have small kids, the existence of izakaya with private rooms is appreciated.
Context 1-JP: <jp>小さい子がいると個室い酒屋の存在はありがたいです。</jp>
Context 2-EN: Koichi's been living in a shared house without his own room for more than five years now.
Context 2-JP: <jp>コウイチはシェアハウスで自分の個室がないという生活をもう五年も続けている。</jp>
Context 3-EN: I reserved a private room for our year-end party.
Context 3-JP: <jp>忘年会に個室を予約しました。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: The <kanji>main</kanji> <kanji>resources</kanji> are the <vocabulary>funds</vocabulary> and <vocabulary>capital</vocabulary> we're getting. Everything else can be gotten using said funds, which is why they're the main resources we have!
Reading Mnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.
Context 1-EN: There’s a reason for the venture capital shortage.
Context 1-JP: <jp>ベンチャー・キャピタル、いわゆる冒険資本が不足するには、わけがあります。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: The <kanji>times</kanji> when you are in <kanji>mourning</kanji> each year are for a loved one's <vocabulary>death anniversary</vocabulary>. They come around again every year. It's important you remember your loved ones at this time.
Reading Mnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.
Context 1-EN: Today is the second anniversary of my grandfather’s death.
Context 1-JP: <jp>今年は祖父の三回忌です。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: Because the hiragana ends with an <jp>う</jp> sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means <kanji>indicate</kanji> so the verb vocab version is <vocabulary>to indicate</vocabulary> or <vocabulary>to show</vocabulary>. This isn't used for "showing" a physical thing, this is more like when "a study shows that ...."
Reading Mnemonic:
Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. You didn't learn that reading with this kanji, so here's a mnemonic to help you: 

Studies seem <vocabulary>to indicate</vocabulary> or <vocabulary>to show</vocabulary> that <reading>She-me</reading>n (<jp>しめ</jp>) are way more powerful than He-men. Just look at how much bigger their swords and biceps are.
Context 1-EN: Don’t promise me anything. Actions speak louder than words.
Context 1-JP: <jp>約束なんてしないで。言葉ではなく行いで示してよ。</jp>

Meaning: To Retire,To Be Retired,To Go Into Retirement
Meaning Mnemonic:
<jp>隠居</jp> is "retirement". Make that a verb and you have <vocabulary>to retire</vocabulary>, <vocabulary>to be retired</vocabulary>, or <vocabulary>to go into retirement</vocabulary>.

Like <jp>隠居</jp>, this word emphasizes life after retiring, and usually implies having a quiet, maybe secluded, lifestyle. It's a bit of an old-fashioned word, but you'll still see it in modern writing.
Reading Mnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.
Context 1-EN: I had some stomach trouble and that forced me to retire.
Context 1-JP: <jp>胃病のせいで、隠居することになりました。</jp>
Context 2-EN: My father is retired in a farming village.
Context 2-JP: <jp>私の父は農村で隠居しています。</jp>
Context 3-EN: I was fed up with my working life, so I decided to sell all my stocks and go into retirement.
Context 3-JP: <jp>社会人生活に嫌気がさしたので、持っている株を全て売って隠居することにしました。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: This is a day of the week. You know this because it has <jp>曜日</jp> in it. But what day of the week is it? The <kanji>fire</kanji> day of the week is the day after the worst day of the week (monday). You set fire to everything because you're so pissed off about yesterday, which makes today <vocabulary>Tuesday</vocabulary>.
Reading Mnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well. It will help to know the word <jp>曜日</jp> as well.
Context 1-EN: On one sunny, Tuesday morning, an old man with a white beard started talking to me while I was watering my flowers.
Context 1-JP: <jp>ある晴れた火曜日の朝、家の花に水やりをしていると、白いひげを生やしたおじいさんに話しかけられました。</jp>
Context 2-EN: I'm sorry, but I am busy next Monday and Tuesday.
Context 2-JP: <jp>すみませんが、来週の月曜日と火曜日はいそがしいんです。</jp>
Context 3-EN: I got owned in baseball on Tuesday.
Context 3-JP: <jp>火曜日は野球でコテンパにやられたよ。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: The <kanji>child</kanji> of a <kanji>judge</kanji> is the thing he puts on his judgements. What does he put on his judgments? His <vocabulary>seal</vocabulary>, you know, to make it all official and stuff.
Reading Mnemonic: <jp>判</jp> is the reading you learned. <jp>子</jp> is the kun'yomi vocab reading, which I bet you know pretty well by now as well. You just have to remember to use it here.
Context 1-EN: This document was officially sealed by Koichi.
Context 1-JP: <jp>この書類には、コウイチによって公的な判子が押されています。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.
Reading Mnemonic: Since this word is made up of a single kanji, it probably uses the kun'yomi reading. You did not learn this reading, so here's a mnemonic to help you to remember: What's that <kanji>figure</kanji> / <kanji>shape</kanji> in the distance? Is that who I think it is? Is that <reading>Sugar To</reading>m (<jp>すがた</jp>)??? You'll have to make up some lore about this "Sugar Tom" but whatever you do be excited about him. He's a dude who gives you tons of sugar, I'm guessing, and you always see him coming from a long ways away because of his Sugar Tom hat, or something like that.
Context 1-EN: I can’t get the image of him smiling at me out of my mind.
Context 1-JP: <jp>彼が私に微笑みかけている姿が頭に焼きついて離れない。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: Go ahead and <kanji>put</kanji> a <kanji>rank</kanji> on something. This one is rank #1, so its <vocabulary>position</vocabulary> is up higher. Then you put a rank #67 on something. That one's position is lower.
Reading Mnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.
Context 1-EN: On your mark, get set, go!
Context 1-JP: <jp>位置について、用意、ドン！</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: Take your <kanji>finger</kanji> and <kanji>lead</kanji> with it. Just point at things. Tell people where they need to go, what they need to do, all with your finger leading them. This is <vocabulary>guidance</vocabulary> you are providing.
Reading Mnemonic: The reading is the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should know them both already!
Context 1-EN: She is a bit careless, but she’s a very good guide.
Context 1-JP: <jp>彼女は不注意ですが、とても頭のいい指導者です。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: This is a word that's attached to other things indicating the <vocabulary>layer of</vocabulary> something (or just <vocabulary>layer</vocabulary>). It has essentially the same meaning as the kanji it comes from, <kanji>layer</kanji>.
Reading Mnemonic: The reading is the reading you learned with the kanji. It's treated like a jukugo reading because it's normally attached to things.
Context 1-EN: Did you know hockey arenas are related to the destruction of the ozone layer?
Context 1-JP: <jp>ホッケーの競技場さえも、オゾン層の破壊に関係しているって、知ってたかい？</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: <kanji>Manag</kanji>ing a <kanji>business</kanji>? That's <vocabulary>business</vocabulary>!
Reading Mnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.
Context 1-EN: I was assigned to Tofugu's sales team.
Context 1-JP: <jp>トーフグの営業チームに配ぞくされました。</jp>
Context 2-EN: The business hours for the Tofugu office are from nine to six PST.
Context 2-JP: <jp>トーフグオフィスの営業時間は西海岸時間で大体朝九時から夕方六時までです。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: A <kanji>demon</kanji> that <kanji>suck</kanji>s <kanji>blood</kanji>? What mythological creature can you think of that sucks blood? How about a <vocabulary>vampire</vocabulary>? Them Sparklzzzz!
Reading Mnemonic: <jp>吸血</jp> should be easy for you to read. The <jp>鬼</jp> part uses the reading you already learned with the kanji, <jp>き</jp>. Easy, no?
Context 1-EN: That vampire told me that he wouldn’t even suck my blood because I am too much of a phony.
Context 1-JP: <jp>あの吸血鬼の野郎、俺の事、血を吸いたくない程インチキ臭すぎるって言うんだ。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: The <kanji>boundary</kanji> separates <kanji>world</kanji>s. It is a <vocabulary>boundary</vocabulary>.
Reading Mnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.
Context 1-EN: My mom and I are always cautious of each other’s personal boundaries.
Context 1-JP: <jp>母と私は、いつもお互いの個人的な境界線のようなものを気にしています。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: The <kanji>original</kanji> <kanji>model</kanji> of something isn't usually very good. It's rough. It's a <vocabulary>prototype</vocabulary>.
Reading Mnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.
Context 1-EN: We usually sculpt a model out of clay at first.
Context 1-JP: <jp>私たちはまず初めに、粘土で彫刻の原型を作るんです。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: A <kanji>military</kanji> <kanji>samurai</kanji> is a <vocabulary>samurai</vocabulary>. This is how most people say "samurai" in Japanese.
Reading Mnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.
Context 1-EN: Koichi kept running as stoically as a samurai and finished the full marathon.
Context 1-JP: <jp>コウイチは武士のようにストイックに走り続け、フルマラソンを完走した。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: Someone takes your <kanji>hand</kanji> and shows you how to <kanji>continue</kanji>. "This is the <vocabulary>procedure</vocabulary>," they say. Move your hand like this. Verrrryyy goood. Good procedure. Good!
Reading Mnemonic: The reading is the kun'yomi vocab readings of <jp>手</jp> and <jp>続く</jp> put together into one. Darn these body parts making everything kun'yomi.
Context 1-EN: Everybody wants to avoid troublesome formalities.
Context 1-JP: <jp>誰だって面倒な手続きは避けたい。</jp>
Context 2-EN: The procedure was very complicated and I got so confused that I didn't know what to do.
Context 2-JP: <jp>手続きがふくざつで、頭が混乱してどうしていいか分からなくなりました。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: When it's <kanji>possible</kanji> to <kanji>separate</kanji> something, it's <vocabulary>divisible</vocabulary>. Just imagine separating things into parts. It's possible. So, if that's possible, it's divisible. Now think of something that's nothing (i.e. "no candy bars"). That is not possible to separate into parts. That is not divisible.
Reading Mnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.
Context 1-EN: The theme of today's Tofugu podcast is the inseparability of life and death.

Context 3-EN: As a general rule, divisible claims, like savings accounts, do not become the target of divisions of inherited property.

Meaning Mnemonic: You can <kanji>blame</kanji> <kanji>duty</kanji> all you want, but you still have a <vocabulary>responsibility</vocabulary> as well, no matter what your duty dictates.

Context 1-JP: <jp>日本のサラリーマンは責任を取る事を嫌がる傾向にある。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: The <kanji>standard</kanji> of <kanji>standard</kanji>s is the main <vocabulary>standard</vocabulary> we work off of.

Context 1-JP: <jp>彼は世間の規準からはちょっと外れた、ユニークな人です。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic:
<kanji>News</kanji> that you <kanji>announce</kanji> becomes a <vocabulary>report</vocabulary>. When someone announces news on a topic, they are giving you a report on the <vocabulary>information</vocabulary>.

<jp>報告</jp> is a report given by someone after they've done some investigation or research into the topic. It can be used for class presentations on a topic or a report given to your boss. This differs from <jp>報道</jp>, which is a report released by news organizations.
Reading Mnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.
Context 1-EN: Shouldn't we report this to Koichi?
Context 1-JP: <jp>コウイチに報告した方がいいんじゃない？</jp>
Context 2-EN: Koichi gave an oral report of Tofugu's annual report for the workers.
Context 2-JP: <jp>コウイチは、トーフグの年次報告を、社員たちに口頭で報告しました。</jp>
Context 3-EN: I’m thinking about the funniest way to inform my boyfriend that I’m pregnant so that he won’t run away from me.
Context 3-JP: <jp>彼が逃げ出さないように、めちゃくちゃ面白い妊娠の報告方法を考えているの。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.
Reading Mnemonic: The reading you learned with the kanji is the same as the reading for this word. No <vocabulary>hole</vocabulary>s in your knowledge!
Context 1-EN: I am so embarrassed, I wished I could sink into the floor!
Context 1-JP: <jp>はずかしくて、穴があったら入りたいよ！</jp>
Context 2-EN: I heard that bats are living in the cave.

Context 3-EN: He has the natural ability to dig deep, magnificent holes.
Context 3-JP: <jp>彼が深くて素晴らしい穴を掘れるのは、持って生まれた才能です。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: <kanji>Self</kanji> <kanji>control</kanji> is <vocabulary>self control</vocabulary> and <vocabulary>self restraint</vocabulary>. Have some!
Reading Mnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

Context 1-JP: <jp>私としては、断然フランボワイヤン様式の方が良かったんですが、そこはまぁ自制しています。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: When you can <kanji>look at</kanji> things that are <kanji>near</kanji> well but you can't see things far away, you have <vocabulary>nearsightedness</vocabulary>. Good to get those eyes checked out occasionally.
Reading Mnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

Context 1-JP: <jp>私は近視と乱視の両方があります。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: Because the hiragana ends with an <jp>う</jp> sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means <kanji>extract</kanji> so the verb vocab version is <vocabulary>to extract</vocabulary>.
Reading Mnemonic: The reading is the same as the one you learned with the kanji. Just go ahead and extract it out of your memory so you can use it here.

Context 1-JP: <jp>ワサビ抜きにしてもらえますか？</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: When you <kanji>transmit</kanji> something that <kanji>unite</kanji>s the people, you are probably pulling on <vocabulary>tradition</vocabulary>. Tradition is what unites us all and transmits who we are to everyone else. What is your <jp>伝統</jp>?
Reading Mnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

Context 1-JP: <jp>あの日本の伝統衣装の名前って何だっけ？単語をすっかり忘れちゃったよ。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: Quite the <kanji>scene</kanji>, this <kanji>view</kanji> is. What you're looking at is called <vocabulary>scenery</vocabulary>. And, in fact, it's a <vocabulary>spectacular view</vocabulary>!
Reading Mnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

Reading Mnemonic: The readings are the ones you learned with the kanji.

Meaning: To Run A Business,To Manage A Business
Meaning Mnemonic: The kanji means <kanji>manage</kanji>, but when you manage something, what are you usually managing? How about a business? So this word means <vocabulary>to run a business</vocabulary> even though the kanji is manage.
Reading Mnemonic: Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. You didn't learn that reading with this kanji, so here's a mnemonic to help you: You have <vocabulary>to run a business</vocabulary>. Your business is to make people eat who don't want to eat. "HEY, YOU <reading>EAT NO</reading>W!" (<jp>いとな</jp>).
Context 1-EN: My parents run a massage therapy business, so I can get 'all-you-can-take-massages' at home.
Context 1-JP: <jp>私の両親はマッサージ業を営んでいるので、私はそこで「マッサージ受け放題」なんです。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: <kanji>Create</kanji>! <kanji>Create</kanji>! If you do this, you are doing <vocabulary>creation</vocabulary>.
Reading Mnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.
Context 1-EN: My little sister is very creative.
Context 1-JP: <jp>私の妹は、創造力がとても豊かだ。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: Remember <jp>頑張る</jp>? This is just another form of that, this time you're telling someone to <jp>頑張る</jp>, making this word mean something along the lines of <vocabulary>good luck</vocabulary> or <vocabulary>do your best</vocabulary>! Speaking of which, <jp>頑張れ</jp>, you!
Reading Mnemonic: The reading comes from <jp>頑張る</jp>.
Context 1-EN: Well, don’t worry about the results, just try your best!
Context 1-JP: <jp>まあ、結果を気にせずに、頑張れよ！</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: This is the <kanji>way</kanji> of <kanji>writing</kanji> (kind of like how <jp>見方</jp> is the way of seeing). A better way to say this though would be to call it <vocabulary>penmanship</vocabulary>, though. How's your <jp>書き方</jp>? Mine is terrible.

Meaning Mnemonic: The <kanji>condition</kanji> that something is in and the <kanji>appearance</kanji> of it is the <vocabulary>condition</vocabulary> / <vocabulary>state</vocabulary> of that object.
Reading Mnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

Meaning Mnemonic: Something that <kanji>obstruct</kanji>s and also does <kanji>damage</kanji> is an <vocabulary>obstruction</vocabulary>. No obstruction is ever good and if left too long it really will cause damage and <vocabulary>interference</vocabulary> as well.
Reading Mnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

Meaning Mnemonic: We're <kanji>cut</kanji> right down to the end, reaching that <kanji>urge</kanji> position where <vocabulary>urgency</vocabulary> and <vocabulary>pressure</vocabulary> are so strong.

Meaning Mnemonic: The <kanji>soil</kanji> that makes up your <kanji>territory</kanji> is your <vocabulary>territory</vocabulary>. Ain't nobody goin' set foot on my soil nuh'uh.

Reading Mnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

Meaning Mnemonic: A <kanji>person</kanji> who has "<kanji>attain</kanji>ed" is someone who knows much. He/She is a <vocabulary>master</vocabulary> or <vocabulary>expert</vocabulary>, obviously.

Meaning Mnemonic: <kanji>Ten thousand</kanji> <kanji>years old</kanji>! That's a lot of time. This is the word for the turned-English Japanese phrase, <vocabulary>banzai</vocabulary>!

Meaning Mnemonic: To <kanji>preserve</kanji> and <kanji>defend</kanji> something is <vocabulary>to conserve</vocabulary> and <vocabulary>to protect</vocabulary>. I won't let you destroy this land I'm trying <vocabulary>to protect</vocabulary>!

Meaning Mnemonic: Let's <kanji>depart</kanji> from this place and <kanji>expand</kanji> it out. To do that we'll have <vocabulary>to develop</vocabulary> it.

Context 1-JP: <jp>年寄りの風邪は肺炎に発展しやすいんだよ。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: The <kanji>circumstance</kanji> is that the thing you're using is a <kanji>hinder</kanji>ance. Usually it's a help, but now it's <vocabulary>out of order</vocabulary> and has a <vocabulary>malfunction</vocabulary>.
Reading Mnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.
Context 1-EN: That fax machine is out of order.
Context 1-JP: <jp>あのファックス機は故障中だよ。</jp>

Meaning: End Of The Year,Year End Gift,End Of Year Gift
Meaning Mnemonic: <kanji>Years old</kanji> of <kanji>livelihood</kanji>. This is each year of livelihood that you have, and at the end of each year you've reached the <vocabulary>end of the year</vocabulary>. This may also refer to a <vocabulary>year end gift</vocabulary>.
Reading Mnemonic: You've learned this reading, but it might not be the one you were expecting. It's <jp>せい</jp>, like the <reading>sa</reading>ber you use to cut down the old year before starting the new one.
Context 1-EN: Are you sure you have the proper year-end gift for your boss?
Context 1-JP: <jp>本当にちゃんと上司へのお歳暮持ったの？</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: <kanji>Divide</kanji> then <kanji>join</kanji> something back together. When you join it back together, it won't be whole again, but you can see the two parts you divided apart. You can also compare them and see which is bigger and by how much. You can easily find the <vocabulary>ratio</vocabulary> this way, too.
Reading Mnemonic: This word uses the kun'yomi readings for both kanji. You've learned them both already, so you should be able to read this already!
Context 1-EN: In Japan, noodles that contain one hundred percent buckwheat flour are called Juwari-soba.
Context 1-JP: <jp>日本では、蕎麦粉の割合が100%の蕎麦を十割り蕎麦と呼びます。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.
Reading Mnemonic:
Since this word is made up of a single kanji, it probably uses the kun'yomi reading. You did not learn this reading, so here's a mnemonic to help you remember: 

When you cut the tree down to produce a <vocabulary>tree trunk</vocabulary>, out jumps <reading>Mickey</reading> Mouse. "WHY YOU CUT DOWN MY TREE BRO?" he yells. I'm Mickey Mouse and I don't stand for this.
Context 1-EN: You should remove the ivy winding around the tree trunk.
Context 1-JP: <jp>木の幹に絡まっているツタを取り除いた方がいいよ。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: A <kanji>child</kanji> that's <kanji>astray</kanji> is a <vocabulary>lost child</vocabulary>. Help them home, don't invite them into your windowless van, please.
Reading Mnemonic: The reading for <jp>迷</jp> is an exceptional reading. The <jp>ご</jp> comes from <jp>こ</jp>. Think of the <jp>まい</jp> as the child asking: "Where is <reading>my</reading> (<jp>まい</jp>) mommy???"
Context 1-EN: I was just trying to find the parents of a lost child, but I was accused of attempted kidnapping.
Context 1-JP: <jp>迷子の子どもの両親を探してあげようとしていただけなのに、誘拐未遂で起訴されてしまいました。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: When something is moving towards <kanji>emergency</kanji> (<jp>非常</jp>), it is something that is <vocabulary>very</vocabulary>, <vocabulary>extremely</vocabulary> bad. Like, <vocabulary>exceedingly</vocabulary> so. It's nuts.
Reading Mnemonic: The reading comes straight from the word <jp>非常</jp>, which you hopefully know okay by now!
Context 1-EN: Strawberries are out of season now, so they are very expensive.
Context 1-JP: <jp>イチゴは今季節外れなので、非常に高いんです。</jp>
Context 2-EN: The tongue is an exceedingly important speech organ.
Context 2-JP: <jp>舌は非常に重要な発声器官です。</jp>
Context 3-EN: President Koichi’s approval ratings are extremely high.
Context 3-JP: <jp>コウイチ大統領の支持率は非常に高い。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: A <kanji>riot</kanji> of <kanji>war</kanji> is where things go nuts. This is a <vocabulary>melee</vocabulary>! A <vocabulary>free for all</vocabulary>!
Reading Mnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.
Context 1-EN: That game was a free for all that we don't see very often.
Context 1-JP: <jp>あの試合はまれに見る乱戦だった。</jp>
Context 2-EN: A melee occurred in the audience due to Koichi's speech.
Context 2-JP: <jp>コウイチのスピーチのせいでかん客の間に乱戦が起こってしまった。</jp>
Context 3-EN: On the first day of the sale, the mall became super crowded, like it was some kind of battle royal.
Context 3-JP: <jp>セール初日、モールは人でごった返しになり、まるで大乱戦のようだった。</jp>

Meaning: Book Counter,Counter For Books,Books,Counter for Volumes
Meaning Mnemonic: The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.
Reading Mnemonic: The reading is the same as well. It's probably treated like on'yomi jukugo because it's attached to things (like numbers!).
Context 1-EN: The city library has over 33,300 volumes.
Context 1-JP: <jp>市立図書館には、三万三千三百冊以上のぞう書があります。</jp>
Context 2-EN: I wanted to give the book to my friends too, so I bought ten copies.
Context 2-JP: <jp>友達にもあげたかったので、その本を十冊買いました。</jp>
Context 3-EN: Excuse me, I’m having trouble hearing you. Did you say how many Japanese textbooks you want?
Context 3-JP: <jp>すみません、ちょっとお声が遠いようなのですが。日本語の教科書が何冊いるとおっしゃいましたか？</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: <kanji>Years old</kanji> you have <kanji>enter</kanji>ed. These are your yearly (years old) amounts of money you've entered into the coffers. These are the <vocabulary>annual revenue</vocabulary>.
Reading Mnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.
Context 1-EN: Does every government have a special revenue fund?
Context 1-JP: <jp>どの政府にも、特別歳入基金はあるものなのですか。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: You're <kanji>distressed</kanji> and it's <kanji>difficult</kanji>. This is quite the <vocabulary>hardship</vocabulary> you're feeling.
Reading Mnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.
Context 1-EN: It'll be hard to make up for the big losses Fugu made by the end of the year.
Context 1-JP: <jp>フグがちょうぼにあけた大穴を今年度中に埋めるのは困難でしょう。</jp>
Context 2-EN: When I face a hard task, I get excited.
Context 2-JP: <jp>困難な仕事に直面すると、ワクワクするんです。</jp>
Context 3-EN: My grandmother has difficulty walking, so I have to help her go shopping today.
Context 3-JP: <jp>私の祖母は歩くのが困難なので、今日は買い物に行くのを手伝ってあげないといけません。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: The <kanji>police</kanji> (<jp>警察</jp>) <kanji>government</kanji> is full of <vocabulary>police officer</vocabulary>s. This is the formal way to say "police officer." It is similar to <jp>警官</jp>, but has a slightly more official feel to it.
Reading Mnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.
Context 1-EN: When the police officer found the suspect, he was painting a beautiful landscape on a hilltop.
Context 1-JP: <jp>警察官が容疑者を発見した際、男は丘の上で美しい風景画を描いていました。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: A <kanji>tribe</kanji> that <kanji>runs wild</kanji> (<jp>暴走</jp>) is what the Japanese call a <vocabulary>biker gang</vocabulary>. Just imagine them riding around on their bikes, running wild. They're also close, like a family. How nice!
Reading Mnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.
Context 1-EN: Mr. Viet, I would be grateful if you could reply as soon as possible about your time spent in a biker gang.
Context 1-JP: <jp>ビエトさん、あなたが暴走族をしていた頃のエピソードについて、早急にお返事いただけると幸いです。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: Remember how <jp>増える</jp> is "to increase" (as in, something just increases, you aren't doing the increasing yourself). This one is that one, where you're doing the increasing. So, this word means <vocabulary>to increase something</vocabulary>. You know you're doing the increasing because you said "yes" (<jp>やす</jp>) to increasing something, and did it yourself.
Reading Mnemonic: The reading is the same like <jp>増える</jp>. If you know that vocab word you probably can read this one as well.
Context 1-EN: I save all my homework for the weekend so I can spend more time with my family on weekdays.
Context 1-JP: <jp>平日に家族と過ごす時間を増やすために、宿題は全部週末にやることにしてるんだ。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: A <kanji>group</kanji> that has <kanji>collect</kanji>ed together is a bunch of people. It is a <vocabulary>group</vocabulary> or <vocabulary>crowd</vocabulary>.
Reading Mnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.
Context 1-EN: I'm not good at acting in a group.
Context 1-JP: <jp>集団で行動するのが苦手なんです。</jp>
Context 2-EN: If you go to that country, you have to be careful about terrorist groups.
Context 2-JP: <jp>その国に行くなら、テロリスト集団に気をつけなくちゃいけませんよ。</jp>
Context 3-EN: Koichi broke out ahead of the crowd at the end of the race and won the Honolulu Marathon.
Context 3-JP: <jp>コウイチは終盤で集団を抜け出し、ホノルルマラソンで優勝した。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: A <kanji>part of speech</kanji> that creates the <kanji>shape</kanji> and <kanji>form</kanji> of a word is something that is descriptive (its shape and form are in there, after all!). This shape and form part of speech is an <vocabulary>adjective</vocabulary>. You are so beautiful!
Reading Mnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.
Context 1-EN: Adjectives can be separated into three categories: na-adjectives, i-adjectives, and no-adjectives.
Context 1-JP: <jp>形容詞は、な形容詞、い形容詞、の形容詞の三つに分けられます。</jp>
Context 2-EN: I can't come up with a good adjective that can depict this situation well.
Context 2-JP: <jp>このシチュエーションにぴったりのいい形容詞が思いつきません。</jp>
Context 3-EN: At the job interview, I had to choose the most suitable adjective to describe myself, and explain why.
Context 3-JP: <jp>その面接試験で、自分を表現するのに最も適した形容詞を選んで、その理由を説明しなくちゃいけなかったんだ。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: Your <kanji>wealth</kanji> <kanji>cloth</kanji> is your <vocabulary>wallet</vocabulary>. Really, a wallet is just a piece of cloth you keep in your pocket that has your wealth in it, right? This can also be your <vocabulary>purse</vocabulary>, especially if you live in the ol' UK.
Reading Mnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.
Context 1-EN: I forgot my wallet at home, but that saved me ten dollars.
Context 1-JP: <jp>財布を家に忘れたおかげで、十ドル得をしました。</jp>
Context 2-EN: My mother follows fengshui and replaces her purse every year.
Context 2-JP: <jp>母は風水の教えにしたがって、毎年財布を買いかえています。</jp>
Context 3-EN: "Hold up! You dropped your wallet!" "Thank you, but what would you do if I said I dropped it on purpose?"
Context 3-JP: <jp>「ちょっと待って。財布を落としましたよ！」「ありがとう。でも、もし私がわざと落としたって言ったら、どうしますか？」</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: In the <kanji>present time</kanji> we <kanji>exist</kanji>. What time is it? It's <vocabulary>present</vocabulary> and <vocabulary>now</vocabulary>. It is the <vocabulary>current</vocabulary> time!
Reading Mnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.
Context 1-EN: How many emails are you getting a day now?
Context 1-JP: <jp>現在一日に何件のEmailを受信しますか？</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: You know that <jp>参加</jp> is <kanji>participation</kanji>, so <kanji>someone</kanji> who does participation is a <vocabulary>participant</vocabulary>.
Reading Mnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.
Context 1-EN: Surprisingly, the oldest participant of the moviegoer party was 100 years old.
Context 1-JP: <jp>映画好きのパーティーの最年長参加者は、なんと百歳だった。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: A <kanji>scene</kanji> that's as awesome and bright as <kanji>sunlight</kanji> is quite the <vocabulary>spectacle</vocabulary>.
Reading Mnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.
Context 1-EN: I’ve never seen such a beautiful sight before.
Context 1-JP: <jp>このような絵のように美しい光景は今までみたことがありません。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: I'm going to <kanji>express</kanji> my <kanji>departure</kanji>. That is my only <vocabulary>announcement</vocabulary>.
Reading Mnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well. The <jp>ひょう</jp> changes to <jp>ぴょう</jp> and the <jp>はつ</jp> gets shortened, though, so just about everything about this word is weird.
Context 1-EN: This evening there will be an important announcement from Koichi.
Context 1-JP: <jp>今夜、コウイチから、重大な発表があります。</jp>
Context 2-EN: Pikachu announced his retirement from Pokemon this morning.
Context 2-JP: <jp>ピカチュウは、今朝、ポケモンから引たいすることを発表した。</jp>
Context 3-EN: I'm nervous because I have to give a presentation about my social media research outcome in front of everyone tomorrow.
Context 3-JP: <jp>明日、みんなの前でSNSの研究成果について発表をしなければならないので、緊張しています。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: <kanji>Prohibition</kanji> of something with a punishment so serious that you'll end up in <kanji>mourning</kanji> after is a <vocabulary>taboo</vocabulary>.
Reading Mnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.
Context 1-EN: It’s often said that your hands and feet are plucked off when you commit a taboo, is that true?
Context 1-JP: <jp>よく、禁忌を犯すと手足をもがれると言われますが、これは本当でしょうか。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: The kanji and the word are almost exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well. This word also means <vocabulary>mountain stream</vocabulary>. Think of it this way, the water for a <vocabulary>swamp</vocabulary> has to come from somewhere right? It starts out up in the mountains and drains out into a swamp in the valley. The life cycle of a mountain stream into a swamp!
Reading Mnemonic: Since this word is made up of a single kanji, it probably uses the kun'yomi reading. You did not learn this reading, so here's a mnemonic to help you to remember: The beginning of the word <vocabulary>swamp</vocabulary> is actually pretty similar to this word's reading. <jp>さわ</jp> = "swa"? I'd say it's close enough to make a mnemonic out of in your head.
Context 1-EN: I saw a gigantic alligator near a swamp in Florida.
Context 1-JP: <jp>フロリダのとある沢のほとりで、巨大なワニを見ました。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: The <kanji>before</kanji> <kanji>time</kanji> was <vocabulary>last time</vocabulary> or the <vocabulary>previous time</vocabulary>
Reading Mnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.
Context 1-EN: Last class we dissected a frog.
Context 1-JP: <jp>前回のじゅぎょうでは、カエルのかいぼうをしました。</jp>
Context 2-EN: Okay so... we will continue from where we ended last time.
Context 2-JP: <jp>それでは、前回のつづきからはじめたいと思います。</jp>
Context 3-EN: Did you guys review the last lesson at home properly?
Context 3-JP: <jp>前回のレッスンの復習は家でちゃんとやってきましたか？</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: We waited an <kanji>interval of time</kanji>, and at each interval it was <kanji>different</kanji>. They're all supposed to be the same. Is there some kind of <vocabulary>mistake</vocabulary>?
Reading Mnemonic: Take the reading of <jp>間</jp> (<jp>ま</jp> from <jp>間に合う</jp>) and <jp>違う</jp> and you'll have the reading for this word too.
Context 1-EN: Expanding into new markets was not a mistake.
Context 1-JP: <jp>新しい市場に参入したことは間違いじゃなかった。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: Something that <kanji>prevent</kanji>s <kanji>water</kanji> is <vocabulary>waterproof</vocabulary> and <vocabulary>watertight</vocabulary>. Time to take a bath with my <jp>防水</jp> cell phone...
Reading Mnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.
Context 1-EN: All the victims of the flood said they wished they'd had waterproof furniture.
Context 1-JP: <jp>水害被災者達は、防水の家具をそろえておけばよかったと口をそろえて言いました。</jp>
Context 2-EN: If you want it to be 100% watertight, you have to use this.
Context 2-JP: <jp>完全防水するには、これを使うしかないよ。</jp>
Context 3-EN: These waterproof boots are far from being waterproof. My feet got soaking wet from just walking around here.
Context 3-JP: <jp>この防水ブーツ、防水されているとはとても言えないな。この辺りを歩いてるだけで、足がビショビショになっちゃったよ。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: An <kanji>undress</kanji>ed <kanji>letter</kanji> is one that's missing. It's an <vocabulary>omitted character</vocabulary> or <vocabulary>omitted word</vocabulary>.
Reading Mnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.
Context 1-EN: Don’t be afraid to let me know if you find misspelled or missing words, please.
Context 1-JP: <jp>誤字脱字を見つけたら、遠慮せずに教えてくださいね。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: The things <kanji>related</kanji> to your <kanji>heart</kanji> are the things that <vocabulary>concern</vocabulary> and <vocabulary>interest</vocabulary> you the most.
Reading Mnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.
Context 1-EN: I like Japanese anime voice actors but I have no interest in foreign ones.
Context 1-JP: <jp>日本のアニメの声ゆうは好きですが、海外のアニメの声ゆうには関心がありません。</jp>
Context 2-EN: What is your greatest concern at the moment?
Context 2-JP: <jp>げんざいの最大の関心は何ですか？</jp>
Context 3-EN: Thank you for your interest in our company, Tofugu, and our products.
Context 3-JP: <jp>当社トーフグ、ならびに当社製品に関心をお寄せいただき、有難うございます。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: When you look at something <kanji>versus</kanji> something else, you <kanji>compare</kanji> them with one another. You look at the <vocabulary>contrast</vocabulary> between them and make a <vocabulary>comparison</vocabulary>.
Reading Mnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.
Context 1-EN: The fisherman compared the two fish.
Context 1-JP: <jp>りょうしは、二ひきの魚を対比してみました。</jp>
Context 2-EN: Japanese life and American life aren't a good comparison.
Context 2-JP: <jp>日本の生活とアメリカの生活じゃ、いい対比にならないよ。</jp>
Context 3-EN: Who took the picture of Koichi’s nose? I really love the contrast between the light and the shadows.
Context 3-JP: <jp>誰がコウイチの鼻の写真を撮ったの？その光と影の対比がすごく好きなんだけど。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic:
You <kanji>hide</kanji> away but you're <kanji>alive</kanji>. You've lived your life, so now it's time to hide and enjoy your <vocabulary>retirement</vocabulary> by making your <vocabulary>retreat</vocabulary> from working life.

This word refers to life after someone retires, and usually implies being retired from active life and having a quiet, maybe even secluded, lifestyle. It can also imply handing over the reins to your successors. The word is a little old-fashioned, but you'll still see it in modern writing.
Reading Mnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.
Context 1-EN: My father has been enjoying his retirement.
Context 1-JP: <jp>私の父は隠居生活をエンジョイしていますよ。</jp>
Context 2-EN: This village used to be a popular place for retreats.
Context 2-JP: <jp>この里は、かつては隠居の地として人気がありました。</jp>
Context 3-EN: Do you really want to retire?
Context 3-JP: <jp>お前は本当に隠居したいのか？</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: What's a <kanji>method</kanji> to <kanji>decrease</kanji> something? Well, you take something away. You do <vocabulary>subtraction</vocabulary>.
Reading Mnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well. Note that the <jp>ほう</jp> changes to <jp>ぽう</jp>. This is because you're trying to subtract <reading>Po</reading>lar (<jp>ぽう</jp>) bears from the area around you as they're very dangerous and you use a cologne made from meat.
Context 1-EN: I mastered addition the other day, so I will start learning subtraction today.
Context 1-JP: <jp>先日、加法をマスターしたので今日からは減法を学びます。</jp>
Context 2-EN: The area that I am good at most in math is subtraction.
Context 2-JP: <jp>私の算数で一番得意な分野は減法です。</jp>
Context 3-EN: In physics problems, we don’t come across vector subtraction very often, but it does pop up sometimes.
Context 3-JP: <jp>物理の問題で、ベクトル減法はあまり見ませんが、たまに出てくることがあります。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: A <kanji>suspicious</kanji> <kanji>incident</kanji> (<jp>事件</jp>) always has a <vocabulary>strange mystery</vocabulary> behind it. It also always turns into a <vocabulary>mystery case</vocabulary>.
Reading Mnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.
Context 1-EN: Even Holmes wouldn’t be able to find a clue to that mystery.
Context 1-JP: <jp>ホームズでさえもその怪事件の糸口を見つけることはできないだろう。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.
Reading Mnemonic: Uses the same reading that you learned with the kanji. Go ahead and use your <vocabulary>tongue</vocabulary> and say the reading out loud... "<reading><jp>した</jp></reading>."
Context 1-EN: Is the numbness in your tongue gone yet?
Context 1-JP: <jp>舌のしびれはもう取れましたか？</jp>
Context 2-EN: Maybe it's because I haven't had enough Vitamin C, but my tongue has been rough lately.
Context 2-JP: <jp>ビタミンCが足りてないからか、最近舌があれてるんだよね。</jp>

Context 2-JP: <jp>共犯者は国外に飛んでしまった可能性が高い。</jp>
