Context 3-JP: <jp>彼はとても素晴らしい犯罪者で、自分一人でも、いとも簡単にとても危ない状態から抜け出すことが出来ました。そして、共犯者は一生必要ないとも豪語していました。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: Many <kanji>times</kanji> is how many times you can use this <kanji>number</kanji> of <kanji>ticket</kanji>s. That means there are many tickets, making this a <vocabulary>book of tickets</vocabulary>.
Reading Mnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.
Context 1-EN: You can also buy a book of train tickets from a ticket outlet.
Context 1-JP: <jp>電車の回数券は金券ショップでも買えますよ。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: My <kanji>righteousness</kanji> <kanji>task</kanji> is my <vocabulary>obligation</vocabulary> to these people. I will go out and purge the world of evil, be righteous, and make things happen. It's my <vocabulary>duty</vocabulary>!
Reading Mnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.
Context 1-EN: Many people say that doing housework is a wife’s obligation to her husband and children, but is that really true?
Context 1-JP: <jp>家事をするのは、夫と子どもに対する妻の義務だと言う人が多くいますが、果たしてそれは本当でしょうか？</jp>

Meaning: Hole In The Wall,Little Known Good Place
Meaning Mnemonic: A <kanji>hole</kanji> <kanji>place</kanji> is what's known as a <vocabulary>hole in the wall</vocabulary>. This is a place that looks small, hidden and dingy, but probably has awesome food.
Reading Mnemonic: The readings are the readings you learned with the kanji.
Context 1-EN: This is a good blowfish restaurant, which isn't known to the public.
Context 1-JP: <jp>ここは、フグ料理の穴場なんですよ。</jp>
Context 2-EN: This Izakaya restaurant is called Kagaya and this is one of the best holes in the wall in Tokyo.
Context 2-JP: <jp>このい酒屋、カガヤって言うんだけど、東京でも穴場中の穴場だよ。</jp>
Context 3-EN: Ever since then I’ve never wanted to have that kind of experience again, or to cause trouble for others, so I’ve stopped going to the little-known place where you can fish for fugu.
Context 3-JP: <jp>あのことがあって以来、もう二度とああいう思いをしたくないし、周りにも迷惑をかけたくないので、フグ釣りの穴場に行くことは止めました。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: You're <kanji>certain</kanji> there is this <kanji>percent</kanji> chance it will happen? You know that this is the <vocabulary>probability</vocabulary>?
Reading Mnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.
Context 1-EN: The probability of Koichi accidentally falling into this pit is at about 20%.
Context 1-JP: <jp>コウイチがあやまってこの穴に落ちる確率は、20%ぐらいだろうね。</jp>
Context 2-EN: What's the likelihood of Koichi being someone who's kind to his friends?
Context 2-JP: <jp>コウイチが友情に厚い人である確率はどのぐらいだと思いますか？</jp>
Context 3-EN: Viet told Koichi that the chances of Tofugu succeeding were 200%.
Context 3-JP: <jp>ビエトはコウイチに、Tofuguが成功する確率は二百パーセントだと言いきった。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: This is a single kanji with an <jp>い</jp> on the end, meaning you know it's probably an adjective. What's the adjective form of <kanji>stinking</kanji>? It's also <vocabulary>stinking</vocabulary> (or <vocabulary>stinky</vocabulary>).
Reading Mnemonic: The reading you learned with the kanji can be used here, too.
Context 1-EN: The flooded area smelled really stinky.
Context 1-JP: <jp>水害地の臭いは、とても臭かったです。</jp>
Context 2-EN: Excuse my garlic breath. It smells terrible, right? I just ate ramen.
Context 2-JP: <jp>ニンニク臭くてごめんね。すごい臭いよね。さっきラーメン食べたんだ。</jp>
Context 3-EN: My husband's morning breath was too stinky to bear, so I decided to divorce him.
Context 3-JP: <jp>夫の朝の口臭が臭くて耐えられないので、離婚を決意したんです。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: Because the hiragana ends with an <jp>う</jp> sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means <kanji>establish</kanji> so the verb vocab version is <vocabulary>to establish</vocabulary>.
Reading Mnemonic: What are you going <vocabulary>to establish</vocabulary>? How about a new bar in Springfield called <reading>Moue</reading>'s (<jp>もう</jp>). You had to add that extra "u" in there because "Moe's" was already taken. Do'h!
Context 1-EN: Koichi often considers establishing new rules for his employees.
Context 1-JP: <jp>コウイチは、新しい従業員規則を設けることを検討しているようです。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: When you go in <kanji>order</kanji> of <kanji>turn</kanji>s that's the <vocabulary>order</vocabulary>. It also represents <vocabulary>one's turn</vocabulary> in said order as well.
Reading Mnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.
Context 1-EN: Koichi replies to his emails in order.
Context 1-JP: <jp>コウイチは順番にEmailに返信をします。</jp>
Context 2-EN: I'm waiting for my turn to pay at the grocery store at the moment.
Context 2-JP: <jp>今、スーパーで支はらいの順番を待っている所です。</jp>
Context 3-EN: Don't push and wait your turn, please!
Context 3-JP: <jp>押さずに順番を待ってください！</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: An <kanji>imitation</kanji> <kanji>manner</kanji> is something that does something in the manner of something else. Imitation over and over and over. Make it into a <vocabulary>pattern</vocabulary>.
Reading Mnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. Since you didn't learn the on'yomi for <jp>様</jp> with the kanji, here's a mnemonic to help you out. You see a pattern in your <reading>yo</reading>gurt (<jp>よう</jp>). The yogurt is an imitation of life. So deep, man. So deep.
Context 1-EN: My wife likes patterns with small flowers.
Context 1-JP: <jp>私の妻は、小さな花の模様が好きです。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: You know how <jp>非常</jp> means <kanji>emergency</kanji> and how <jp>口</jp> can be some kind of doorway (like in <jp>入り口</jp>, for example)? Well, if that's the case, then you have an emergency doorway. Usually you run away from emergencies, though, making this an <vocabulary>emergency exit</vocabulary>.
Reading Mnemonic: The reading is the words <jp>非常</jp> and <jp>口</jp> combined together. The thing that makes this weird is that it's a mix of the kun and on'yomi readings. I guess things get all jostled up when you have yourself an emergency.
Context 1-EN: You will see the emergency exit when you turn left at that corridor.
Context 1-JP: <jp>非常口はそこの通路を左に行ったところにあります。</jp>
Context 2-EN: When you think of a place where bad high schoolers skip class and hang out, it would be under the emergency exit staircase, right?
Context 2-JP: <jp>不良高校生がクラスをサボってくつろぐ場所と言えばふ通は非常口のかいだんの下ですよね？</jp>
Context 3-EN: After putting Aya’s drawing under his coat, the thief slipped out through the emergency exit.
Context 3-JP: <jp>コートの下にアヤが描いた絵を隠すと、泥棒は非常口からこっそりと抜け出した。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: A <kanji>special</kanji> <kanji>indication</kanji> on something or yourself is a special <vocabulary>characteristic</vocabulary>. It's a <vocabulary>distinctive feature</vocabulary> that exists.
Reading Mnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.
Context 1-EN: His personality is characterized by indecision and immobilism.
Context 1-JP: <jp>優柔不断と事なかれ主義が彼の特徴だ。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: A <kanji>monk</kanji> who is at <kanji>master</kanji> status is probably a priest by now... though not just any priest, this refers to a <vocabulary>Buddhist priest</vocabulary>. In modern Japanese this has also come to mean a <vocabulary>shaved head</vocabulary> or <vocabulary>close-cropped hair</vocabulary>. You can probably guess why!
Reading Mnemonic: The <jp>坊</jp> reads like you'd expect. Unfortunately <jp>主</jp> is an exception and read <jp>ず</jp>. Just think of a <reading>zoo</reading> that holds <vocabulary>Buddhist priest</vocabulary>s in captivity. How sad for those Buddhist priests.
Context 1-EN: Before becoming a Buddhist priest, I shaved my head.
Context 1-JP: <jp>坊主になる前に頭を坊主にした。</jp>
Context 2-EN: Tomorrow, I'll shave my head with clippers.
Context 2-JP: <jp>明日、バリカンで坊主にする。</jp>
Context 3-EN: Hey, son. You have to be realistic. Isn’t it about time you followed in my footsteps and became a Buddhist priest?
Context 3-JP: <jp>息子よ。現実的になれ。いい加減俺の後を継いで坊主になったらどうなんだ？</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: To <kanji>prevent</kanji> <kanji>beforehand</kanji> is still <vocabulary>prevention</vocabulary>.
Reading Mnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.
Context 1-EN: If we had better risk management, we would have been able to prevent this accident.
Context 1-JP: <jp>危機かん理がもっとしっかりしていたら、この事故は事前に予防することができたはずだ。</jp>
Context 2-EN: If you go to that country, please make sure to take medicine to prevent malaria beforehand.
Context 2-JP: <jp>その国に行くなら、事前に必ずマラリア予防の薬を飲んでください。</jp>
Context 3-EN: Do Japanese people get a tetanus vaccination every ten years, too?
Context 3-JP: <jp>日本人も十年ごとに破傷風の予防接種を受けるのですか？</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.
Reading Mnemonic: The reading is the same as the one you learned with the kanji.
Context 1-EN: I started reading Naoya Shiga’s novel, "At Cape Kinosaki" today.
Context 1-JP: <jp>今日志賀直哉の小説『城の崎にて』を読み始めました。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: An <kanji>earth</kanji> <kanji>earthquake</kanji> is just another way to say <vocabulary>earthquake</vocabulary>.
Reading Mnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well. Notice that <jp>地</jp> is read as <jp>じ</jp> instead of <jp>ち</jp>. You've seen this happen a few times before, so just try to remember that this is the case here.
Context 1-EN: The press severely criticized the government's earthquake preparedness.
Context 1-JP: <jp>新聞は、政府の地震対さくをはげしく非難しました。</jp>
Context 2-EN: When an earthquake occurs in a place where they rarely have them, some people call the police.
Context 2-JP: <jp>ふだん地震のない所でごくたまに地震が起きると警察に電話してくる人が出る。</jp>
Context 3-EN: "I want to talk to you about the earthquake last night." "I’ll totally listen to what you have to say."
Context 3-JP: <jp>「昨夜の地震について話したいんだけど。」「ぜひ聞きたいから話してよ。」</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: To <kanji>prevent</kanji> and <kanji>stop</kanji> someone from doing something is <vocabulary>prevention</vocabulary>. It's good to have prevention instead of letting something bad happen.
Reading Mnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.
Context 1-EN: The police have prevented crime from spreading in this town.
Context 1-JP: <jp>警察がこの町の犯罪の拡大を防止してくれています。</jp>
Context 2-EN: Today we discussed the prevention of global warming at school.
Context 2-JP: <jp>今日は学校で、地球温だん化防止について話し合いをしました。</jp>
Context 3-EN: Japanese currency is known for incorporating the world’s most advanced counterfeit prevention technology, but Viet is planning to defeat it.
Context 3-JP: <jp>日本の通貨は、世界一優れた偽造防止技術が使われていることで知られていますが、ビエトはそれを打ち負かそうとしています。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: Just be sure to make <kanji>certain</kanji> that you <kanji>recognize</kanji> him. We need <vocabulary>confirmation</vocabulary> and <vocabulary>verification</vocabulary>, so make certain again, please.
Reading Mnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.
Context 1-EN: When the confirmation screen shows up, please enter your ID and password to login.
Context 1-JP: <jp>確認画面が出たらIDとパスワードを入力してログインをしてください。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: You know how <jp>宇宙</jp> is <kanji>outer space</kanji> and how <jp>船</jp> is <kanji>ship</kanji>, right? Well, put those together and you have an outer space ship (better known as a <vocabulary>space ship</vocabulary>).
Reading Mnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well. It will help to know the word <jp>宇宙</jp> beforehand as well.
Context 1-EN: Nearly all of the sixteen space ships were retained and refurbished.
Context 1-JP: <jp>十六台の宇宙船のほとんど全てが、保持され改装されました。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: I have a <kanji>suspicion</kanji> (<jp>容疑</jp>) about <kanji>someone</kanji>. That someone is my main <vocabulary>suspect</vocabulary>.
Reading Mnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well. Will help to be able to read <jp>容疑</jp> first, though.
Context 1-EN: The suspect somehow conveyed a message of ambition and optimism to teenagers.
Context 1-JP: <jp>その容疑者は、どういう訳か十代の若者たちに大志と楽観主義のメッセージを伝えた。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: When you <kanji>undress</kanji> from the <kanji>line</kanji> it's like you're peeling something off the line, going off in another direction, and then causing a <vocabulary>digression</vocabulary> in whatever the line was about. It's like when you're talking and you digress. Think of your speech as a line. Then, undress a part of it and let it fall away. That is your digression.
Reading Mnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.
Context 1-EN: The train was derailed, but nobody was injured.
Context 1-JP: <jp>電車が脱線しましたが、怪我人はありませんでした。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: A <kanji>constitution</kanji> <kanji>government</kanji> is a <vocabulary>constitutional government</vocabulary>.
Reading Mnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.
Context 1-EN: What is a constitutional crisis?
Context 1-JP: <jp>憲政の危機って何ですか。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: To <kanji>prevent</kanji> <kanji>crime</kanji> is a good thing. To do this you use <vocabulary>crime prevention</vocabulary> techniques.
Reading Mnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.
Context 1-EN: The reason I’m here today is to introduce our latest crime prevention products.
Context 1-JP: <jp>本日参りました理由は、当社の最新防犯グッズをご紹介するためです。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: This is a single kanji with an <jp>い</jp> on the end, which means you think it ought to be an adjective, but it's not, it's a noun :( What's the noun form of <kanji>force</kanji>? It's also <vocabulary>force</vocabulary>.
Reading Mnemonic: This is a rough one. There is much force behind you, so when you come at me I scream: "<reading>EEK! OI!</reading> (<jp>いきおい</jp>), Get away from me!"
Context 1-EN: Our dog always bolts towards the milk-bone even though he isn’t racing anyone.
Context 1-JP: <jp>私達の犬は、誰と競争している訳でもないのに、いつもすごい勢いでミルクボーンに向かって行きます。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: Your <kanji>dwelling</kanji> <kanji>house</kanji> is your <vocabulary>dwelling</vocabulary> (or <vocabulary>residence</vocabulary>).
Reading Mnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.
Context 1-EN: Even in modern times, many Japanese homes continue to use tatami mats.
Context 1-JP: <jp>近年でも、多くの日本の住宅で畳が使われています。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: You must <kanji>respond</kanji> with <kanji>aid</kanji> in order to show your <vocabulary>support</vocabulary> for someone who needs it. You can usually show your support if you <vocabulary>root for</vocabulary> them.
Reading Mnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.
Context 1-EN: Who the heck is that enthusiastic and vocal supporter?
Context 1-JP: <jp>あの熱心に声を出す応援者はいったい誰なんだ？</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: <jp>主観</jp> is <kanji>subjectivity</kanji>. So when something moves towards subjectivity it is becoming <vocabulary>subjective</vocabulary>.
Reading Mnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well. It will help if you know <jp>主観</jp>.
Context 1-EN: This may be a very subjective view, but to me, you work too much and should take time off sometime soon.
Context 1-JP: <jp>これはとても主観的な見方かもしれないけど、僕にとっては君は働き過ぎだと思うんだよね。近々休みを取った方がいいよ。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: <jp>回復</jp> is <kanji>recovery</kanji>. Make it into a verb and you have <vocabulary>to recover</vocabulary>.
Reading Mnemonic: The reading comes from <jp>回復</jp>, but you can also figure it out via the readings of the kanji as well.
Context 1-EN: The doctor told me that he is not likely to regain consciousness.
Context 1-JP: <jp>彼が意識を回復することは難しいだろうと医者に言われました。</jp>

Meaning: Husband And Wife,Wife And Husband,Married Couple
Meaning Mnemonic: A <kanji>husband</kanji> and <kanji>wife</kanji> combo are a <vocabulary>husband and wife</vocabulary>.
Reading Mnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.
Context 1-EN: Oh, honey. Now that we’re husband and wife, I hope things go smoother between us.
Context 1-JP: <jp>ねぇ、あなた。これから先、私たち夫婦の間で色々なことがうまくいくといいわね。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: There are many <kanji>clause</kanji>s about the <kanji>promise</kanji>s you make in this contract considering it's supposed to be a <vocabulary>treaty</vocabulary>.
Reading Mnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.
Context 1-EN: Koichi’s New Year’s resolution is memorizing the entire text of the Treaty of Versailles.
Context 1-JP: <jp>コウイチの今年の抱負は、ベルサイユ条約の全文を暗記することです。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: You <kanji>suck</kanji> something in and <kanji>obtain</kanji> it. Shhheewwwwww! When you suck something in and obtain it into your body, you have done <vocabulary>absorption</vocabulary> because it's been sucked inside of you.
Reading Mnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.
Context 1-EN: When plants get water, how long does it take for them to absorb it?
Context 1-JP: <jp>植物が水分を取り入れる時って、どれくらいのスピードで吸収するんですか？</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: A <kanji>group</kanji> that <kanji>roots for</kanji> you is your <vocabulary>rooting section</vocabulary> or <vocabulary> cheerleaders</vocabulary>. Go go go you!
Reading Mnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well. <jp>応援</jp> is a word you've seen before, so if you know that this word will be easier.
Context 1-EN: Hey, you are the leader of the cheerleaders, right? I’ve heard a lot about you.
Context 1-JP: <jp>ああ、君が応援団長だね？噂はかねがね伺っておるよ。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: You <kanji>undress</kanji> and <kanji>run</kanji> out of that room. You had to take off your clothes in order <vocabulary>to escape</vocabulary>, but now you can run and start <vocabulary>to flee</vocabulary>. Just imagine some sort of contraption that holds you in place via your clothes, and you need to escape from it by taking said clothes off. Now imagine running away from that place naked. Escape!
Reading Mnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well. The <jp>だつ</jp> changes to <jp>だっ</jp>, though, so be careful of that.
Context 1-EN: The criminal, who had received a heavy sentence, broke out of prison.
Context 1-JP: <jp>重い刑罰を言い渡された犯罪者が、刑務所から脱走した。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: A <kanji>bend</kanji> in a <kanji>line</kanji> is merely a <vocabulary>curve</vocabulary>.
Reading Mnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.
Context 1-EN: This dress gives me beautiful curves.
Context 1-JP: <jp>このドレスは、曲線を美しく出してくれます。</jp>
Context 2-EN: The curve of Koichi's butt protruding from the speedo is very... nice!
Context 2-JP: <jp>ブーメランパンツから出てるコウイチのおしりの曲線…いいね！</jp>
Context 3-EN: I really love the soft, slanted curve of your cheek when you get mad.
Context 3-JP: <jp>あなたが怒った時の、ほおの柔らかく歪んだ曲線が好きよ。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: When you <kanji>establish</kanji> and <kanji>determine</kanji> something, you are making an establishment. When you make that into a verb, you have the word <vocabulary>to establish</vocabulary>. It also works for tech things, like <vocabulary>to set up</vocabulary> your computer settings.
Reading Mnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well. Careful because the <jp>設</jp> gets shortened to <jp>せっ</jp>.
Context 1-EN: I set up a new business mail account in Google for you.
Context 1-JP: <jp>あなたの新しいビジネス用のメールアカウントを、グーグルに設定しました。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: You know how <jp>宇宙</jp> is <kanji>space</kanji>? Well, a <kanji>person</kanji> from space is an <vocabulary>alien</vocabulary>.
Reading Mnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well. It will also help to know how to read the word <jp>宇宙</jp> on its own, too.
Context 1-EN: Koichi’s photographs honestly and sympathetically portray aliens who were victims of drought and the Great Depression on Mars.
Context 1-JP: <jp>コウイチの写真は、火星で干ばつと大恐慌の犠牲となった宇宙人たちを正直に、かつ同情を込めてとらえている。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: If <jp>混乱</jp> is <kanji>confusion</kanji> then making it into a verb would cause it <vocabulary>to be confused</vocabulary>.
Reading Mnemonic: The reading is the same as <jp>混乱</jp> so no reason for you <vocabulary>to be confused</vocabulary>, right?
Context 1-EN: You’re probably confused, but my brother is striving to overcome his fear of death right now, so please leave him alone.
Context 1-JP: <jp>君はおそらく混乱すると思うけど、弟は今、死への恐怖を克服しようと必死で努力しているところなの。だから、そっとしておいてあげてくれないかな？</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: Say you <kanji>give birth</kanji> to a baby. Then, after that everything falls apart and your life is <kanji>overthrown</kanji>. You lose it all because of this baby (babies are expensive). When you have your baby and everything is overthrown, you yourself are thrown into <vocabulary>bankruptcy</vocabulary>.
Reading Mnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.
Context 1-EN: When I learned my company would go bankrupt, I looked up at the sky and saw a beautiful contrail.
Context 1-JP: <jp>会社が倒産すると知った時、空を見上げたら、きれいな飛行機雲が見えたんです。</jp>
Context 2-EN: That company is under suspicion of bankruptcy.
Context 2-JP: <jp>あの会社には、倒産の嫌疑がかかっている。</jp>
Context 3-EN: Last year there were more than a hundred bankruptcies in this city alone.
Context 3-JP: <jp>昨年はこの街だけで100余りの企業が倒産した。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: I've <kanji>untie</kanji>d all the <kanji>reason</kanji> and made it even simpler, making it easier to understand. This increases my <vocabulary>comprehension</vocabulary> and <vocabulary>understanding</vocabulary> by quite a bit!
Reading Mnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.
Context 1-EN: I love you, sofa. Only you understand me.
Context 1-JP: <jp>愛してるよ、ソファー。お前だけは俺のことを理解してくれる。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: A <kanji>clause</kanji> in the <kanji>matter</kanji> complicates things. It adds <vocabulary>conditions</vocabulary>, <vocabulary>terms</vocabulary> and <vocabulary>requirements</vocabulary> to an otherwise simple matter.
Reading Mnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.
Context 1-EN: Fugu, you can go to the drinking party on Friday night, but on one condition - you can’t drink alcohol.
Context 1-JP: <jp>フグ、金曜の夜の飲み会に行ってもいいけど、一つだけ条件があるわ。お酒は飲まないでね。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: Know how <jp>存在</jp> is existence? Well, make it a verb and then you have <vocabulary>to exist</vocabulary>.
Reading Mnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.
Context 1-EN: I think that life after death exists.
Context 1-JP: <jp>私は死後の世界は存在すると思います。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: Things that are <kanji>manufacture</kanji>d in <kanji>Japan</kanji> (<jp>日本</jp>) are <vocabulary>made in Japan</vocabulary>. Good quality stuff, that is.
Reading Mnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well. Will help if you know how to read <jp>日本</jp> already.
Context 1-EN: The sword hilt was made in Japan and is studded with beautiful jewels.
Context 1-JP: <jp>その日本製の刀の柄には、美しい宝石が散りばめられている。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: If you put <kanji>writing</kanji> into a <kanji>category</kanji>, you'd have to write it down after you've chosen what category it is in. Where would you write that down? Into a <vocabulary>document</vocabulary>, probably.
Reading Mnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.
Context 1-EN: This document is incomplete.
Context 1-JP: <jp>この書類は不びがあります。</jp>
Context 2-EN: I think the document is on my desk at home.
Context 2-JP: <jp>書類を家のつくえの上においてきてしまったっぽい！</jp>
Context 3-EN: "When do you want Tofugu’s secret documents?" "The sooner, the better."
Context 3-JP: <jp>「いつTofuguの機密書類が欲しい？」「早ければ早いに越したことはないな。」</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: This is a weird one. Just think about the <kanji>sect</kanji> of <kanji>hand</kanji>s. They are always doing jazz hands and things like that, trying to be all <vocabulary>showy</vocabulary> and <vocabulary>flashy</vocabulary>. Ugh, what a dumb sect, you think.
Reading Mnemonic: The readings are the ones you learned with the kanji, though <jp>て</jp> goes to <jp>で</jp>.
Context 1-EN: I never want to be a bridesmaid because the dresses are too flashy.
Context 1-JP: <jp>ドレスが派手すぎるので、ブライズ・メイドには絶対なりたくありません。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: <kanji>Machine</kanji>s <kanji>dislike</kanji> everything. Their <vocabulary>mood</vocabulary> is very sour. What about your mood?
Reading Mnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well. <jp>けん</jp> gets changed to <jp>げん</jp>, though, so don't let that ruin your <vocabulary>mood</vocabulary>.
Context 1-EN: Koichi gets in a good mood for three o'clock snack time, every day like clockwork.
Context 1-JP: <jp>コウイチは、機械のように、毎日三時のおやつの時間になると機嫌が良くなる。</jp>
Context 2-EN: What kind of mood is mom in today?
Context 2-JP: <jp>今日のお母さんの機嫌はどう？</jp>
Context 3-EN: "Her mood's terrible in the morning." "Yeah don’t I know it!"
Context 3-JP: <jp>「彼女は朝、機嫌が悪いわね。」「ええ、全くその通りね。」</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: So this doesn't quite make sense in terms of the meaning of the kanji... but you'll be okay. This means <vocabulary>on purpose</vocabulary>. Perhaps when you do something that has the <kanji> appearance</kanji> of doing what you wanted to do you're doing it <vocabulary>on purpose</vocabulary>.
Reading Mnemonic: Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. You didn't learn that reading with this kanji, so here's a mnemonic to help you: "You did that to me <vocabulary>on purpose</vocabulary>? <reading>Whaza</reading>pp with that?"
Context 1-EN: She pretended to be indifferent toward him on purpose.
Context 1-JP: <jp>彼女は、彼に態と気のないふりをした。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: You <kanji>compare</kanji> the <kanji>percent</kanji> and by doing that figure out the <vocabulary>percentage</vocabulary> and <vocabulary>ratio</vocabulary> of something.
Reading Mnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.
Context 1-EN: What percent relies on machine translations?
Context 1-JP: <jp>機械ほんやくにはどれぐらいの比率でたよっていますか？</jp>
Context 2-EN: The ratio of boys and girls in the Tofugu office is 5 to 2.
Context 2-JP: <jp>トーフグのオフィスの男女比率は、5:2です。</jp>
Context 3-EN: I think Tofugu has a capital-to-asset ratio of 100%.
Context 3-JP: <jp>Tofuguの自己資本比率は100％だと思います。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: You <kanji>exit</kanji> and then make a <kanji>departure</kanji>. This is just a <vocabulary>departure</vocabulary>.
Reading Mnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well. The <jp>しゅつ</jp> gets shortened and <jp>はつ</jp> changes to <jp>ぱつ</jp>. No wonder you want to make a departure, you want to get away from crazy readings like this.
Context 1-EN: There are five minutes until departure.
Context 1-JP: <jp>出発まで五分です。</jp>
Context 2-EN: I'm going to leave for Tokyo in two weeks.
Context 2-JP: <jp>二週間後に、東京に出発する予定です。</jp>
Context 3-EN: Thank you so much for inviting me to a drinking party to celebrate the departure of a co-worker that I rarely spoke to.
Context 3-JP: <jp>ほとんど喋ったことのない同僚の出発の門出を祝う飲み会にお誘い頂き、どうも有難う御座います。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: A <kanji>truth</kanji> <kanji>occasion</kanji> is <vocabulary>reality</vocabulary>. This word is also used a lot as an adverb (with or without the particle <jp>に</jp>) to mean <vocabulary>actually</vocabulary> or <vocabulary>really</vocabulary>.
Reading Mnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well. The <jp>つ</jp> is shortened to <jp>っ</jp>.
Context 1-EN: How many clients does Tofugu actually have at the moment?
Context 1-JP: <jp>今現在、実際にTofuguは何名の顧客を抱えているのですか？</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: Take your <kanji>plan</kanji> and make a <kanji>drawing</kanji> out of it. This is your <vocabulary>plan</vocabulary>.
Reading Mnemonic: The <jp>かく</jp> reading was not the one you learned with the kanji. It is an exception that was introduced with the word <jp>計画</jp> not long back. Just keep that in mind and you'll be fine.
Context 1-EN: Nice to meet you. I am Koichi, the head of project management.
Context 1-JP: <jp>初めまして。私は経営企画部部長のコウイチと申します。</jp>

Meaning: To Get Knocked Over,To Get Knocked Down,To Collapse
Meaning Mnemonic: You've seen how <jp>倒す</jp> is "to knock over." But this is when something gets knocked over by itself. You know that you're not doing anything here, because when you're not touching all these fine glass items, it's very <reading>rare</reading> (<jp>れる</jp>) that anything gets knocked over (because you're not touching anything, you clumsy dumsy). It's also when you or someone else collapses. You didn't push yourself over, you just kind of fell by yourself.
Reading Mnemonic: The reading is the same like <jp>倒す</jp>. If you knew <jp>倒す</jp> you will know the reading of this one too.
Context 1-EN: The marathon runner collapsed from exhaustion right before the finish line.
Context 1-JP: <jp>そのマラソン選手は、ゴールの直前で疲れきって倒れてしまいました。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: The <kanji>past</kanji> <kanji>shape</kanji> is how things were in the past. To describe those things (like you would with an adjective, aka <jp>形容詞</jp>), you'd use <vocabulary>past tense</vocabulary>.
Reading Mnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.
Context 1-EN: Don’t you use the past tense in this case?
Context 1-JP: <jp>この場合は過去形は使わないんですか？</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: <kanji>Build</kanji> and <kanji>establish</kanji>. To do this, you'll need to do lots of <vocabulary>construction</vocabulary>.
Reading Mnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.
Context 1-EN: I used to live near the hills on which the ancient city of Rome was built.
Context 1-JP: <jp>私はかつて古代ローマが建設された丘の近くに住んでいた。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: The <kanji>someone</kanji>s (people) who <kanji>incur</kanji> <kanji>damage</kanji> are the <vocabulary>victims</vocabulary>. WILL SOMEBODY THINK OF THE VICTIMS HERE???
Reading Mnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well. It will help to know the word <jp>被害</jp> as well.
Context 1-EN: The crime was so brutal that not only the victim’s family, but everyone else, is hoping that the judge will sentence him with the ultimate punishment.
Context 1-JP: <jp>その犯罪は本当に残忍だったので、被害者家族だけではなく全ての人が裁判官が極刑を言い渡すことを願っている。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: You hopefully know that this has something to do with <kanji>housesitting</kanji> (<jp>留守番</jp>). So, a <kanji>telephone</kanji> (<jp>電話</jp>) that does housesitting for you is what? It's your <vocabulary>answering machine</vocabulary>.
Reading Mnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.
Context 1-EN: On my answering machine, I got a message from Koichi saying he's flying to Hawaii tomorrow.
Context 1-JP: <jp>留守番電話にコウイチから明日飛行機でハワイに行くというメッセージが入っていました。</jp>
Context 2-EN: He challenged me to a debate on my answering machine.
Context 2-JP: <jp>あっちが留守番電話で議論をふかっけてきたんだぜ。</jp>
Context 3-EN: I've been calling the Tofugu office over and over again, but I always get the answering machine.
Context 3-JP: <jp>Tofuguのオフィスに何度も何度も電話をしていますが、いつも留守番電話です。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: Use your <kanji>finger</kanji> to <kanji>indicate</kanji> some things. These are your <vocabulary>instructions</vocabulary>. Okay, do this (point), do that (point), and then finally do this (point).
Reading Mnemonic: The readings are the on'yomi readings. You've learned them both already, good for you!
Context 1-EN: Ignoring orders is not good, but I don’t want you to be someone who can’t work without instructions. Do you know what I mean?
Context 1-JP: <jp>指示を無視するのはよくありませんが、指示待ち族にはなってもらいたくはありません。私の言っている意味が分かりますか？</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: A <kanji>tall</kanji> <kanji>value</kanji>. If you paid for something that had a tall value, it would have a <vocabulary>high price</vocabulary>.
Reading Mnemonic: This word uses the kun'yomi readings for both kanji, but you know them both now, so you should be able to read this too!
Context 1-EN: Koichi’s secret diary fetched a record high price at the auction.
Context 1-JP: <jp>コウイチの秘密の日記が、オークションで歴代最高値で落札された。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: I <kanji>obtain</kanji> some <kanji>territory</kanji>, so I want a <kanji>writte</kanji>n record of it. How will I get a written record of my obtained territory? How about with a <vocabulary>receipt</vocabulary>? Emailing one will do just fine.
Reading Mnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.
Context 1-EN: I’d like to return this. Here’s the receipt.
Context 1-JP: <jp>これを返品したいのですが。これが領収書です。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: This one is a little strange. You have <jp>混じる</jp> (to get mixed up in), <jp>混ぜる</jp> (to mix), <jp>混ざる</jp> (to get mixed), and now this: <jp>混む</jp>, <vocabulary>to be crowded</vocabulary>. It makes sense that when everyone's all mixed up it's going to be crowded, but how to differentiate between this and the other <jp>混</jp> words? Just think of how cows <reading>muuuuu</reading> (<jp>む</jp>) get all bunched up and crowded, which is why this word is <vocabulary>to be crowded</vocabulary>.
Reading Mnemonic: Hey, <reading>come</reading> (<jp>こむ</jp>) out of that crowd of cows. It's going <vocabulary>to be crowded</vocabulary> in there.
Context 1-EN: The train is crowded every morning, but it’s not your fault. There’s no need to blame yourself.
Context 1-JP: <jp>電車は毎日混みますが、あなたのせいではありません。自分を責める必要はありませんよ。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: This is a single kanji with an <jp>い</jp> on the end, meaning you know it's probably an adjective. What's the adjective form of <kanji>cool</kanji>? It's <vocabulary>cool</vocabulary> (or <vocabulary>refreshing</vocabulary>).
Reading Mnemonic: If you want to experience a place that is <vocabulary>cool</vocabulary> and <vocabulary>refreshing</vocabulary> go to <reading>Sue</reading>'s <reading>Zoo</reading> (<jp>すず</jp>). Imagine yourself walking into the entrance of Sue's Zoo. Then walk in and feel how cool and refreshing it is.
Context 1-EN: Unfortunately, it was really cool out today.
Context 1-JP: <jp>残念ながら、今日はとても涼しかった。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: A <kanji>bow</kanji> and an <kanji>arrow</kanji>. Put them together and you have a <vocabulary>bow and arrow</vocabulary>.
Reading Mnemonic: The reading is the vocab readings, <jp>弓</jp> and <jp>矢</jp>, put together. This is probably because this word is like two separate words put together, thus the "and" in the middle of the English translation.
Context 1-EN: You need to be patient if you want to shoot a deer with a bow and arrow.
Context 1-JP: <jp>弓矢でシカを仕留めるには、にんたいがいります。</jp>
Context 2-EN: That night, my parents discussed whether or not to sell the bow and arrow.
Context 2-JP: <jp>その夜、両親は、弓矢を売るべきかどうか議論しました。</jp>
Context 3-EN: We used to use bows and arrows for hunting rabbits.
Context 3-JP: <jp>昔はうさぎ狩りに弓矢を使っていました。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.
Reading Mnemonic: "That's <reading>coo' </reading>," you like to say in response to <vocabulary>pipe</vocabulary>s. You've never seen pipes before, which makes them pretty cool to you. You've been using an outhouse your whole life, so pipes are pretty neat.
Context 1-EN: My sister chugged a bottle of the sweet kind of cough syrup when she was two and she had to get a tube shoved through her nose and into her stomach to pump it out.
Context 1-JP: <jp>妹は二歳の時に甘い咳止めシロップを一気飲みしてしまい、鼻から管を通して胃を洗浄するはめになった。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: Because the hiragana ends with an <jp>う</jp> sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means <kanji>plan</kanji> so the verb vocab version is <vocabulary>to plan</vocabulary>.
Reading Mnemonic: What are you trying <vocabulary>to plan</vocabulary>? No. Wait. How could you? You're trying to plan a <reading>coup? Whadda</reading> (<jp>くわだ</jp>) you thinking???
Context 1-EN: "What is it?" "Ah, nothing!" "You’re planning something, aren’t you?!"
Context 1-JP: <jp>「何それ？」「わっ！何でもないよ。」「何か企てているでしょう？」</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: The <kanji>region</kanji> that is this <kanji>ground</kanji> is the <vocabulary>region</vocabulary> / <vocabulary>area</vocabulary>. Just think of each area of ground. Each area is each region.
Reading Mnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.
Context 1-EN: Superman rushed food and fresh water to that region.
Context 1-JP: <jp>スーパーマンはその地域へ食料と新鮮な水を急送した。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: Please <kanji>determine</kanji> what <kanji>righteousness</kanji> means. I want the <vocabulary>definition</vocabulary> for it.
Reading Mnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.
Context 1-EN: What’s the definition of spam mail?
Context 1-JP: <jp>スパムメールの定義は何ですか？</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: When a <kanji>passage of time</kanji> <kanji>comes to an end</kanji>, you look back on it and see how well you did. Did we make more money? Did we make less? That's all <vocabulary>economics</vocabulary>, baby (that's money, baby!).
Reading Mnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well. The <jp>さい</jp> changes to <jp>ざい</jp>, though, so watch out for that.
Context 1-EN: Since Koichi was inaugurated as President, the US economy has continued to recover at a rapid pace.
Context 1-JP: <jp>コウイチが大統領に就任してからというもの、アメリカの経済は急ピッチで回復している。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic:
A <kanji>man</kanji> who is <kanji>superior</kanji> to us is an <vocabulary>actor</vocabulary>, or more specifically a <vocabulary>male actor</vocabulary>.

Just a word of warning: over the years this word has taken on the connotation of "adult film actor" so most people would use <jp>俳優</jp> for "actor" now. You'll be learning that word very soon!
Reading Mnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.
Context 1-EN: A homeless guy said seriously, "I’d like to try to win the award for best actor."
Context 1-JP: <jp>ホームレスの男性が、「主演男優賞を狙いたい」と真面目に語った。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: A <kanji>steam</kanji> <kanji>flute</kanji> is a flute that goes off using steam. The only time I can think of this happening is via a <vocabulary>steam whistle</vocabulary>. Choo choooo!
Reading Mnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.
Context 1-EN: We heard a steam train whistle coming from outside the window.
Context 1-JP: <jp>まどの外から、汽車の汽笛が聞こえてきました。</jp>
Context 2-EN: You ready? You've gotta jump off the ship when the steam whistle blows.
Context 2-JP: <jp>いいか？汽笛が鳴ったら、船から飛び下りるんだぞ。</jp>
Context 3-EN: In my dream last night, I was fortunate enough to witness the blowing of the Titanic’s steam whistles.
Context 3-JP: <jp>昨日の夢で、幸運にもタイタニック号が汽笛を鳴らすところを見たよ。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: They have <kanji>strong</kanji> <kanji>control</kanji> over us. That's why they can make us do all this <vocabulary>compulsory</vocabulary> stuff. We have to do it. They're too strong!
Reading Mnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.
Context 1-EN: My mother forced Fugu and I to move into this historic art-deco property.
Context 1-JP: <jp>母は、フグと私がこのアール・デコ様式の建物に引っ越すよう強制しました。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: Your <kanji>versus</kanji> <kanji>plan</kanji> is to attack back. They've already attacked you once, so now it's time for your <vocabulary>counter plan</vocabulary>.
Reading Mnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.
Context 1-EN: I was making a cup of coffee, I pressed a button, and the machine caught on fire. We have to find the cause of the defect and take measures to prevent its recurrence.
Context 1-JP: <jp>コーヒーを入れようとしてボタンを押したら、コーヒーメーカーが火を噴いたの。不具合の原因を見つけて、再発防止対策を講じなきゃいけないわ。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: Because the hiragana ends with an <jp>う</jp> sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means <kanji>stretch</kanji> so the verb version is <vocabulary>to stretch</vocabulary>.
Reading Mnemonic: Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. You didn't learn that reading with this kanji, so here's a mnemonic to help you: Imagine yourself trying <vocabulary>to stretch</vocabulary> (or better yet stand up and do it). Every time you stretch you start to laugh uncontrollably. <reading>HA</reading> (<jp>は</jp>) HA HA HA HA HA. Go ahead and laugh like that out loud while you stretch, it will help you to remember this reading.
Context 1-EN: Who put up the volleyball net?
Context 1-JP: <jp>バレーボールのネットを張ったのは誰ですか？</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: Your <kanji>parent</kanji>s don't want this to <kanji>expand</kanji> out into the community. Let's keep this <vocabulary>confidential</vocabulary>.
Reading Mnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.
Context 1-EN: If you opened a sealed envelope marked "Confidential" without permission, it could be considered as an unlawful opening of a letter and you could be punished with imprisonment with work detail for under one year, or a fine of up to 200,000 yen.
Context 1-JP: <jp>もし「親展」と書かれている封書を勝手に開けたら、信書開封罪とみなされて一年以下の懲役又は二十万円以下の罰金に課せられるかもしれませんよ。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.
Reading Mnemonic: Since this word is made up of a single kanji, it should use the kun'yomi reading. When learning the kanji, you didn't learn that reading, so here's a mnemonic to help you with this word: You're having this crazy <vocabulary>dream</vocabulary>. The dream allows you to do anything you want. Every time you ask "hey, can I do this?" The answer is always "<reading>you may</reading>" (<jp>ゆめ</jp>). Think of some things you'd want to do if you could do anything. Ask permission and get this answer in your imagination.
Context 1-EN: I heard that you sell dreams. How much does one dream cost?
Context 1-JP: <jp>あなたは夢を売っているそうですが、一個いくらですか？</jp>
Context 2-EN: Yesterday, I had a dream that Koichi was giving me a shiatsu massage.
Context 2-JP: <jp>昨日、コウイチに指圧をしてもらっている夢を見たんだ。</jp>
Context 3-EN: My dream is to become a manga artist. I hope it will come true.
Context 3-JP: <jp>私の夢は漫画家になることです。叶うといいな。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: Go ahead and <kanji>throw</kanji> your <kanji>resources</kanji> at the project. It could use the <vocabulary>investment</vocabulary>.
Reading Mnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well!
Context 1-EN: I don’t want to get involved in high risk investments.
Context 1-JP: <jp>リスクの高い投資商品にまで手を出したくはないんです。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: The <kanji>hand</kanji> who <kanji>borrow</kanji>s is the <vocabulary>borrower</vocabulary>.
Reading Mnemonic: You'll want to know the words <jp>借りる</jp> and <jp>手</jp> to be able to read this one. Combine them to know the reading.
Context 1-EN: Regardless of what you say, there's still a possibility that we won't be able to find a tenant, right?

Context 2-EN: When we advertised that Koichi used to live here, the house went right away.

Context 3-EN: That apartment still doesn’t have any tenants because it’s rumored to be haunted.
Context 3-JP: <jp>あのマンションは、幽霊屋敷であるという評判のせいで借り手がつかない。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: You know how <jp>参加</jp> is <kanji>participation</kanji>? Well, make that a verb with <jp>する</jp> and you have yourself <vocabulary>to participate</vocabulary>.
Reading Mnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well. Will also help to know the reading of <jp>参加</jp>.
Context 1-EN: I’m participating in the skyscraper observation tour this Sunday.
Context 1-JP: <jp>今週の日曜日、摩天楼の見学ツアーに参加します。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: In terms of an <kanji>individual</kanji> <kanji>person</kanji>... well, that's <vocabulary>personal</vocabulary>, and depends on the <vocabulary>individual</vocabulary>. Whatever it is, an individual person has personal tastes, so make sure to think of that.

Meaning Mnemonic: You <kanji>mix</kanji>, but there's a <kanji>distinction</kanji> as to where you mix at this <kanji>point</kanji>. Where is this point? It can be found when two streets cross, at an <vocabulary>intersection</vocabulary>, also known as a <vocabulary>crossing</vocabulary>.

Meaning Mnemonic: Let's <kanji>evaluate</kanji> the <kanji>value</kanji>. What is this also known as? An <vocabulary>evaluation</vocabulary>.

Meaning Mnemonic: Let's go <kanji>view</kanji> some <kanji>sunlight</kanji>! Oh wait, we can't do that here. We will have to go <vocabulary>sightseeing</vocabulary> to go see this amazing sunlight thing.

Context 1-EN: Let's not play the blame game because we are both old and our blood pressure might go up.

Context 3-EN: When I told my doctor that I still have high blood pressure, even after taking blood pressure meds, he told me the importance of reducing stress to control it.

Meaning Mnemonic: Even in the <kanji>middle</kanji> of your <kanji>dream</kanji> you're thinking about your body pillows. You're <vocabulary>crazy about</vocabulary> them, wrapped in <vocabulary>absorption</vocabulary>.

Context 3-JP: <jp>「サーモン。あのさ、多分知らなかっただろうけど、高校生の頃、き、きみに夢中だったんだ。」「知ってたわよ。フグ。」</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: When the <kanji>order</kanji> is from <kanji>big</kanji> (to small), you are talking about <vocabulary>decreasing order</vocabulary>. That's <vocabulary>largest first</vocabulary>.

Meaning Mnemonic: The <kanji>selling</kanji> (<jp>販売</jp>) of something has a <kanji>limit</kanji> (<jp>限定</jp>). This kind of item is one of <vocabulary>limited edition</vocabulary>.

Meaning Mnemonic: Even though the kanji mainly means <kanji> occasion</kanji>, for some reason this word means <vocabulary>side</vocabulary> or <vocabulary>edge</vocabulary>. Reading Mnemonic: You're on the very <vocabulary>edge</vocabulary> of the world. Meaning: Cut It Out,Cut The Bs,That's Enough
Meaning Mnemonic: You know how <jp>いい加減</jp> is unfounded or pointless? Because if you <kanji>add</kanji> and then <kanji>decrease</kanji> you haven't really done anything? Well, this is like saying "do the pointless!" Okay, that doesn't make any sense. This is a phrase that means something similar to <vocabulary>cut it out</vocabulary> or <vocabulary>cut the BS</vocabulary>!
Reading Mnemonic: The reading is the same as <jp>いい加減</jp>, which you (hopefully) learned earlier.
Context 1-EN: Viet was so angry that he couldn’t restrain himself from punching Koichi and screaming, "Cut it out!"
Context 1-JP: <jp>ビエトはあまりにも怒っていたので、コウイチを殴って「いい加減にしろ！」と叫ばずにはいられなかった。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: They <kanji>warn</kanji>, they <kanji>look at</kanji> crime, and they're an <kanji>agency</kanji> of the government. They are the <vocabulary>metropolitan police department</vocabulary>.
Reading Mnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.
Context 1-EN: My brother works for the Tokyo Metropolitan Police Department Public Security Bureau.
Context 1-JP: <jp>私の兄は、東京都警視庁公安部に勤めています。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: We're going to <kanji>deal with</kanji> it by <kanji>put</kanji>ting this up your butt and giving you the <vocabulary>treatment</vocabulary> you need. Kancho!

Meaning Mnemonic: Because the hiragana ends with an <jp>う</jp> sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means <kanji>respond</kanji> so the verb vocab version is <vocabulary>to respond</vocabulary>.
Reading Mnemonic: The reading is actually the same as the one you learned with the kanji! Not too shabby.
Context 1-EN: Do you think they will respond to our request for a 20 percent discount?
Context 1-JP: <jp>先方は、我々の二割りの値下げ要求に応じるでしょうか？</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: A <kanji>medicine</kanji> <kanji>expert</kanji> is someone who knows a lot about medicine. Those people are (I hope) generally <vocabulary>doctor</vocabulary>s.

Context 1-JP: <jp>ほんの短い時間だけでしたが、あの医師は二度テレビに出たことがあります。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: Please <kanji>write down</kanji> and <kanji>publish</kanji> this so we have a <vocabulary>record</vocabulary> of it.

A <kanji>haiku</kanji> <kanji>paragraph</kanji> is just a <vocabulary>haiku</vocabulary>. Haikus are little haiku paragraphs.

You will learn kanji
The Crabigator watches

Meaning: New Year's Card,New Year's Greeting Card

Meaning Mnemonic: This is a single kanji with an <jp>い</jp> on the end, meaning you'd think it's probably an adjective. However in this case, it's a noun. What's the noun form of <kanji>different</kanji>? It's <vocabulary>difference</vocabulary>.
Reading Mnemonic: The reading is the same as the one you learned with the kanji. Not different at all.
Context 1-EN: I really don’t see the difference between a garbage man and an executive vice president.
Context 1-JP: <jp>清掃員と副社長の違いなんて全く分からないね。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: An <kanji>action</kanji> <kanji>matter</kanji> is really just something that happens. It's an <vocabulary>incident</vocabulary> or <vocabulary>case</vocabulary>.

Context 1-JP: <jp>この「盗まれたコウイチの下着」事件について、できるだけ早く報告してください。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: This word consists of kanji with hiragana attached. Because the hiragana ends with an <jp>う</jp> sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means <kanji>continue</kanji> so the verb vocab version is <vocabulary>to continue</vocabulary>. Please continue.
Reading Mnemonic: Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. You didn't learn that reading with this kanji, so here's a mnemonic to help you: <reading>Two du</reading>des (<jp>つづ</jp>) get <vocabulary>to continue</vocabulary> on. I'm afraid you two ladies are going to have to stay here. This is a dudes only night club.

Context 1-JP: <jp>五日も雨が続いています。</jp>

Context 3-EN: I twisted my testicles and the pain has lasted for over five hours.

Meaning Mnemonic: A <kanji>month</kanji>'s <kanji>amount</kanji> is the <vocabulary>monthly amount</vocabulary>.

Meaning Mnemonic: Our <kanji>face</kanji>s have <kanji>adjoin</kanji>ed in this one room to talk. You did the telephone interview where you didn't show the face of your face. Now you're showing it, so we can begin the real <vocabulary>interview</vocabulary>.

Meaning Mnemonic: Your <kanji>appearance</kanji> has many <kanji>degree</kanji>s. You turn it up a dial, and you show off one <vocabulary>attitude</vocabulary>. Then you turn it down a degree and you have another <vocabulary>attitude</vocabulary>. So many attitudes to show off.

Meaning Mnemonic: You <kanji>beckon</kanji> someone to come to you, but then you <kanji>wait</kanji>. This is because they aren't really near you, so your beckon is more like an invitation. That's why this word means <vocabulary>to invite</vocabulary> or <vocabulary>to summon</vocabulary>.

Meaning Mnemonic: When you <kanji>raise</kanji> something you are causing it <vocabulary>to rise</vocabulary>.
Reading Mnemonic: Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. You didn't learn that reading with this kanji, so here's a mnemonic to help you: The reading for this is the same as the other "to rise" word, <jp>上がる</jp>. Nice how that works, right? So, just associate the two and you have yourself a reading.

To figure out the quantity, however, you have <vocabulary>to measure</vocabulary> / <vocabulary>to weigh</vocabulary> whatever it is you want to get the quantity of.

Context 1-JP: <jp>体重計で自分の体重を量るのが恐い。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: The <kanji>correct</kanji> <kanji>righteousness</kanji> is always your <vocabulary>righteousness</vocabulary>. It is your form of <vocabulary>justice</vocabulary>.

Meaning Mnemonic: A <kanji>product</kanji>'s <kanji>quality</kanji> is in its <vocabulary>material quality</vocabulary>. If the materials aren't any good then the product isn't either.

Context 1-JP: <jp>彼女は品質管理マネージャーとして入社した。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.
Reading Mnemonic: The reading is the same as what you learned with the kanji. Huzzah!
Context 1-EN: "Ah, my feet are killing me." "Told you so! That’s why I told you to wear more comfortable shoes."
Context 1-JP: <jp>「ああ、足が棒だよ。痛くて死にそう。」「言わんこっちゃない。だから、もっと歩きやすい靴を履けって最初に言ったじゃないか。」</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: Please <kanji>present</kanji> your <kanji>plan</kanji> in the form of a <vocabulary>proposition</vocabulary>.
