Meaning Mnemonic: Because the hiragana ends with an <jp>う</jp> sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means <kanji>mention</kanji> so the verb vocab version is <vocabulary>to mention</vocabulary>.
Reading Mnemonic: I have <vocabulary>to mention</vocabulary> this thing... "<reading>NO</reading>," (<jp>の</jp>) you quickly respond. I don't want you mentioning that here and now.
Context 1-EN: I don’t feel like explaining to my boss that I have a completely different opinion than he has.
Context 1-JP: <jp>上司に全く正反対の意見を述べるのは気が引けます。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: <kanji>Long</kanji> <kanji>shoes</kanji> aren't long in that the feet part are long (that wouldn't make sense). Instead, the top part is long, making them into <vocabulary>boots</vocabulary>.
Reading Mnemonic: The reading is a bit weird. Double kun'yomi, so think along the lines of <jp>長い</jp> and <jp>靴</jp> getting added together. <jp>靴</jp> is the reading you learned with the kanji, however. It also gets rendaku'd.
Context 1-EN: While laying in his hospital bed that night, he decided he would get a nice pair of rain boots for his wife next day.
Context 1-JP: <jp>病院のベッドに横になりながら、彼は明日妻にいい長靴を買ってやろうと思った。</jp>

Meaning: On'yomi And Kun'yomi,Chinese And Japanese Readings
Meaning Mnemonic: You've seen (hopefully) <jp>音読み</jp> and <jp>訓読み</jp>. This is a combination of the two. This is <vocabulary>on'yomi and kun'yomi</vocabulary>, aka the <vocabulary>Chinese and Japanese readings</vocabulary>.
Reading Mnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.
Context 1-EN: Please teach me how to differentiate between on'yomi and kun'yomi.
Context 1-JP: <jp>漢字の音訓の見分け方を教えてください。</jp>
Context 2-EN: This is a Chinese and Japanese reading chart of commonly used kanji.
Context 2-JP: <jp>これは常用漢字の音訓表です。</jp>
Context 3-EN: The Japanese and Chinese readings for kanji are so confusing, I hate them.
Context 3-JP: <jp>漢字の音訓ってすごく紛らわしいので嫌いです。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: <kanji>One</kanji> <kanji>husband</kanji>, <kanji>many</kanji> <kanji>wives</kanji>. Sounds a bit sketchy. This is <vocabulary>polygamy</vocabulary>.
Reading Mnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well. Just note that the <jp>一</jp> gets changed to <jp>いっ</jp> and the <jp>夫</jp> gets changed to <jp>ぷ</jp> from <jp>ふう</jp> for some reason. You can imagine that this is because when you are the type that has many wives, you're probably the type who makes them clean up your <reading>poo</reading> for you as well.
Context 1-EN: Japan used to approve of polygamy too.
Context 1-JP: <jp>日本もかつては一夫多妻がみとめられていました。</jp>
Context 2-EN: "I can't believe polygamy exists," Viet said accusingly. "You can turn that finger around,” Koichi retorted with a smile.
Context 2-JP: <jp>「一夫多妻せいとか、ありえないよな」とビエトが非難するように言うと、「その非難、自分に向けた方がいいんじゃねぇか？」とコウイチが笑って言い返した。</jp>
Context 3-EN: It’s not like all men support polygamy.
Context 3-JP: <jp>全ての男性が一夫多妻制を支持する訳じゃない。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: If you <kanji>aid</kanji> and <kanji>help</kanji> someone you are giving them <vocabulary>assistance</vocabulary>. How kind!
Reading Mnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.
Context 1-EN: Your assistance is vital to the success of this fart plan.
Context 1-JP: <jp>このオナラ計画が成功するには君の援助がぜひ必要です。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.
Reading Mnemonic: The reading is the same as the kanji.
Context 1-EN: Koichi made tons of money on the stock market and decided to swag out his car with big wheels and leather seats.
Context 1-JP: <jp>コウイチは株でガッポリ儲けたので、車のタイヤをどでかいホイール・タイヤに変えて、シートも革張りにしてカッチョ良くしちゃおうと決めた。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: Remember how <jp>構う</jp> is "to care about"? This is when you tell someone to not care about something, aka <vocabulary>don't worry about it</vocabulary>.
Reading Mnemonic: The reading comes from <jp>構う</jp>, so if you know that you know this!
Context 1-EN: I’ll be home soon so don’t worry.
Context 1-JP: <jp>すぐ帰りますので、お構いなく。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: <kanji>Quiet</kanji> <kanji>quiet</kanji>! Do it <vocabulary>quietly</vocabulary>, please.
Reading Mnemonic: You know how <jp>静か</jp> is <jp>しずか</jp>? Well, this is the same reading as that. Say it in a whisper with me: "<reading><jp>しずしず</jp></reading>." Shhh!
Context 1-EN: My mom always did housework quietly and mechanically.
Context 1-JP: <jp>私の母は、いつも静々と機械的に家事をこなしていました。</jp>
Context 2-EN: I was just ignoring my super-angry wife and calmly cleaning our place.
Context 2-JP: <jp>いかりくるう妻の横を尻目に、ぼくはただ静々とそうじをしていた。</jp>
Context 3-EN: The duchess gracefully entered the room and kissed the duke.
Context 3-JP: <jp>公爵夫人は静々と部屋に入って、公爵にキスをした。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: Because the hiragana ends with an <jp>う</jp> sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means <kanji>include</kanji> so the verb vocab version is <vocabulary>to include</vocabulary>.
Reading Mnemonic:
Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. You didn't learn that reading with this kanji, so here's a mnemonic to help you: 

They don't want <vocabulary>to include</vocabulary> you in their game? Well, "<reading>F***</reading> (<jp>ふく</jp>) you!" you yell at them, because they wouldn't include you.
Context 1-EN: What kinds of benefits does a hot spring containing alkali have?
Context 1-JP: <jp>アルカリを含む温泉にはどのような効能があるのですか？</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: You <kanji>sleep</kanji> like a <kanji>monk</kanji>, as in you never stop sleeping (because you sleep while you meditate). When you sleep like a monk like this you constantly <vocabulary>oversleep</vocabulary>, probably because you're up late doing sutras or something. I have no idea why monks wake up late, but figure something out to make this stick in your brain cage.
Reading Mnemonic: These are the readings you learned with the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.
Context 1-EN: I’m afraid no one in the Tofugu office is available at the moment. Every worker overslept today.
Context 1-JP: <jp>あいにくですが、トフグのオフィスには今、ご対応できる者がおりません。社員がみんな寝坊してしまったのです。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: A "<kanji>not</kanji> <kanji>condition</kanji>" is where nothing is going well. How are things going? Not well. The condition is bad. We're in a <vocabulary>recession</vocabulary>.
Reading Mnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.
Context 1-EN: The price of gold tends to rise during recessions.
Context 1-JP: <jp>不況時に金の価格は上昇しやすい。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: Put a <kanji>force</kanji> on your <kanji>figure</kanji> to make it into a certain shape. This is your <vocabulary>posture</vocabulary>.
Reading Mnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.
Context 1-EN: Your poor posture is probably causing your neck pain.
Context 1-JP: <jp>恐らく姿勢が悪いことが首の痛みの原因でしょう。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: A place where people <kanji>meet</kanji> and do <kanji>deliberation</kanji>. Sounds boring, but also sounds like some kind of <vocabulary>meeting</vocabulary> or <vocabulary>conference</vocabulary>.
Reading Mnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.
Context 1-EN: I started getting hungry during the assembly.
Context 1-JP: <jp>会議中に、おなかが減ってきました。</jp>
Context 2-EN: You ditched the conference to watch a serial TV drama!? What the heck!?
Context 2-JP: <jp>会議をサボって連ドラを見てるとは、何事だ！</jp>
Context 3-EN: The purpose of this meeting is to discuss our current situation and go over new plans.
Context 3-JP: <jp>この会議の目的は、我々の現状と新しい計画についての話し合いをすることです。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: A <kanji>half</kanji> <kanji>amount</kanji> sale is when things are <vocabulary>half price</vocabulary>. Cheap!
Reading Mnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.
Context 1-EN: Koichi, time to get up! We have to go to Walmart’s half price sale today.
Context 1-JP: <jp>コウイチ、そろそろ起きる時間よ！ウォールマートの半額セールに行かなきゃいけないんだから。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: A <kanji>pure</kanji> <kanji>cool</kanji> is <vocabulary>refreshing</vocabulary> and <vocabulary>cool</vocabulary>, isn't it.
Reading Mnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.
Context 1-EN: How many carbonated soft drinks do you think you can drink in ten minutes?
Context 1-JP: <jp>十分間にどれだけの炭酸入り清涼飲料水を飲めると思いますか？</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: Something that's <kanji>superior</kanji> will <kanji>excel</kanji>. It is <vocabulary>superior</vocabulary> in every way.
Reading Mnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.
Context 1-EN: Superior system administrators prepare for any possibility of hacking.
Context 1-JP: <jp>優秀なシステム管理者は、ハッキングによるいかなる攻撃の可能性にも備えます。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: If you <kanji>sue</kanji> and bring about a <kanji>lawsuit</kanji>, you are bringing about a <vocabulary>lawsuit</vocabulary>.
Reading Mnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.
Context 1-EN: The documents related to the lawsuit have all been properly filed by the lawyer.
Context 1-JP: <jp>その訴訟に関する書類は、弁護士によって全てきちんとファイルされている。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: Because the hiragana ends with an <jp>う</jp> sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means <kanji>cut off</kanji> so the verb vocab version is <vocabulary>to cut off</vocabulary>. Don't confuse this with <jp>断る</jp> which means "to refuse." You know this is <vocabulary>to cut off</vocabulary> because of the <jp>つ</jp>, which hints that you have had <reading>two</reading> (<jp>つ</jp>) too many chocolates, and it's time to cut you off.
Reading Mnemonic: URGH! The reading isn't even the same as <jp>断る</jp>, how frustrating. <vocabulary>To Cut Off</vocabulary> is read as <reading><jp>たつ</jp></reading>. Instead of eating too many chocolates and getting cut off, maybe you're eating too many tater <reading>tots</reading> (<jp>たつ</jp>). Don't eat so many of those, it's unhealthy. You have <vocabulary>to cut off</vocabulary> tater tots from your diet so you don't get fat.
Context 1-EN: Take into account that you don’t know what you could do while you’re drunk, so you should really cut yourself off from drinking alcohol.
Context 1-JP: <jp>酔っぱらった時に何をしでかしたかを考慮すると、あなたは絶対にお酒を断つべきですよ。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: An <kanji>ice</kanji> <kanji>river</kanji> is some ice that moves (very slowly) like a river. That is a <vocabulary>glacier</vocabulary>. In fact, many inlets and sounds were created with glaciers, because glaciers moved through them like rivers... not very quickly, though.
Reading Mnemonic: The reading for <jp>氷</jp> is the one you didn't learn. Think of the glacier coming slowly to your door. It rings your doorbell and says <reading>heyo</reading> (<jp>ひょう</jp>). Note that the <jp>か</jp> becomes <jp>が</jp> here.
Context 1-EN: The number of melting glaciers has been increasing every year due to global warming.
Context 1-JP: <jp>地球温暖化のために、毎年溶けている氷河が増えている。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: <kanji>New</kanji> and <kanji>fresh</kanji> is <vocabulary>fresh</vocabulary> (has to be new if you want it to be fresh, after all).
Reading Mnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.
Context 1-EN: I always worked overtime at my last job until I was told to stop, so it’s very new to me to leave work at five o’clock every day.
Context 1-JP: <jp>前の職場では、止めろと言われるまでいつも残業していたので、毎日五時に退社するのはとても新鮮です。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: Because the hiragana ends with an <jp>う</jp> sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means <kanji>sue</kanji> so the verb vocab version is <vocabulary>to sue</vocabulary>.
Reading Mnemonic: <reading>YOU TA</reading>KE (<jp>うった</jp>) MY THINGS, I AM GOING <vocabulary>TO SUE</vocabulary> YOU!
Context 1-EN: A couple weeks ago, my direct supervisor was let go because many female workers complained about his sexual harassment.
Context 1-JP: <jp>多くの女子社員がセクハラを訴えたため、私の直属の上司は二、三週間前に解雇されました。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: Because the hiragana ends with an <jp>う</jp> sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means <kanji>to illuminate</kanji>. Don't get it confused with <jp>照れる</jp> which is "to feel embarrassed," though, that would be embarrassing. You know this is "to illuminate" because the <jp>らす</jp> is the <reading>rash</reading> (<jp>らす</jp>) you get every time you're illuminated.
Reading Mnemonic: Speaking of things that illuminate, your <reading>hand</reading>s (<jp>手</jp>) illuminate all the time for some reason.
Context 1-EN: Can you shine the flashlight over there for a moment?
Context 1-JP: <jp>ちょっと懐中電灯であそこの方を照らしてくれない？</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: <kanji>Scatter</kanji> around the ground and <kanji>walk</kanji>. When you walk in a scatter all around, you're going for <vocabulary>a walk</vocabulary> or <vocabulary>a stroll</vocabulary>.
Reading Mnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well. The <jp>ほ</jp> goes to <jp>ぽ</jp>, though.
Context 1-EN: I bring change with me when I go for walks.
Context 1-JP: <jp>散歩をする時は、小銭しか持ち歩きません。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: I <kanji>recognize</kanji> your <kanji>consent</kanji>. It is <vocabulary>approval</vocabulary> of what I'm doing.
Reading Mnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.
Context 1-EN: I don't have much confidence that I can get approval from the committee.
Context 1-JP: <jp>委員会から承認を得られる自信はあまりありません。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: The number <kanji>two</kanji> <kanji>scroll</kanji> is the <vocabulary>second volume</vocabulary>. With Japanese books, they often come in pieces with groups of three being common. This represents the <vocabulary>second volume</vocabulary>.
Reading Mnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.
Context 1-EN: They made an appendix for all sources cited in the second volume.
Context 1-JP: <jp>二巻では、引用の出典に関する別表が作成されました。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: If <jp>健康</jp> is "health," then something that is <kanji>not</kanji> this is <vocabulary>unhealthy</vocabulary>.
Reading Mnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well. Will help to know <jp>健康</jp> first.
Context 1-EN: The TV show about unhealthy baseball players will be broadcasted nationwide.
Context 1-JP: <jp>不健康な野球選手についてのテレビ番組は、全国放送される予定ですよ。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: The <jp>日</jp> is the <jp>日</jp> in <jp>日本</jp>, making it mean <kanji>Japanese</kanji> in this word. If you are <kanji>Japanese</kanji> in <kanji>lineage</kanji> then you are of <vocabulary>Japanese descent</vocabulary>.
Reading Mnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.
Context 1-EN: My wife is a third generation American of Japanese descent.
Context 1-JP: <jp>私の妻は日系アメリカ人の三世です。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: A <kanji>strangle</kanji> <kanji>kill</kanji> is when you are <vocabulary>strangled to death</vocabulary>. Try to avoid this.
Reading Mnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.
Context 1-EN: "You almost strangled that guy to death!" "I’m sorry. I went too far."
Context 1-JP: <jp>「あんた、もう少しであの男を絞殺しかけたのよ！」「ごめん。やりすぎたよ。」</jp>

Meaning: To Be Replaced,To Be Substituted,To Be Switched
Meaning Mnemonic: Because the hiragana ends with an <jp>う</jp> sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means <kanji>replace</kanji>, but this word means <vocabulary>to be replaced</vocabulary>.
Reading Mnemonic: The reading is the same as the one you learned with the kanji.
Context 1-EN: Would you mind switching seats with me? I’m with her and our seats are separate.
Context 1-JP: <jp>もしご迷惑でなければ、席を替わってもらえませんか？彼女と一緒なんですが、席が別々になってしまったんです。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: Because the hiragana ends with an <jp>う</jp> sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means <kanji>knit</kanji> so the verb vocab version is <vocabulary>to knit</vocabulary>.
Reading Mnemonic: When you start <vocabulary>to knit</vocabulary>, you always end up with the same thing every time when you're done, no matter what you're trying to make: The letter "<reading>A</reading>" (<jp>あ</jp>). It's so frustrating that you can't knit anything else.
Context 1-EN: What inspired you to knit bras?
Context 1-JP: <jp>ブラジャーを編んでみようと思ったきっかけはなんですか。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: Because the hiragana ends with an <jp>う</jp> sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means <kanji>abbreviation</kanji>, so the verb vocab version is <vocabulary>to abbreviate</vocabulary>.
Reading Mnemonic: The reading is, strangely, the same as the reading you learned with the kanji. <reading><jp>りゃくす</jp></reading>.
Context 1-EN: Young Japanese people tend to abbreviate words and phrases.
Context 1-JP: <jp>日本の若者はすぐ単語やフレーズを略したがる。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: <kanji>English</kanji> <kanji>translate</kanji> is an <vocabulary>English translation</vocabulary>.
Reading Mnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.
Context 1-EN: All I can do is to translate from Japanese to English.
Context 1-JP: <jp>日本語から英訳することしかできません。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: The <kanji>feeling</kanji> of <kanji>dye</kanji>, covering your body, is the feeling of nasty germs and diseases penetrating your skin, getting inside of you. This is an <vocabulary>infection</vocabulary>, and it's gross.
Reading Mnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.
Context 1-EN: I didn’t know that periodontitis is a type of infectious disease.
Context 1-JP: <jp>歯周病は感染症の一種だとは知りませんでした。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: This takes the second meaning of the kanji you learned, <vocabulary>chastity</vocabulary>.
Reading Mnemonic: Who is doing the <vocabulary>chastity</vocabulary> thing? That <reading>missa, oh</reading> (<jp>みさお</jp>), yes she is.
Context 1-EN: My brother says that girls should preserve their chastity until marriage.
Context 1-JP: <jp>私の兄は女性は結婚するまで操を守るべきだと言う。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: Remember <kanji>Nara</kanji> (<jp>奈良</jp>)? This is the <kanji>prefecture</kanji> of it, making it <vocabulary>Nara Prefecture</vocabulary>.
Reading Mnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.
Context 1-EN: She was one of my best friends when I lived in Nara prefecture, but we’ve drifted apart since I moved to Osaka.
Context 1-JP: <jp>私が奈良県に住んでいる時は、彼女は親友の一人でしたが、私が大阪に引っ越してからは疎遠になりつつあります。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: This <kanji>earth</kanji> <kanji>belt</kanji> is the area within the belt, which holds this area of earth in. It is separate from the rest of the earth, making it its own <vocabulary>zone</vocabulary> or <vocabulary>district</vocabulary>.
Reading Mnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.
Context 1-EN: This is a safe zone for everyone but you.
Context 1-JP: <jp>ここは、あなた以外には安全地帯です。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: If <jp>延長</jp> is <kanji>prolonging</kanji>, then the verb version is <vocabulary>to prolong</vocabulary>.
Reading Mnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.
Context 1-EN: Do you know where I should go to extend my visa?
Context 1-JP: <jp>ビザを延長するにはどこに行ったらいいのか知ってる？</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: "<kanji>No</kanji>" is the <kanji>decision</kanji> I've made. Sorry, but this is <vocabulary>rejection</vocabulary>.
Reading Mnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.
Context 1-EN: I read that the senate rejected the bill in the newspaper this morning.
Context 1-JP: <jp>今朝新聞で上院は議案を否決したって読んだよ。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: Because the hiragana ends with an <jp>う</jp> sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means <kanji>translate</kanji> so the verb version would be <vocabulary>to translate</vocabulary>.
Reading Mnemonic: The reading for the kanji part is surprisingly the <jp>やく</jp> you learned with it, even you wouldn't expect that. I suppose that's the kind of thing you have to look forward to if you were to go into translating.
Context 1-EN: This word is difficult to translate.
Context 1-JP: <jp>この単語を訳すのは難しい。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: People of a <kanji>valuable</kanji> <kanji>tribe</kanji> are part of <vocabulary>the nobility</vocabulary>. Unlike our tribes, they are valuable.
Reading Mnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.
Context 1-EN: If I had been born to a noble family, I would have been able to talk to her.
Context 1-JP: <jp>ああ、もし私が貴族の家柄に生まれていたら、彼女と話をすることも可能だったかもしれないのに。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: A <kanji>tear</kanji> in your <kanji>ship</kanji> will cause it to wreck, making it a <vocabulary>shipwreck</vocabulary>.
Reading Mnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.
Context 1-EN: The ship carrying the famous sword of the Edo period was shipwrecked in a storm.
Context 1-JP: <jp>江戸時代の有名な刀を載せた船は、嵐によって破船してしまいました。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: You remember <jp>提案</jp>, which means <kanji>proposition</kanji>? Make that into a verb and you have <vocabulary>to propose</vocabulary>.
Reading Mnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.
Context 1-EN: I’d like to propose a new mutual fund to you today.
Context 1-JP: <jp>本日は、新しい投資信託をご提案させて頂きたいと思います。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: To <kanji>support</kanji> and <kanji>aid</kanji> is <vocabulary>to support</vocabulary>.
Reading Mnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.
Context 1-EN: I tried to stand by you no matter what happened, but I failed.
Context 1-JP: <jp>何が起ころうが君を支援しようとしたけど、できなかったんだ。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: A <kanji>banquet</kanji> <kanji>meet</kanji>ing is when you meet together for a <vocabulary>banquet</vocabulary> (or <vocabulary>dinner party</vocabulary>).
Reading Mnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.
Context 1-EN: Drinking alcohol with someone you don’t like at a dinner party is a much more tedious task than recording the proceedings of a meeting.
Context 1-JP: <jp>宴会で嫌な奴とお酒を飲むのは、会議で議事録を記録するより退屈な仕事だ。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: If <jp>呼ぶ</jp> is "to call" then this is something similar. This is when you are called by someone (and you're not doing the calling). This word is <vocabulary>to be called</vocabulary>.
Reading Mnemonic: The reading is shared with <jp>呼ぶ</jp>, so remember that and you'll be able to read this too.
Context 1-EN: I was a little sad to reach an age where I can be called a middle-aged woman.
Context 1-JP: <jp>おばちゃんと呼ばれる年になってしまったことがちょっと悲しかった。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: <kanji>Long</kanji> <kanji>Cape</kanji> <kanji>Prefecture</kanji>. This will make more sense when you look at the reading. Hint: It's <vocabulary>Nagasaki Prefecture</vocabulary>.
Reading Mnemonic: The readings are <jp>長</jp> from <jp>長い</jp>, normal <jp>崎</jp> and normal <jp>県</jp>.
Context 1-EN: I am from Nagasaki prefecture and my family graves are all located there, too.
Context 1-JP: <jp>私は長崎県の出身で、家族の墓も全部そこにあります。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: <jp>招く</jp> is "to beckon," so a <kanji>cat</kanji> that <kanji>beckon</kanji>s is known as a <vocabulary>maneki neko</vocabulary> or a <vocabulary>beckoning cat</vocabulary>. These are the cat statues places in front of shops that move their arms up and down and are like, "Hey, come on in!"
Reading Mnemonic: This word uses the kun'yomi readings for both kanji, which you know already!
Context 1-EN: Don’t leave the electrical Maneki Neko plugged into the outlet when you leave here.
Context 1-JP: <jp>ここを出る時、電動招き猫のコンセントを挿しっぱなしにしないでね。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: The thing that will <kanji>pass through</kanji> <kanji>freight</kanji> is <vocabulary>currency</vocabulary>. Why? Because when you want freight to be your own, you have to put money through it and to the person who owns it. When you do that, it becomes yours. Use that currency!
Reading Mnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.
Context 1-EN: I am quite familiar with this currency.
Context 1-JP: <jp>私はこの通貨をよく知っています。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: The <kanji>order</kanji> of things is the <kanji>preface</kanji> to the entire <vocabulary>sequence</vocabulary> and <vocabulary>steps</vocabulary> we're planning on taking. So, just remember. The order is just the preface. It is what allows us to come up with a sequence.
Reading Mnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.
Context 1-EN: After I successfully bid on Yahoo auctions, I wrote about the order of procedures on my blog.
Context 1-JP: <jp>ヤフオクで入札した後の手続きの順序についてブログでまとめてみました。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: If <jp>官僚</jp> is "bureaucracy," then adding a <jp>的</jp> to it would make it <vocabulary>bureaucratic</vocabulary>.
Reading Mnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well. Knowing <jp>官僚</jp> will help a lot too.
Context 1-EN: There’s too much bureaucratic red tape in this company.
Context 1-JP: <jp>この会社では官僚的な形式主義がまかり通りすぎている。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: The <kanji>alluring</kanji> <kanji>power</kanji> is the power of <vocabulary>allure</vocabulary>.
Reading Mnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

Reading Mnemonic:

The one with the <vocabulary>flag</vocabulary> is the Mad <reading>Hatter</reading> (<jp>はた</jp>). Just imagine looking through a group of people. You have to find the Mad Hatter, and he has to find you. That's why he offered to wear a flag on his hat.
Context 1-EN: I bought the cute toothpick flags on impulse.
Context 1-JP: <jp>私は可愛い爪楊枝の旗を衝動買いしてしまいました。</jp>

And just so you know, this is a very formal word used when you're trying to be polite. So keep that in mind, please!

Meaning: To Be Scattered,To Get Scattered,To Scatter
Meaning Mnemonic: Because the hiragana ends with an <jp>う</jp> sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means <kanji>scatter</kanji> so the verb vocab version is <vocabulary>to be scattered</vocabulary>. You know that this verb represents when something is scattering (you're not doing the scattering), because you would never be so <reading>ru</reading>de as to scatter someone or something yourself. It only happens when it happens on its own.
Reading Mnemonic: Think about something scattering. That something is <reading>chee</reading>se (<jp>ち</jp>), scattering all over the floor, going everywhere, getting in everything. Ugh, you hate how cheese scatters, don't you?
Context 1-EN: "Hey, are you listening?" "Oh, yes. I’m listening. Sorry, sorry, I just got distracted for a moment."
Context 1-JP: <jp>「ねえ、聞いてるの？」「あっ、うん。聞いてるよ。ごめん、ごめん。でも、ちょっと気が散っちゃってた。」</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: Because the hiragana ends with an <jp>う</jp> sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means <kanji>crowded</kanji> and the verb vocab version is <vocabulary>to be crowded</vocabulary>.
Reading Mnemonic: Lucky for you, the reading you learned with the kanji is the one you use here.
Context 1-EN: Disneyland is always crowded, whether or not it's a holiday.
Context 1-JP: <jp>休日だろうが何だろうがディズニーランドはいつでも込んでるよ。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: The <kanji>way</kanji> of <kanji>virtue</kanji> is the way you take if you have <vocabulary>morals</vocabulary>. Hopefully you have some.

Context 1-EN: Why are you so sure that animals have no sense of morality?
Context 1-JP: <jp>どうして動物には道徳感がないって断言できるの？</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic:
The <kanji>acid</kanji> <kanji>element</kanji> is <vocabulary>oxygen</vocabulary>. In German it’s the same as in Japanese - it’s called “Sauerstoff”, including “sauer”, the word for “sour”. The noun version is “säure” which means both “sourness” and “acid” (which again is the same in Japanese, the same kanji is used in both words). The word “oxygenium” in Greek/Latin literally means “acid maker”. Long ago chemists thought oxygen was a defining characteristic of acids, later they found out there are also acids without oxygen like hydrochloric/muriatic/salt acid and the defining characteristic actually is hydrogen. But the name stuck.

Or you could just imagine all the oxygen you breathe has turned into acid (oh no!), and it sucks to breathe. Whatever works for you.
Reading Mnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.
Context 1-EN: I do aerobic exercises every afternoon.
Context 1-JP: <jp>毎日午後に有酸素運動をしています。</jp>

Reading Mnemonic: The <jp>磁</jp> reading makes sense. The <jp>しゃく</jp> reading for <jp>石</jp> is an exception. To remember this, just think how you are using a magnet to find this <reading>shack</reading> (<jp>しゃく</jp>) full of other magnets. It pulls you towards the shack, and when you find it and open it, all the magnets fly out and crush you because of magnety reasons.
Context 1-EN: I got some cute magnets for your souvenir.
Context 1-JP: <jp>お土産に可愛い磁石をいくつか買ったわよ。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: You know that <jp>味噌</jp> is "miso," and that <jp>汁</jp> is "soup." So, combine them together and you have <vocabulary>Miso Soup</vocabulary>.
Reading Mnemonic: The reading is <jp>味噌</jp> plus the vocab <jp>汁</jp> put together.
Context 1-EN: "We have to finish eating this miso soup by tomorrow." "Okay, let’s get it over with."
Context 1-JP: <jp>「明日までに、この味噌汁を飲んでしまわなければならないよ。」「じゃあ、さっさと片付けちまおうぜ。」</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: Things that are <kanji>strong</kanji> and <kanji>intense</kanji> are <vocabulary>strong</vocabulary> and <vocabulary>intense</vocabulary> (the "strong" meaning is more along the lines of the "intense" meaning, so not so much like my muscles are super muscly and strong).
Reading Mnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.
Context 1-EN: If I smoke for the first time in a while, I get an intense tobacco high.
Context 1-JP: <jp>ひっさびさにタバコ吸ったら、強烈なヤニくらくらっちまったよ。</jp>

Meaning: To Line Up,To Put In Order
Meaning Mnemonic: <jp>並ぶ</jp> is when something is lining up. <jp>並べる</jp> is when you're lining something up. You know this because when it comes to <reading>bear</reading>s (<jp>べる</jp>), you have to line them up yourself, because they won't be doing it for you, that's for sure.
Reading Mnemonic: The reading can come from <jp>並ぶ</jp>, so if you know that you can figure out the reading for this one as well.
Context 1-EN: Why did it take you so long to set up the bowling pins?
Context 1-JP: <jp>ボーリングのピンを並べるのにどうしてそんなに時間がかかったんですか。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: If you <kanji>secret</kanji> something, you are trying <vocabulary>to keep secret</vocabulary> something. That, or you're trying <vocabulary>to conceal</vocabulary> it.
Reading Mnemonic: The reading is the same as the one you learned with the kanji, strangely enough. Nothing <vocabulary>to conceal</vocabulary> about this reading, you gots it.
Context 1-EN: I’m worried about him because he tends to hide his feelings.
Context 1-JP: <jp>彼は内に秘めるタイプなので、心配しています。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well. Remember, this is the eyeball pupil.
Reading Mnemonic: A <reading>person</reading>'s (<jp>ひと</jp>) <reading>see</reading>ing (<jp>見</jp>) ability comes from their <vocabulary>pupil</vocabulary>. That's how you can remember <jp>ひとみ</jp>.
Context 1-EN: When I look at my stepmother’s listless eyes I always end up wincing.
Context 1-JP: <jp>父の再婚相手の気怠い瞳を見ると、いつもたじろいでしまいます。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: The <kanji>religion</kanji> <kanji>teach</kanji>ings are what makes up a <vocabulary>religion</vocabulary>. If you don't have the teachings of the religion, nobody will learn about it, and it will stop being a religion.
Reading Mnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.
Context 1-EN: She will be the secretary who records the transactions of the world religions meeting.
Context 1-JP: <jp>彼女が、世界宗教会議の記録を取る書記を務めます。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: Because the hiragana ends with an <jp>う</jp> sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means <kanji>break</kanji> so the verb vocab version is <vocabulary>to break something</vocabulary>, because you're doing the breaking. You know this because someone is trying to <reading>sue</reading> (<jp>す</jp>) you for the things you broke of theirs.
Reading Mnemonic: The thing you broke? A beautiful ceramic <reading>koa</reading>la (<jp>こわ</jp>). Watch it shatter to the ground, because you threw it there. What a jerk you are.
Context 1-EN: I cooked this blowfish in my own way and it wrecked my stomach.
Context 1-JP: <jp>この河豚を自分なりに料理してみたんですが、お腹を壊してしまいました。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: The <kanji>zen</kanji> <kanji>religion</kanji> is a part of Buddhism. It is the <vocabulary>Zen Sect</vocabulary> of Buddhism.
Reading Mnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.
Context 1-EN: The movie about the Zen sect of Japanese Buddhism is playing at this theater.
Context 1-JP: <jp>その禅宗に関する映画は、この映画館で上映中です。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: I <kanji>fear</kanji> it. It is <kanji>scary</kanji>. It is pure <vocabulary>terror</vocabulary>.
Reading Mnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.
Context 1-EN: When a yakuza told me that the change I gave him was 100 yen short, I felt an incredible amount of fear.
Context 1-JP: <jp>ヤクザにお釣りが百円足りないと言われた時に、とてつもない恐怖を感じました。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: It's <kanji>pleasant</kanji> but also <kanji>fast</kanji>. When getting on a train, it's nice to find a train that's both of these things. What makes it pleasant? That would be the <vocabulary>high speed</vocabulary>. What makes it fast? Also the <vocabulary>high speed</vocabulary>. Really, if you're on a train you'd rather get to your destination sooner than later, so a high speed <jp>快速</jp> train is the way to go.
Reading Mnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.
Context 1-EN: Koichi dreamt last night that he showed off his talent of throwing with a 150-kilometer-per-hour fastball.
Context 1-JP: <jp>コウイチは、昨晩、150キロの快速球を投げ込んで才能の違いを見せつけている夢を見た。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: Because the hiragana ends with an <jp>う</jp> sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means <kanji>dangle</kanji> so the verb vocab version is <vocabulary>to dangle</vocabulary> or <vocabulary>to dangle something</vocabulary>. You're doing the dangling.
Reading Mnemonic:
Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. You didn't learn that reading with this kanji, so here's a mnemonic to help you: 

What are you trying <vocabulary>to dangle</vocabulary>? You're dangling a <reading>ta</reading>co (<jp>た</jp>) in front of a hungry person. He just wants the taco, and you keep dangling it like that.
Context 1-EN: She drew a picture of a bulldog drooling while napping and it was really cute.
Context 1-JP: <jp>あの娘が涎を垂らしながら一服しているブルドッグの絵を描いたんだけど、それがすっごく可愛くってさ。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: If <jp>騒ぐ</jp> is "to make noise," then a <kanji>big</kanji> version of this is even louder. It's a <vocabulary>clamor</vocabulary> and an <vocabulary>uproar</vocabulary>.
Reading Mnemonic: This is word that uses the kun'yomi readings of the kanji, which you should know already because <jp>大</jp> is pretty familiar to you by now (I hope) and you just learned <jp>騒ぐ</jp> as well! Put them together, with a little tweaking at the end, and you have your reading. Ta-da!
Context 1-EN: An escaped gorilla caused a major scene in some country, didn't it?
Context 1-JP: <jp>どこかの国で、ゴリラが逃げ出して大騒ぎになっていたことがあったよね。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: <jp>越す</jp> is "to go beyond." Now you're going beyond your home and <kanji>pull</kanji>ing everything with you to go to another home. You are trying <vocabulary>to move</vocabulary> / <vocabulary>to move homes</vocabulary>.
Reading Mnemonic: The readings come from <jp>引く</jp> and <jp>越す</jp> put together. Careful of that <jp>っ</jp>.
Context 1-EN: "Dad, Fugu and I are getting married and moving to Japan." "Not while I’m alive, you won’t."
Context 1-JP: <jp>「パパ、フグと私、結婚して日本に引っ越すつもりよ。」「俺の目の黒いうちはそんなことはさせないぞ。」</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: Your <kanji>previous</kanji> <kanji>ancestor</kanji>s are your <vocabulary>ancestors</vocabulary>. All ancestors are previous to you, after all, unless you want to talk time travel, then who knows.
Reading Mnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own. Just remember there is a rendaku that changes <jp>そ</jp> to <jp>ぞ</jp>！
Context 1-EN: Our family has a special diaper that has been passed down from father to son for six generations.
Context 1-JP: <jp>うちの家族には、六世代に渡って先祖代々受け継がれてきた特別なおむつがあります。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: If <jp>結婚</jp> is <kanji>marriage</kanji>, then a marriage <kanji>ceremony</kanji> is a <vocabulary>marriage ceremony</vocabulary> or <vocabulary>wedding</vocabulary>.
Reading Mnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.
Context 1-EN: "It’s tomorrow, but I think we should still cancel our wedding." "You took the words right out of my mouth."
Context 1-JP: <jp>「もう明日だけど、でも、やっぱり、私たちの結婚式を中止するべきだと思うの。」「僕もそれを言おうと思っていたんだ。」</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: Because the hiragana ends with an <jp>う</jp> sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means <kanji>steal</kanji>, so the verb vocab version is <vocabulary>to steal</vocabulary>.
Reading Mnemonic: What are you going <vocabulary>to steal</vocabulary>? How about a <reading>noose</reading> (<jp>ぬす</jp>)? Wait, why are you stealing a noose? That sounds like trouble to me...
Context 1-EN: He’s the kind of guy who never does something halfway, so he must have a magnificent plan to steal the 3106 carat diamond.
Context 1-JP: <jp>あいつは絶対に中途半端なことはしない奴だから、3106カラットのダイヤモンドを盗むための壮大な計画を立てているに違いない。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: A <kanji>defense</kanji> <kanji>star</kanji> isn't really a star, but it is something shiny in the sky that can look like a star if it's bright enough. This is a <vocabulary>satellite</vocabulary>, and while it's not always defensive, satellites can have defensive properties. Think ion canons and video and things like that.
Reading Mnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You know them both already, so you should be able to read this word!
Context 1-EN: It’s not impossible to avoid a falling satellite.
Context 1-JP: <jp>落下する衛星を避けることは、不可能ではありません。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: You're <kanji>pure</kanji> and that's <kanji>stylish</kanji>, which makes you even more <vocabulary>pure</vocabulary>, somehow. But your purity also makes you <vocabulary>genuine</vocabulary>, unlike all the people who aren't pure trying to be stylish.
Reading Mnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.
Context 1-EN: I’m still with my husband for purely financial reasons.
Context 1-JP: <jp>純粋に金銭的な理由だけで、夫とまだ一緒にいるんです。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: A <kanji>slow</kanji> <kanji>carve</kanji> is so slow. If you carve something slowly, it will take you a long time. You will <vocabulary>be late</vocabulary> with a slow carve like that.
Reading Mnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.
Context 1-EN: I was late three days in a row.
Context 1-JP: <jp>三日連続で遅刻してしまいました。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: This is a single kanji with an <jp>い</jp> on the end, meaning you know it's probably an adjective. What's the adjective form of <kanji>slow</kanji>? It's <vocabulary>slow</vocabulary> (or, if you're slow, you're probably <vocabulary>late</vocabulary>, too).
Reading Mnemonic: How <vocabulary>slow</vocabulary> are you? You are <reading>oh so</reading> slow (<jp>おそ</jp>).
Context 1-EN: My computer is very slow because it’s running out of hard drive space.
Context 1-JP: <jp>私のパソコンはハードディスクの容量が無くなってきているので、動作がすごく遅いです。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: I <kanji>jammed in</kanji> myself and <kanji>enter</kanji>ed your personal life. Because I care, you know? I don't want you to be addicted to My Little Pony anymore, so this is an <vocabulary>intervention</vocabulary>.
Reading Mnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

Meaning: To Tighten,To Become Tight,To Be Toned
Meaning Mnemonic: Because the hiragana ends with an <jp>う</jp> sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means <kanji>tighten</kanji>, so the verb vocab version is <vocabulary>to tighten</vocabulary>.
Reading Mnemonic:
What can you do if you want something <vocabulary>to tighten</vocabulary> or <vocabulary>to become tight</vocabulary>? You need to hug your <reading>shee</reading>p (<jp>し</jp>) really close until...

The sheep tightens into a tiny little ball. Cute!
Context 1-EN: This seat belt tightens on its own.
Context 1-JP: <jp>このシートベルトは自動的に締まってくれます。</jp>
Context 2-EN: Mr Onishi's body is well toned isn't it!
Context 2-JP: <jp>大西さんの体はよく締まっていますね〜。</jp>
Context 3-EN: This is my first managerial position and I’m very tense.
Context 3-JP: <jp>初めての管理職ということで、身の引き締まる思いをしています。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.
Reading Mnemonic: Since this word is made up of a single kanji, it probably uses the kun'yomi reading. You did not learn this reading, so here's a mnemonic to help you to remember: Please hand me the rope, right <reading>now</reading> (<jp>なわ</jp>), otherwise I will fall to my death!
Context 1-EN: Both ropes look the same to me. I can’t tell the difference at all.
Context 1-JP: <jp>私にはどっちの縄も同じに見えますね。違いは全く分かりません。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.
Reading Mnemonic: The reading is the same as the one you learned with the kanji. That's <jp>零</jp> extra things for you to learn.
Context 1-EN: My mom really loses her temper if I get zero marks on my exams.
Context 1-JP: <jp>うちの母親は、僕が零点を取ると、キーッと癇癪を起こします。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: <jp>興味</jp> is <kanji>interest</kanji> in something. If you do not have (<jp>がない</jp>) that interest, then you have <vocabulary>no interest</vocabulary> or you're <vocabulary>not interested</vocabulary>.
Reading Mnemonic: Reading comes from the on'yomi as well as <jp>興味</jp>.
Context 1-EN: I’m not interested in building personal relationships with customers.
Context 1-JP: <jp>俺は顧客と個人的に仲良くなることには興味がないんだ。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: When you have <kanji>flame</kanji> <kanji>symptom</kanji>s that's when you feel like you're filled with fire, which is <vocabulary> inflammation</vocabulary>.
Reading Mnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

Context 1-JP: <jp>筋肉の炎症には、ノンステロイドの痛み止めを処方しておきますね。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: Your <kanji>self</kanji> <kanji>oneself</kanji>, is your <vocabulary>oneself</vocabulary> or <vocabulary>self</vocabulary>.
Reading Mnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

Meaning: Middle Ten Days Of The Month,Middle Of The Month,Middle Of Month
Meaning Mnemonic: The <kanji>middle</kanji> <kanji>time of the month</kanji> is the <vocabulary>middle ten days of the month</vocabulary>.
Reading Mnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.
Context 1-EN: My due day is around the middle of November.
Context 1-JP: <jp>予定日は十一月の中旬です。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: Because the hiragana ends with an <jp>う</jp> sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means <kanji>rescue</kanji> so the verb vocab version is <vocabulary>to rescue</vocabulary>.
Reading Mnemonic: The <jp>すく</jp> in the reading is a lot like the <reading>scue</reading> (<jp>すくう</jp>) part of <vocabulary>to rescue</vocabulary>, don't you think? Hopefully you do, so you can make the connection.
Context 1-EN: My friend’s blog has been trolled. Give me some advice to rescue her from it.
Context 1-JP: <jp>友人のブログが荒らされています。友人を救うための知恵を貸してください。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: To lend is <jp>貸す</jp>. This is the noun version. It is something that has been rented, a <vocabulary>rental</vocabulary>.
Reading Mnemonic: The reading is the same as <jp>貸す</jp>.
Context 1-EN: I’m living in a rental warehouse now.
Context 1-JP: <jp>今は貸し倉庫で寝泊まりしているんです。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: A <kanji>knit</kanji> <kanji>someone</kanji> is one who knits words together and makes them better. This someone is an <vocabulary>editor</vocabulary>.
Reading Mnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.
Context 1-EN: This is Mr. Maruyama, who worked as the editor for this magazine.
Context 1-JP: <jp>こちらの雑誌の編者を務めてくれた丸山君です。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: <kanji>Open</kanji>ed and <kanji>closed</kanji> things are <vocabulary>opening and closing</vocabulary>.
Reading Mnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.
Context 1-EN: Changing the opening and closing times caused a little bit of confusion and misunderstanding.
Context 1-JP: <jp>開閉時刻の変更は、小さな混乱と誤解を招いた。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: <kanji>Simple</kanji> and <kanji>pure</kanji>. This is <vocabulary>simple</vocabulary>.
Reading Mnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.
Context 1-EN: I can make up simple sentences in Japanese, but I can’t do complicated ones yet.
Context 1-JP: <jp>日本語で単純な文章なら作れますが、難しいのはまだ無理です。</jp>

Meaning: Overstepping Your Authority,Overstep One's Authority,Overstepping One's Authority
Meaning Mnemonic: If you <kanji>go beyond</kanji> your <kanji>rights</kanji>, you are going too far. You're doing what you're not supposed to do, and you're overstepping your authority.
Reading Mnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.
Context 1-EN: Officer, I’m afraid you are overstepping your bounds.
Context 1-JP: <jp>お巡りさん、差し出がましいようですがそれは越権行為では無いでしょうか。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: When your <kanji>tense</kanji>ness is <kanji>stretch</kanji>ed out as far as it is, it becomes not just tenseness, but <vocabulary>stress</vocabulary> as well. The <vocabulary>tension</vocabulary> is crazy when you stretch it out like this!
Reading Mnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.
Context 1-EN: "I have a job interview tomorrow. I’m a little nervous." "Oh, really? Well, I’m sure you’ll do fine."
Context 1-JP: <jp>「明日、就職の面接があるんで、ちょっと緊張してるんだよね。」「え〜そうなの？うまくいくといいね。」</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: <jp>診断</jp> is a <kanji>diagnosis</kanji>. Make this into a verb, and you have <vocabulary>to diagnose</vocabulary>.
Reading Mnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.
Context 1-EN: Right before the doctor diagnosed me with cancer, a nurse glanced over her shoulder at me.
Context 1-JP: <jp>その医者が私に癌だと診断するほんの少し前に、ある看護婦さんが私の事をちらっと振り返って見たんです。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: When you have the <kanji>feeling</kanji> of <kanji>pleasant</kanji>ness, you are experiencing <vocabulary>pleasure</vocabulary>.
Reading Mnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.
Context 1-EN: I don’t want you to be a person who derives pleasure from humiliating people.
Context 1-JP: <jp>人に恥をかかせることで快感を味合うような人にはなってもらいたくないわ。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: Because the hiragana ends with an <jp>う</jp> sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means <kanji>exclude</kanji> so the verb vocab version is <vocabulary>to exclude</vocabulary>.
Reading Mnemonic: You would like to exclude your <reading>nose</reading> (<jp>のぞ</jp>) because you don't like your nose. Imagine your strong feelings about your nose as you decide to exclude it.
Context 1-EN: Fold all the papers, excluding the red one, to meet the crease.
Context 1-JP: <jp>赤い紙を除く全ての紙を、その折り目まで折ってください。</jp>

Meaning: To Become Thirsty,To Be Thirsty,To Become Dry
Meaning Mnemonic: When you have a <kanji>thirst</kanji>, you tend <vocabulary>to become thirsty</vocabulary>.
Reading Mnemonic: The reading is the same as the one you learned with the kanji. Go grab a cup of water so you don't become dehydrated, okay?
Context 1-EN: Well, I was really thirsty so I drank too much beer. I’m drunk~
Context 1-JP: <jp>ええっと、喉がカラカラに渇いてたから、ビールを飲み過ぎちゃったんだよね。俺は今、ベロベロだ〜。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: An <kanji>ash</kanji> <kanji>plate</kanji> is a plate you use for ashes. That's an <vocabulary>ashtray</vocabulary>.
Reading Mnemonic: The reading is the two vocab words, <jp>灰</jp> and <jp>皿</jp>, put together.
Context 1-EN: I bought an ashtray just in case.
Context 1-JP: <jp>念のため灰皿を買っておきました。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: A <kanji>punish</kanji> <kanji>period of time</kanji> is the time in which you are being punished in prison. This is your <vocabulary>prison term</vocabulary>.
Reading Mnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.
Context 1-EN: The convict was released after serving a fifteen-year prison term, but he had nowhere to go.
Context 1-JP: <jp>その囚人は、十五年間の刑期を務めた後で釈放されたが、行く当てがなかった。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: Everything is <kanji>suitable</kanji> and <kanji>right</kanji>. Therefore it is <vocabulary>appropriate</vocabulary>, <vocabulary>proper</vocabulary>, and <vocabulary>suitable</vocabulary>. Strangely enough, this also means <vocabulary>irresponsible</vocabulary>. Maybe it's because when everything is suitable and right for you, you're taking too much and not leaving enough for everyone else, making you irresponsible?
Reading Mnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.
Context 1-EN: Please choose the appropriate answer.
Context 1-JP: <jp>適当な答えを選んでください。</jp>
Context 2-EN: That guy often says irresponsible things.
Context 2-JP: <jp>あいつは適当な事ばかり言っている。</jp>
Context 3-EN: I was surprised when my colleague was ordering in an izakaya and said to the waitress: "Choose whatever you think is best".
Context 3-JP: <jp>居酒屋で、同僚が店員に「適当にお願いします」と言って注文をしたことに驚きました。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: A <kanji>male</kanji> <kanji>dog</kanji> is a <vocabulary>male dog</vocabulary>. Do you know what a female dog is?
Reading Mnemonic: The readings are the kun'yomi readings, which is probably A-Okay for <jp>犬</jp>, but for <jp>雄</jp> you'll want to think about how a male dog is probably pretty pushy, always trying <reading>to push</reading> (<jp>押す</jp>) other dogs around, being male and moody and all that.
Context 1-EN: "Daddy, I want a male dog. Can we have a male dog?" "We’ll see, but why not a female dog?"
Context 1-JP: <jp>「パパ、僕、雄犬がほしいな。雄犬を飼える？」「様子を見ようか。でも、どうして雌犬じゃないの？」</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: When <kanji>the cabinet</kanji> meets for <kanji>deliberation</kanji> they are having a <vocabulary>cabinet meeting</vocabulary>. So governmenty.
Reading Mnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.
Context 1-EN: What did we discuss at the cabinet meeting held earlier today? I forgot.
Context 1-JP: <jp>さっきの閣議では何が議題だったんだっけ？忘れちゃった。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: A <kanji>mountain</kanji> <kanji>vein</kanji> is a vein that extends across the land, and is covered in mountains. This refers to a <vocabulary>mountain range</vocabulary>.
Reading Mnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.
Context 1-EN: The Himalayan Mountain range is rich with a wide variety of nature.
Context 1-JP: <jp>ヒマラヤ山脈は多種多様な自然に恵まれています。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: For this word, the <jp>便</jp> comes from <jp>便所</jp>, which you know as "toilet." A <kanji>toilet</kanji> <kanji>secret</kanji> is one you take with you to the bathroom, one that you don't want people to know about. This is <vocabulary>constipation</vocabulary>.
Reading Mnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own. The <jp>ひ</jp> changes to <jp>ぴ</jp> because "P" stands for "Poop."
Context 1-EN: I’ve been constipated. I haven’t pooped in a week!
Context 1-JP: <jp>便秘がひどくてさぁ。もう一週間以上ウンコしていないんだよ！</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.
Reading Mnemonic: The reading is the same as the one you learned with the kanji.
Context 1-EN: The Sakurajima volcano eruption in Kagoshima covered the nearby city with ash.
Context 1-JP: <jp>鹿児島の桜島の火山の噴火で、近くの街は灰だらけになってしまいました。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: If you create <kanji>subscription</kanji>s to <kanji>buy</kanji> things, you're probably in the <vocabulary>purchasing</vocabulary> department. It's your responsibility to set up subscriptions and buy everything for everyone else because you're the purchasing person.
Reading Mnemonic: The reading is on'yomi, which is great for <jp>購</jp> but not as great for <jp>買</jp>. Luckily, the reading for <jp>買</jp> is <reading>buy</reading> (<jp>ばい</jp>), which is the same as the meaning, which is a pretty awesome coincidence.
Context 1-EN: I’m researching customers’ purchasing motivations.
Context 1-JP: <jp>私は消費者の購買意欲について研究をしています。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: <kanji>Dissolve</kanji> your <kanji>resources</kanji>, because you need to pay back your <vocabulary>financing</vocabulary> and <vocabulary>loan</vocabulary>s now.
Reading Mnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.
Context 1-EN: Getting a bank loan was more difficult than I thought.
Context 1-JP: <jp>銀行の融資を受けるのは思っていたよりも難しかったです。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: Something is <kanji>reverse</kanji>, that much you know. The <jp>さま</jp> comes from <jp>様</jp>, which could mean <kanji>manner</kanji>. So, something that is in a "reverse manner," is something that is <vocabulary>upside down</vocabulary>.
Reading Mnemonic: The reading comes from <jp>逆らう</jp> and <jp>様</jp>, put together. A bit of an <vocabulary>upside down</vocabulary> reading if I do say so myself, but you do what you gotta do.
Context 1-EN: Why did you draw the butterfly upside down?
Context 1-JP: <jp>どうして蝶々を逆さまに描いたの？</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: When you <kanji>enter</kanji> an <kanji>inlet</kanji>, you've gone into the <vocabulary>inlet</vocabulary>. It's also where water goes inside of the inlet (it's entering the inlet from the ocean, or whatever), so that's another way to think about it.
Reading Mnemonic: For this reading, just imagine this as <jp>入り</jp> with <jp>江</jp> pushed on at the end!
Context 1-EN: I was proposed to by someone I didn’t know in a cove north of the Baltic Sea. It was so romantic that I accepted.
Context 1-JP: <jp>バルト海の北の入江で知らない人からプロポーズされたんですが、とてもロマンチックだったのでつい承諾してしまったんです。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.
Reading Mnemonic:
Since this word is made up of a single kanji, it should use the kun'yomi reading. When learning the kanji, you didn't learn that reading, so here's a mnemonic to help you with this word:

There's something inside and you wanna get to what's within. Look inside. <reading>Ooh, chee</reading>se (<jp>うち</jp>)! Your favorite. Ooh cheese, how I love you.
Context 1-EN: Please paint the inside of the box pink.
Context 1-JP: <jp>はこの内がわをピンクいろにぬってください。</jp>
Context 3-EN: The thoughts I hide inside myself were spelled out in my diary.
Context 3-JP: <jp>内にひめたおもいを、日きにつづった。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: You <kanji>need</kanji> something so you <kanji>request</kanji> it. But, since it's such a strong need, it's not really a request, it's more of a <vocabulary>demand</vocabulary>.
Reading Mnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.
Context 1-EN: The labor unions demanded a wage increase.
Context 1-JP: <jp>労働組合は賃上げを要請した。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: The <kanji>clothes</kanji> with which I <kanji>decorate</kanji> myself with is my <vocabulary>attire</vocabulary>.
Reading Mnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.
Context 1-EN: I graduated from a fashion technical school.
Context 1-JP: <jp>私は服飾専門学校を卒業しました。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: You know <kanji>Meiji</kanji>, (<jp>明治</jp>), and you know <kanji>restoration</kanji> (<jp>維新</jp>). Combine them together and you have the <vocabulary>Meiji Restoration</vocabulary>.
Reading Mnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.
Context 1-EN: Fluorescent lights didn’t exist yet during the Meiji Restoration, right?
Context 1-JP: <jp>蛍光灯は明治維新の頃にはまだ無かったんだよね。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: You'd think this one would have a much different meaning, considering it's <kanji>tear</kanji> and <kanji>give birth</kanji>. This word means <vocabulary>bankruptcy</vocabulary>, which seems a bit odd, but I guess there's another bankruptcy word with <jp>産</jp> in it too (<jp>倒産</jp>). That one is fall, and this one is tear. They're both pretty bad, and they both refer to bankruptcy.
Reading Mnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.
Context 1-EN: It’s rumored that his grandfather was a bankrupt farmer of the Edo period.
Context 1-JP: <jp>彼の祖父は江戸時代の破産した百姓だという噂だ。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: My <kanji>introduce</kanji> was <kanji>jammed in</kanji> there for you to hear. That is my <vocabulary>introduction</vocabulary>. Jammin' it in.
Reading Mnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.
Context 1-EN: Salmon-Roe: "Hi, is Salmon here? I’m her sister." Salmon: "Oh my God, Salmon-Roe!" Fugu: "Oh, introduce us!" Salmon: "This is Fugu." (Points at him.) Salmon-Roe: "Nice to meet you!" Salmon: "And you know Crabigator and Kinnikuma!" Crabigator & Kinnikuma: "Hi Salmon-Roe. Long time, no see."
Context 1-JP: <jp>「こんにちは。サーモンいますか？妹なんですけど。」「わぁ、イクラじゃない！！！」「わぁ、紹介してよ！」「こちらが、フグ。（フグを指さしながら）」「初めまして。」「鰐蟹とキンニクマは知ってるわよね！」「やあ、イクラちゃん。久しぶり。」</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: If <jp>出版</jp> means <kanji>publishing</kanji>, then a <kanji>company</kanji> that does said publishing is a <vocabulary>publishing company</vocabulary>.
Reading Mnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own. Will help to know the word <jp>出版</jp> as well, though.
Context 1-EN: You have to show your ID card to enter the publishing company.
Context 1-JP: <jp>その出版社では、入館の際に身分証明書を提示しなければなりません。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: An <kanji>angry</kanji> <kanji>energy</kanji> comes out of you when you have <vocabulary>anger</vocabulary>. It also can refer to a <vocabulary>fit of anger</vocabulary>.
Reading Mnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.
Context 1-EN: His nostrils swelled with anger.
Context 1-JP: <jp>彼の鼻の穴は怒気を含んで膨らんでいる。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: When you really <kanji>stuff in</kanji> (<jp>詰める</jp>) what you are <kanji>see</kanji>ing, you're really looking at something, causing you <vocabulary>to stare at</vocabulary> whatever it is you're stuffing your seeing into.
Reading Mnemonic: The reading is <jp>見</jp> and <jp>詰める</jp>.
Context 1-EN: The dog was motionlessly staring at the balloon flying straight up, higher and higher.
Context 1-JP: <jp>その犬は、真っすぐ上へ上へと飛んで行く風船をじっと見詰めていた。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: You have an <kanji>idea</kanji> and you have <kanji>intent</kanji> to carry it out. This is your <vocabulary>will</vocabulary> and <vocabulary>volition</vocabulary>.
Reading Mnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.
Context 1-EN: I’m aware that I’m a weak-willed person.
Context 1-JP: <jp>自分が意志の弱い人間だってことは自覚してますよ。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: The <kanji>path</kanji> of the <kanji>sword</kanji> is known as <vocabulary>kendo</vocabulary>. You could also say <vocabulary>Japanese fencing</vocabulary>.
Reading Mnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.
Context 1-EN: Koichi has high aspirations. He wants to be the best in the world at kendo.
Context 1-JP: <jp>コウイチには大きな目標がある。剣道で世界一になりたいんだ。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: A <kanji>seal</kanji> <kanji>model</kanji> is the best kind of <vocabulary>seal</vocabulary>, but it's still just a seal.
Reading Mnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.
Context 1-EN: You need an officially sealed document.
Context 1-JP: <jp>公的な印鑑が押された書類が必要になります。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: Remember how <jp>直行</jp> is "nonstop"? Well, with <jp>直航</jp> it's the same thing, but more like with flying things, making this a <vocabulary>nonstop flight</vocabulary>.
Reading Mnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.
Context 1-EN: This ship is on a direct voyage to Kobe Port.
Context 1-JP: <jp>この船は神戸港に直航します。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: <jp>詰める</jp> is "to stuff in," so if you're really stuffing in your thoughts (<kanji>think</kanji>), you're really trying <vocabulary>to think hard</vocabulary>. That's just another way of saying <vocabulary>to brood</vocabulary>.
Reading Mnemonic: The reading is <jp>思い</jp> and <jp>詰める</jp> put together into one reading.
Context 1-EN: I’m between jobs, but I’m not worrying too much about it.
Context 1-JP: <jp>私は失業中ですが、そのことを思い詰めてはいません。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: A <kanji>wound</kanji> of your <kanji>heart</kanji>. That could be many things, but in this case it's <vocabulary>heartbreak</vocabulary>.
Reading Mnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.
Context 1-EN: He dumped me and I’m a little heartbroken, so I’m going on a trip to Paris to get over it.
Context 1-JP: <jp>彼に振られて傷心気味なので、パリに傷心旅行に行くんです。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: A <kanji>party</kanji> <kanji>member</kanji> is <vocabulary>party member</vocabulary> of a political party.
Reading Mnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.
Context 1-EN: I was deeply moved by a speech made by a member of the Republican Party.
Context 1-JP: <jp>ある共和党の党員の演説にとても感動しました。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: <kanji>Exclude</kanji> this one and put it <kanji>outside</kanji> what we're considering. This is the <vocabulary>exception</vocabulary>.
Reading Mnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.
Context 1-EN: The horse was excluded from the race due to shin soreness.
Context 1-JP: <jp>その馬はソエにより競争除外となりました。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well. You can put this on other words to say that it's a "Fierce ____" or "Energetic _____," or something along those lines. If you see this, you know that something is done fiercely or really energetically.
Reading Mnemonic: The reading is the same as what you learned with the kanji, probably because it's stuck onto things making it all jukugo and such.
Context 1-EN: The motorcycle came rushing forward at breakneck speed.
Context 1-JP: <jp>バイクが猛スピードで突っ込んできた。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: This has the same meaning as the kanji, specifically the <vocabulary>how much</vocabulary> meaning. To remember this, just think about how <reading>Ra</reading>, the Egyptian God, is always asking "<vocabulary>How much</vocabulary> will it cost to build this pyramid?" Ugh, too much, let's hire some slaves.
Reading Mnemonic: Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. You learned this reading already so you should be able to read it!
Context 1-EN: Could you tell me how much the shipping will be, please?
Context 1-JP: <jp>送料が幾らになるのか教えて頂けませんでしょうか。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.
Reading Mnemonic: When you have <vocabulary>intention</vocabulary> to do something, it feels like you're pointing at it with your heart. To say "heart pointing" in Japanese, you could say <jp>こころざし</jp> (<jp>心刺し</jp>). Guess what? The reading is the same thing as that, bringing it to <reading><jp>こころざし</jp></reading>. Now get out there and heart point to your dreams!
Context 1-EN: Viet has high aspirations and is steadily making his dreams come true.
Context 1-JP: <jp>ビエトは高い志を持っており、どんどん夢を実現していってる。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: <kanji>Dodge</kanji> a <kanji>difficult</kanji> situation by getting away from it. Do an <vocabulary>evacuation</vocabulary> to get out of there!
Reading Mnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.
Context 1-EN: The fire escape is badly damaged, so we need to replace it.
Context 1-JP: <jp>その避難梯子はひどく痛んでいるので、交換する必要があります。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: A <kanji>freight</kanji> <kanji>thing</kanji>s <kanji>ship</kanji> is a boat that freights things. It's a <vocabulary>freighter</vocabulary>.
Reading Mnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own. The <jp>物</jp> takes its <jp>もつ</jp> reading, which makes sense since it sounds like <jp>持つ</jp>, which is "to hold." What is this freighter doing? It's holding freight! So, that's how you can remember that bit.
Context 1-EN: Don’t roughhouse in my freighter!
Context 1-JP: <jp>私の貨物船の中で騒ぐんじゃない！</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: The <kanji>mountain</kanji> <kanji>middle</kanji> <kanji>lake</kanji> is <vocabulary>lake Yamanaka</vocabulary>, a famous and very nice lake in Japan. It's also a lake that will help you to learn the lake kanji reading better.
Reading Mnemonic: The reading is the kun'yomi readings of <jp>山</jp> and <jp>中</jp>, then the on'yomi reading of <jp>湖</jp>.
Context 1-EN: Given how cheap the camera was, all the pictures of Lake Yamanaka turned out beautiful.
Context 1-JP: <jp>安物のカメラで撮ったにしては、山中湖の写真すごく綺麗に撮れてるじゃん。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: To <kanji>become</kanji> <kanji>ripe(n)</kanji> is to <vocabulary>ripen</vocabulary> and <vocabulary>mature</vocabulary>.
Reading Mnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.
Context 1-EN: I’m writing a paper about the differences between the mature female brain and the mature male brain.
Context 1-JP: <jp>成熟した女性の脳と成熟した男性の脳の相違点について、論文を書いています。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: A <kanji>blood</kanji>'s <kanji>vein</kanji> is a <vocabulary>blood vessel</vocabulary>.
Reading Mnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.
Context 1-EN: We shouldn’t allow our bloodline to die out.
Context 1-JP: <jp>我々の血脈を絶やさせるべきではない。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: Your <kanji>blood</kanji> <kanji>fluid</kanji> is your <vocabulary>blood</vocabulary>.
Reading Mnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.
Context 1-EN: Why is blood red?
Context 1-JP: <jp>どうして血液は赤いのですか。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: <kanji>Someone</kanji> who has a <kanji>wound</kanji> is someone who is wounded. They are an <vocabulary>injured person</vocabulary>.
Reading Mnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.
Context 1-EN: It’s said that there were three killed and more than 200 wounded in that accident.
Context 1-JP: <jp>その事故による死者は三名、傷者は二百人以上にのぼるという。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.
Reading Mnemonic: The reading is the same as the one you learned with the kanji as well.
Context 1-EN: My profile can be found on the back page of this pamphlet.
Context 1-JP: <jp>私の紹介はパンフレットの裏表紙に記されています。</jp>

Meaning: To Hurt Someone,To Injure,To Wound,To Scratch,To Damage
Meaning Mnemonic: You <jp>つける</jp> (attach) a <kanji>wound</kanji> to someone. In other words, this word means <vocabulary>to hurt someone</vocabulary> or <vocabulary>to injure</vocabulary> them.
Reading Mnemonic: The reading is <jp>傷</jp>. If you remember the reading for that you got this too.
Context 1-EN: I might have scratched my contact lens.
