Meaning Mnemonic: The <kanji>body</kanji> of the <kanji>lineage</kanji> is part of a bigger system. Add <jp>的</jp> to it, and you have <vocabulary>systematic</vocabulary>.
Reading Mnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.
Context 1-EN: We are offering systematic Japanese learning material.
Context 1-JP: <jp>私達は、体系的な日本語学習教材を提供しています。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: Something that's <kanji>flat</kanji> and <kanji>equal</kanji> to everything around it, all those flat things around it, are <vocabulary>average</vocabulary>. They're the <vocabulary>mean</vocabulary> (same as average).
Reading Mnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.
Context 1-EN: The average grade for 2014’s National Center Test for University Admissions was revealed.
Context 1-JP: <jp>2014年のセンター試験の平均点が出ました。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: A <kanji>sand</kanji> <kanji>sugar</kanji> is just <vocabulary>sugar</vocabulary>.  Nom nom nom, sugar.
Reading Mnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.
Context 1-EN: Brown sugar is called sotou in Japanese and it’s different from muscovado sugar.
Context 1-JP: <jp>ブラウンシュガーは日本語では粗糖と呼ばれ、黒砂糖とは区別されます。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: If a <jp>奴</jp> is just some dude or some guy, adding a <jp>ら</jp> on there makes it plural. Now it's <vocabulary>those dudes</vocabulary> or <vocabulary>those guys</vocabulary>.
Reading Mnemonic: The reading comes from <jp>奴</jp>.
Context 1-EN: Those guys are bathing and relaxing in the sun while we are working.
Context 1-JP: <jp>奴ら、俺たちは働いてるってのに、呑気に日光浴なんかしてやがるぜ。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: A <kanji>leak</kanji> of <kanji>water</kanji> is a <vocabulary>water leakage</vocabulary>.
Reading Mnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.
Context 1-EN: No matter how expensive it is, we should buy the water leakage sensor.
Context 1-JP: <jp>どんなに値段が高くても、その漏水検出器を買うべきだと思います。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: <kanji>Eternity</kanji> is a <kanji>long time</kanji>... as in <vocabulary>forever</vocabulary>. This word has to do with an actual forever. So, like, forever. Not like an "oh man I haven't done that in forever," because if you've done something before, it's not forever. This is forever for realsies.
Reading Mnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.
Context 1-EN: I’ve removed my armpit hair permanently, so my armpits are very smooth now.
Context 1-JP: <jp>脇毛を永久脱毛したから、今脇はツルツルだよ。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: The <kanji>previous</kanji> <kanji>extent</kanji> of time was <vocabulary>a while ago</vocabulary>. Just think to a previous extent of time that was indeed a while ago, now, associate!
Reading Mnemonic: The reading is the words <jp>先</jp> and <jp>程</jp>, put together.
Context 1-EN: I read the letter from you some time ago.
Context 1-JP: <jp>先程あなたからの手紙を読ませて頂きました。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: You know that <jp>旅行</jp> is a <kanji>trip</kanji>. The other part is <kanji>new</kanji> <kanji>marriage</kanji>. What's the trip you go on after a new marriage? The <vocabulary>honeymoon</vocabulary>!
Reading Mnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.
Context 1-EN: I can’t wait to go to Hawaii for my honeymoon! Yen is high, so I’m going to spend all my money on shopping. Haha.
Context 1-JP: <jp>新婚旅行でハワイに行くのが待ちきれないよ〜。円高の恩恵にあやかって、お金使い果たすぐらい買い物しまくるつもり！笑</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: You are <kanji>poor</kanji> and money / food is very <kanji>scarce</kanji> for you, making you <vocabulary>poor</vocabulary>.
Reading Mnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.
Context 1-EN: Salmon is a really materialistic girl. When she found out that Fugu didn’t have as much money as he said he did, she called him poor and left him.
Context 1-JP: <jp>サーモンって本当に物欲が強い女性だよね。フグが言ってるほどお金持って無いって知った途端、彼のこと貧乏って呼んで、振っちゃったんだもんね。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: The <kanji>lineage</kanji> of the <kanji>sun</kanji> (<jp>太陽</jp>) is that of everything surrounding it. This is the <vocabulary>solar system</vocabulary>.
Reading Mnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well. Will help to know <jp>太陽</jp>.
Context 1-EN: How many planets does the solar system have?
Context 1-JP: <jp>太陽系には惑星はいくつあるんだっけ？</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: If <jp>出版</jp> is <kanji>publishing</kanji>, then the verb vocab version is <vocabulary>to publish</vocabulary>.
Reading Mnemonic: The reading comes from <jp>出版</jp>, so if you know that you know this. Also, it's just the kanji readings too, so no problemo for a person like you, I'm sure.
Context 1-EN: Although he is a famous fiction writer, he sometimes self-publishes his books.
Context 1-JP: <jp>彼は有名な小説家だが、時々自費出版することもあるんだよ。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: Another way to say <vocabulary>to shut</vocabulary> or <vocabulary>to close</vocabulary>. A verb version of the kanji <jp>閉</jp>.
Reading Mnemonic: The reading is different from, say, <jp>閉める</jp> or <jp>しまる</jp>. Instead, the reading is <jp>とじる</jp>. Why? Because you shut your <reading>toe</reading> (<jp>と</jp>) in the door because it sheared off the hinges and out of control.
Context 1-EN: She shut the laptop, stretched her arms, and yawned.
Context 1-JP: <jp>彼女はノートパソコンを閉じて、両腕を伸ばし、欠伸をした。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: <jp>直接</jp> is <kanji>direct</kanji>. Add <jp>的</jp> to the mix and you have <vocabulary>directly</vocabulary>.
Reading Mnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well. Will help if you know <jp>直接</jp> already.
Context 1-EN: Fortunately, our family didn't take any direct damage from the huge earthquake or the tsunami in Japan.
Context 1-JP: <jp>幸運なことに、私の家族はあの日本の大地震や大津波による直接的な被害は受けませんでした。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: A <kanji>street</kanji> <kanji>road</kanji> is as wide as a street plus a road combined together. So cool! So wide! It's a <vocabulary>highway</vocabulary>!
Reading Mnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well. It uses the <jp>かい</jp> reading (not the <jp>がい</jp>) because it's at the beginning of the word.
Context 1-EN: Tokai-do Road, Nakasen-do Road, Nikko-kaido Road, Koshu-kaido Road, and Oshu-kaido Road are called Gokaido, which were the five principal routes used during the Edo period.
Context 1-JP: <jp>東海道、中山道、日光街道、甲州街道、奥州街道は、五街道と呼ばれ、江戸時代の五大陸上交通路であった。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.
Reading Mnemonic: The reading is the same as the one you learned with the kanji. OH <reading>HAI</reading> THERE LUNG. OH HAI THERE YOU.
Context 1-EN: Pulmonary pneumothorax is also known as handsome guy disease in Japan.
Context 1-JP: <jp>肺気胸は日本ではイケメン病としても知られている。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: That's very <kanji>odd</kanji> and <kanji>strange</kanji>, making it <vocabulary>odd</vocabulary> and <vocabulary>strange</vocabulary>.
Reading Mnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.
Context 1-EN: I’m not sure if it was because this summer was unusually hot, but a strange rash broke out on my chest.
Context 1-JP: <jp>今年の夏が例年になく暑かったせいなのかは分かりませんが、奇妙な発疹が胸に出ましてね。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: The <kanji>virtue</kanji> <kanji>island</kanji> <kanji>prefecture</kanji> is <vocabulary>Tokushima prefecture</vocabulary>. The reading will give away the meaning of this one, so long as you knew "prefecture."
Reading Mnemonic: The readings are the ones you learned with the individual kanji. Put them together and you'll know this is <vocabulary>Tokushima Prefecture</vocabulary>.
Context 1-EN: Governor, in what ways would you change Tokushima Prefecture? I like things just the way they are.
Context 1-JP: <jp>知事は、徳島県をどういう風に変えていくおつもりですか？私は今のままがいいと思うのですが。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: <kanji>Random</kanji> <kanji>expense</kanji>s are <vocabulary>miscellaneous expenses</vocabulary>. Not actually random, but they feel that way.
Reading Mnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own. The <jp>ざつ</jp> goes to <jp>ざっ</jp> and the <jp>ひ</jp> goes to <jp>ぴ</jp>, making it into a dumb sounding word, like "zappy" (<jp>ざっぴ</jp>), so you can think about how some of your miscellaneous expenses were on zappy items.
Context 1-EN: What is the average cost of a Japanese college student’s food and miscellaneous expenses?
Context 1-JP: <jp>日本の大学生の食費と雑費の平均はいくらぐらいですか。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.
Reading Mnemonic:
Since this word is made up of a single kanji, it probably uses the kun'yomi reading. You did not learn this reading, so here's a mnemonic to help you to remember: 

When you get hit in the face with a board, it hurts. It is very <reading><jp>痛</jp></reading> (<jp>いた</jp>).
Context 1-EN: I posted some comments on a forum about baseball on 2chan, but I was told it was the wrong board.
Context 1-JP: <jp>2chの野球板に書き込みをしたんですが、板違いだと言われてしまいました。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: <kanji>Do</kanji> you <kanji>fat</kanji> <kanji>al</kanji>... is <vocabulary>fatal</vocabulary>!
Reading Mnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.
Context 1-EN: The scandal with his student was fatal to his teaching career.
Context 1-JP: <jp>生徒とのスキャンダルは、彼の教師生命にとって致命的でした。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.
Reading Mnemonic: Since this word is made up of a single kanji, it probably uses the kun'yomi reading. You did not learn this reading, so here's a mnemonic to help you to remember: If you walk around on the beach, you'll get <vocabulary>sand</vocabulary> in your shoes <reading>sooner</reading> (<jp>すな</jp>) or later.
Context 1-EN: It reminds me of the sand castle that you and I made on beach when we were little.
Context 1-JP: <jp>小さい頃、あなたとビーチで作った砂のお城を思い出します。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: <kanji>Ripen</kanji>ed <kanji>language</kanji>s are words that have taken some time to come into their form. They ripened up, starting with just one kanji, but then became two, or three, or more. That is a <vocabulary>compound word</vocabulary> or <vocabulary>compound kanji</vocabulary>. You know that "jukugo" thing I talk about so much? That's this!
Reading Mnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.
Context 1-EN: I just learned that compound word yesterday.
Context 1-JP: <jp>昨日その熟語を学んだところです。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: The one who <kanji>oversee</kanji>s and <kanji>coach</kanji>es is the one who gives the <vocabulary>supervision</vocabulary> and <vocabulary>direction</vocabulary>. I see it all! I coach!
Reading Mnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.
Context 1-EN: I can’t remember the name of that movie director. What was his name? It’s on the tip of my tongue though. Uhg, crap!
Context 1-JP: <jp>あの映画監督の名前が思い出せないんだけど。何て名前だっけ。もうここまで出かかってるんだけどな。あー、気持ち悪い！</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: The <kanji>prime minister</kanji> (<jp>総理</jp>) <kanji>minister</kanji> is the official word for the <vocabulary>prime minister</vocabulary>.
Reading Mnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own. Will help to know the words <jp>総理</jp> and <jp>大臣</jp> from previous levels.
Context 1-EN: Hey y’all. Prime Minister Koichi is in da house, yo! Check it out!
Context 1-JP: <jp>よぉみんな！コウイチ総理大臣がここに登場だぜ！チェケラ！</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: If you have a <kanji>tenacious</kanji> <kanji>writing brush</kanji>, you are doing a lot of <vocabulary>writing</vocabulary>. Also, if you <vocabulary>write for a magazine</vocabulary> you probably write a ton too, because they have to come out with new issues every week or month.
Reading Mnemonic: The <jp>執</jp> is a little altered, where <jp>しつ</jp> is shortened to <jp>しっ</jp>. You've seen this kind of thing before, so just keep this shortening pattern in mind and you'll be a-okay!
Context 1-EN: When was the last time you wrote a short story?
Context 1-JP: <jp>最後に短編小説を執筆したのはいつですか？</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: A <kanji>cherry tree</kanji> can create a <vocabulary>cherry</vocabulary>. This is what this word is.
Reading Mnemonic: The reading comes from the kanji.
Context 1-EN: These cherries are ridiculously tasty.
Context 1-JP: <jp>この桜んぼ、やばいくらい美味しいんだけど。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: When you've <kanji>finish</kanji>ed <kanji>solv</kanji>ing something, you've come to a point of <vocabulary>comprehension</vocabulary> and <vocabulary>understanding</vocabulary>. Also, used in (often radio) communication to signify you know what's up. It's like saying "<vocabulary>roger</vocabulary>!"
Reading Mnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.
Context 1-EN: He expressed his understanding with a weak nod and walked away.
Context 1-JP: <jp>彼は弱々しいうなずいて了解の意を示して、立ち去った。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: <kanji>Zero</kanji> <kanji>o'clock</kanji> is 0:00. That's <vocabulary>midnight</vocabulary> or <vocabulary>twelve o'clock</vocabulary>.
Reading Mnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.
Context 1-EN: I saw her walking really fast downtown by herself around midnight.
Context 1-JP: <jp>零時頃、彼女が町中を一人で猛スピードで歩いているのを見かけました。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: Strangely, <kanji>cherry tree</kanji> <kanji>meat</kanji> isn't just some kind of cherry steak... it's <vocabulary>horse meat</vocabulary>. Hopefully you'll just remember that due to the strangeness of this word's kanji.
Reading Mnemonic: The reading is the words <jp>桜</jp> and <jp>肉</jp> put together into one horse steak of a word.
Context 1-EN: You should come with me to the horse meat party. It’s going to be hip.
Context 1-JP: <jp>お前も一緒に桜肉パーティーに来いよ。イカしたパーティーになるぜ。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: Your <kanji>lifespan</kanji> is your <kanji>fate</kanji> and will show you how long your <vocabulary>lifespan</vocabulary> is.
Reading Mnemonic: You did learn the reading of <jp>寿</jp>, but the reading for <jp>命</jp> is an exception. When you think of a lifespan, think of how that affects everyone. Me, you... well, just those things. Combine them both into <reading>myou</reading> (<jp>みょう</jp>). That is who the lifespan affects. Myou!
Context 1-EN: My phone battery’s lifespan is getting shorter.
Context 1-JP: <jp>携帯の電池の寿命が短くなってきてるんだけど。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: A <kanji>fishing</kanji> <kanji>boat</kanji> is a <vocabulary>fishing boat</vocabulary>.
Reading Mnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.
Context 1-EN: I had my fishing boat stolen last night.
Context 1-JP: <jp>昨夜漁船を盗まれました。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: <kanji>No</kanji>! I will not <kanji>determine</kanji> that. I refuse. I am in <vocabulary>denial</vocabulary>.
Reading Mnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.
Context 1-EN: The actress denied that she was on a diet.
Context 1-JP: <jp>その女優はダイエット中であることを否定した。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: <kanji>Odd</kanji> <kanji>numbers</kanji> are <vocabulary>odd numbers</vocabulary> (as in, 1, 3, 5, 7, though they are a bit strange as well).
Reading Mnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.
Context 1-EN: Odd numbers are numbers that cannot be divided by two.
Context 1-JP: <jp>奇数とは2で割り切れない数字のことです。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: The <kanji>thing</kanji>s that are <kanji>weave</kanji>d are, essentially, just <vocabulary>cloth</vocabulary> or <vocabulary>fabric</vocabulary>.
Reading Mnemonic: The readings are the kun'yomi readings. With <jp>織</jp> you can pull the reading from <jp>織る</jp>. With <jp>物</jp> you've probably seen it enough to know that it's often <jp>もの</jp> and not <jp>ぶつ</jp>. Just think of a piece of <vocabulary>cloth</vocabulary> that is <reading>mono</reading>chrome.
Context 1-EN: I’m majoring in politics, but somehow I started working for a fabric company.
Context 1-JP: <jp>政治学が専門なのですが、何故か織物会社に就職しました。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: A <kanji>flavor</kanji> that makes foods <kanji>boisterous</kanji> is a great flavor. In this case, it's the flavor of <vocabulary>miso</vocabulary>, which goes in a lot of Japanese dishes, and certainly does make the flavor of things boisterous.
Reading Mnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.
Context 1-EN: Miso and soy sauce are essential for a Japanese-style meal.
Context 1-JP: <jp>味噌と醤油は和食には欠かせません。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: <kanji>Fix</kanji> the <kanji>diameter</kanji>. It is the wrong diameter and must be a new <vocabulary>diameter</vocabulary>. Test it now, what's the <vocabulary>diameter</vocabulary>?
Reading Mnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.
Context 1-EN: A new, giant 100 foot in diameter species of jellyfish oozed on the beach.
Context 1-JP: <jp>直径100フィートもある巨大な新種のクラゲが、ビーチをドロドロにしてしまいました。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: Remember how <jp>驚く</jp> is "to be surprised"? This is when you are surprising someone else, doing the surprising, making this word <vocabulary>to surprise</vocabulary> or <vocabulary>to shock</vocabulary>.
Reading Mnemonic: The reading comes from <jp>驚く</jp>. Don't be surprised if you remember the reading of this word because of your past knowledge.
Context 1-EN: The 23-year-old new recruit surprised everyone who works with him by marrying the 82-year-old CEO.
Context 1-JP: <jp>23歳の新入社員は82歳のCEOと結婚して、一緒に仕事をする人全員を驚かした。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: Your <kanji>ancestor</kanji> <kanji>father</kanji> isn't your father, it's the father that came before your father's generation, your <vocabulary>grandfather</vocabulary>.
Reading Mnemonic: The reading is all on'yomi, which is great for <jp>祖</jp> but not as great for <jp>父</jp>. To remember that this <jp>父</jp> is <jp>ふ</jp>, just think about how much of a <reading>foo</reading>l (<jp>ふ</jp>) your grandfather was, even if he wasn't.
Context 1-EN: Ummm... what can I say? My grandpa is just a moody kind of a guy. He has highs and he has lows. So, don’t even bother him.
Context 1-JP: <jp>う〜ん、何て言ったらいいのかな。僕の祖父は単なる気分屋なんだよね。機嫌がいい時もあれば、悪い時もあるっていうか。だから、あんまり気にしないで。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: A <kanji>bribe</kanji> <kanji>bribe</kanji> is a <vocabulary>bribe</vocabulary>.
Reading Mnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.
Context 1-EN: It’s impossible to bribe him with anything other than a Big Mac.
Context 1-JP: <jp> 彼にはビッグマック以外の賄賂は効かないよ。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: A <kanji>mistake</kanji> in <kanji>use</kanji> is a <vocabulary>misuse</vocabulary>.
Reading Mnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.
Context 1-EN: Misuse of medicine can be fatal.
Context 1-JP: <jp>薬の誤用は命に関わることがあります。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: You <kanji>carve</kanji> then you <kanji>carve</kanji> again. So much carving until, wait, wow, it looks like something! All that carving became a <vocabulary>sculpture</vocabulary>!
Reading Mnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.
Context 1-EN: I dropped the sculpture and it broke in half.
Context 1-JP: <jp>彫刻を落として、真っ二つに割ってしまいました。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: In a <kanji>copper</kanji> <kanji>mountain</kanji> you go in and make a <vocabulary>copper mine</vocabulary>.
Reading Mnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. The 山 reading is ざん instead of さん because of rendaku.
Context 1-EN: In Japan, copper mines have been closing one after another.
Context 1-JP: <jp>日本では、銅山は次々に閉山していっています。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: An <kanji>omen</kanji> for the <kanji>climate</kanji> of things is a <vocabulary>sign</vocabulary> or <vocabulary>indication</vocabulary> of change. If there's an omen, there's going to be a sign as well.
Reading Mnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.
Context 1-EN: She told me that she had symptoms of diarrhea and rushed into the bathroom.
Context 1-JP: <jp>彼女は、私に下痢の兆候がきたと告げるやいなや、トイレに駆け込んでいった。</jp>

Meaning: The Next Month,Next Month,The Following Month
Meaning Mnemonic: <kanji>The next</kanji> <kanji>moon</kanji> refers to <vocabulary>the next month</vocabulary>.
Reading Mnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.
Context 1-EN: He is moving to the small house with the yellow door next month.
Context 1-JP: <jp>彼は翌月黄色いドアがある小さな家に引っ越しています。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: <jp>肺</jp> is <kanji>lung</kanji>, <jp>がん</jp> is "cancer," I suppose because you want it <reading>gone</reading> (<jp>がん</jp>) from you. That makes this word <vocabulary>lung cancer</vocabulary>, which, with all the smoking in Japan, happens a decent amount.
Reading Mnemonic: The reading is the same as what you learned with the kanji.
Context 1-EN: I really understand what you’re going through because I also have lung cancer.
Context 1-JP: <jp>君の辛さはすごく分かるよ。僕も肺がんなんだ。</jp>

Meaning: To Kill Off,To Let Die Out
Meaning Mnemonic: <jp>絶える</jp> is "to die out." <jp>絶やす</jp> is "<vocabulary>to kill off</vocabulary>." You know this because if something is to die off, you'd say "no." But if you're the one doing the killing off, you'd say <reading>yes</reading> (<jp>やす</jp>).
Reading Mnemonic: The reading comes from <jp>絶える</jp>.
Context 1-EN: Make sure the fire doesn’t go out during the night.
Context 1-JP: <jp>夜の間、火を絶やさないように気をつけるんだぞ。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: It was <kanji>previously</kanji> <kanji>decide</kanji>d, which means it's been <vocabulary>decided</vocabulary> and <vocabulary>settled</vocabulary>.
Reading Mnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.
Context 1-EN: I think that applying for post-conviction relief may be a possibility in your case.
Context 1-JP: <jp>あなたのケースでは、既決囚救済制度が適用される可能性もなきにしもあらずだと思います。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: If you take a<kanji>part</kanji> and <kanji>detach</kanji> it from the group into its own separate group, that's just <vocabulary>segregation</vocabulary>, isn't it?
Reading Mnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.
Context 1-EN: I’m going to google how to separate cream from milk.
Context 1-JP: <jp>クリームを牛乳から分離させる方法をググってみるよ。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: Something that is in a <kanji>powder</kanji> <kanji>condition</kanji> is something that has been <vocabulary>powdered</vocabulary>. Puff!
Reading Mnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.
Context 1-EN: I have a fresh red hot chili pepper but I want powdered chili pepper and I’m not sure how to do that.
Context 1-JP: <jp>新鮮な鷹の爪があるので粉状の唐辛子にしたいなと思っているんですが、やり方がよく分かりません。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: The <kanji>original</kanji> <kanji>oil</kanji> is oil in its original state. That is <vocabulary>crude oil</vocabulary>.
Reading Mnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.
Context 1-EN: The price of crude oil is going to keep rising.
Context 1-JP: <jp>原油の値段は上がり続けている。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: A <kanji>mistake</kanji> in what you <kanji>solve</kanji>... wow, sorry, I thought I was supposed to solve this, not that. What a terrible <vocabulary>misunderstanding</vocabulary>.
Reading Mnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.
Context 1-EN: You’ve got the wrong idea. She’s my older sister.
Context 1-JP: <jp>君は誤解しているよ。あれは俺の姉貴だよ。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: An <kanji>English</kanji> <kanji>brave</kanji> person. Okay, there are probably other kanji meanings that aren't as common being put into effect here, but if you just think about this as King Arthur, an English brave person, then you can get the meaning of this word. King Arthur is probably England's most well known <vocabulary>hero</vocabulary>.
Reading Mnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.
Context 1-EN: This phrase is quoted from a book about heroes.
Context 1-JP: <jp>この言葉は、英雄たちについて書かれたとある本からの引用です。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: An <kanji>all</kanji> <kanji>loss</kanji> is when you lose it all. It is a <vocabulary>total loss</vocabulary>.
Reading Mnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.
Context 1-EN: If it turns out that the car is a total loss, many insurance companies will not pay the full repair cost.
Context 1-JP: <jp>車が全損してしまった場合、修理代は保険で全額支払われないことが多いです。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: <kanji>Deposit</kanji> your <kanji>gold</kanji> here in the bank. When you do that, it is a <vocabulary>bank deposit</vocabulary>.
Reading Mnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.
Context 1-EN: He deposits all the money he earns from raising scallops.
Context 1-JP: <jp>彼は帆立の養殖で稼いだ金は全て預金している。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: It has <kanji>become</kanji> that we <kanji>agree</kanji>. We have <vocabulary>agreement</vocabulary>!
Reading Mnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.
Context 1-EN: Do you support Japan accepting new immigrants?
Context 1-JP: <jp>日本が新たな移民を受け入れることには賛成ですか。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.
Reading Mnemonic: The reading is the same as what you learned with the kanji.
Context 1-EN: The proverb "Don’t count your chickens before they hatch" is "Don’t assume you can grab a tanuki" in Japanese.
Context 1-JP: <jp>「卵がかえる前にひなを数えるな」という諺は、日本語では「とらぬ狸の皮算用をするな」です。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: <jp>撮影</jp> is <kanji>photography</kanji>. <jp>禁止</jp> is <kanji>prohibition</kanji>. So if photography is prohibited, then we can assume there's a <vocabulary>no photos</vocabulary> or <vocabulary>no photos allowed</vocabulary> rule in place.
Reading Mnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own. Will help to know the words <jp>撮影</jp> and <jp>禁止</jp>.
Context 1-EN: Photography and video recordings are prohibited for Parents’ Day at this kindergarten.
Context 1-JP: <jp>この幼稚園では、子どもたちのお遊戯会は撮影禁止です。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: A <kanji>punish</kanji> <kanji>penalty</kanji> is a <vocabulary>punishment</vocabulary>.
Reading Mnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.
Context 1-EN: In order to root out crime, I think we should restore all the brutal punishments, like burning people at the stake.
Context 1-JP: <jp>犯罪を根絶するには、火あぶりの刑みたいな残酷な刑罰を全部復活させるべきだと思うね。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: If <jp>遺伝</jp> is <kanji>heredity</kanji> and you pass your heredity to your <kanji>child</kanji>, how is it being passed? Via <vocabulary>genes</vocabulary>, of course.
Reading Mnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.
Context 1-EN: I’m wondering if they really want to get the paternity test done.
Context 1-JP: <jp>本当に彼らは父親を鑑定する遺伝子検査を受けたいんでしょうか。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: The kanji is <kanji>descend</kanji>, but this verb vocab word is <vocabulary>to get off</vocabulary>, as in, to get off the train, or to get out of the car. If you think about trains back in the day, you had to descend down to the platform to get out of them, which is how this word became what it is. You know that this word is the "to get off" word because once you get off the train, you enter the <reading>real</reading> (<jp>りる</jp>) world, where hardships are real and not as comfy as the train.
Reading Mnemonic: The reading is unlike anything you've seen with this kanji. Just think about how you have <vocabulary>to get off</vocabulary> at <reading>O</reading>-station. None of the other letters are your stop. Just <reading>O</reading>-Station (<jp>お</jp>).
Context 1-EN: The woman I thought was his wife was actually a spy and jumped off the train.
Context 1-JP: <jp>彼の奥さんだと思っていた女性が実はスパイでね、電車から飛び降りたんだよ。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: A dancing (<jp>舞踏</jp>) <kanji>meet</kanji> is when you all get together to do dancing, the kind that's like "step step swing" (or whatever). This is a <vocabulary>ball</vocabulary> or <vocabulary>dance</vocabulary>.
Reading Mnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.
Context 1-EN: For this dance, I’m thinking of wearing a brighter color dress than the last time.
Context 1-JP: <jp>今回の舞踏会には、前回よりも明るい色のドレスを着て行くつもりです。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: Because the hiragana ends with an <jp>う</jp> sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means <kanji>accumulate</kanji> and the verb version is <vocabulary>to accumulate</vocabulary>.
Reading Mnemonic: If something accumulates, you can start with one, but you need at least <reading>two</reading> (<jp>つ</jp>) things to say it has accumulated. If you don't, then there's nothing accumulating at all.
Context 1-EN: You don’t have to drastically decrease the amount of food you normally eat to lose weight. It is more important to have a balanced, healthy diet. It’s said every little bit counts.
Context 1-JP: <jp>体重を減らすために、日常の食事の量を極端に減らす必要はないよ。それよりも、バランスの良い、健康な食事を取ることの方が重要だ。ちりも積もれば山となるって言うじゃないか。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: Did you know that the <kanji>mountain</kanji> that is <kanji>rich</kanji> in <kanji>samurai</kanji> happens to be Japan's most famous mountain? It makes sense considering samurai are probably Japan's most famous thing as well. Combine the two most famous things and you have <vocabulary>Mt Fuji</vocabulary> (or <vocabulary>Mount Fuji</vocabulary> if you'd rather write it that way).
Reading Mnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.
Context 1-EN: Koichi: I am getting freaked out about climbing Mt. Fuji tomorrow. Viet: I know, I know. It’s freaking me out too.
Context 1-JP: <jp>コウイチ：明日富士山に登るなんて、もう気が狂っちゃいそうだよ。 ビエト：分かる分かる。俺もめちゃくちゃ不安。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: In the <kanji>body</kanji>, liquids <kanji>accumulate</kanji>. It can be the body of a cup, a body of a bucket, or the body of your body. Whatever it is, this body accumulation represents the <vocabulary>volume</vocabulary> of liquid in your body.
Reading Mnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.
Context 1-EN: My dad told me to measure the volume of our garage, but I don’t know why. It seems kind of weird to me.
Context 1-JP: <jp>父さんにガレージの体積を測るように言われたんだけど、理由は知らないよ。何か変だよね。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: If you <kanji>cut</kanji> someone from the <kanji>backside</kanji> you're doing a backstabbing, making this word <vocabulary>to backstab</vocabulary> or <vocabulary>to betray</vocabulary>.
Reading Mnemonic: The reading is <jp>裏</jp> plus <jp>切る</jp> put together into one word.
Context 1-EN: She betrayed me and I’m feeling depressed.
Context 1-JP: <jp>彼女に裏切られて落ち込んでいるんです。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: When you <kanji>stand</kanji> up out of the <kanji>nest</kanji>, you're getting ready to leave it. Your mother may be sad about this, but this means it's time to <vocabulary>leave the nest</vocabulary> and <vocabulary>become independent</vocabulary>.
Reading Mnemonic: The readings are from the words <jp>巣</jp> and <jp>立つ</jp> put together.
Context 1-EN: Why do birds leave the nest before they can fly?
Context 1-JP: <jp>どうして鳥は飛べるようになる前に巣立ちをするのですか。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: Give a <kanji>coin</kanji> and get <kanji>hot water</kanji>. So you hand over a coin and then you get hot water in the form of a bath. It's a bath for anyone willing to pay, making it a <vocabulary>public bath</vocabulary>.
Reading Mnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You don't know the on'yomi reading of <jp>湯</jp>, though, so just think about how when you get in the <vocabulary>public bath</vocabulary>, you're in <reading>To</reading>kyo (<jp>とう</jp>), because there are a lot of public baths in Japan, and Tokyo is the most well known city there.
Context 1-EN: My grandfather starts his day by going to a public bath.
Context 1-JP: <jp>祖父の一日は、銭湯から始まります。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: A <kanji>dirty</kanji> <kanji>point</kanji> is a little point of dirtiness on something. This is a <vocabulary>stain</vocabulary> or <vocabulary>smudge</vocabulary>.
Reading Mnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.
Context 1-EN: A disgrace in life is also called dark history in Japanese.
Context 1-JP: <jp>人生の汚点は日本語では黒歴史とも呼ばれる。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: If <jp>購読</jp> is a <kanji>subscription</kanji>, then the verb vocab version would be <vocabulary>to subscribe</vocabulary>.
Reading Mnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.
Context 1-EN: It’s worth subscribing to this magazine.
Context 1-JP: <jp>その雑誌は購読する価値がありますよ。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: I would like to <kanji>say humbly</kanji> in this <kanji>crowded</kanji> place that I am going <vocabulary>to apply</vocabulary>. If there are a lot of other people applying, you feel humbled, so you say humbly you want to apply.
Reading Mnemonic: The readings come from <jp>申す</jp> and <jp>込む</jp>, stuck together... humbly.
Context 1-EN: I forgot to apply for the JLPT exam.
Context 1-JP: <jp>JLPTのテストに申し込むのを忘れてしまった。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: <jp>詰まる</jp> is "to be stuffed." So, if your <kanji>nose</kanji> is <kanji>stuffed</kanji>, then you have a <vocabulary>stuffy nose</vocabulary>.
Reading Mnemonic: The reading is <jp>鼻</jp> and <jp>詰まる</jp> put together. the <jp>詰まり</jp> is rendaku'd, probably because you're trying to say this word with a stuffy nose.
Context 1-EN: I’m suffering from a terrible fever and stuffy nose.
Context 1-JP: <jp>私は高熱と鼻詰まりに苦しんでいます。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: You <kanji>dance</kanji>, you <kanji>step</kanji>, you dance, you step. Good job! Now you're doing <vocabulary>dancing</vocabulary>.
Reading Mnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.
Context 1-EN: It was the first dance in six months.
Context 1-JP: <jp>半年ぶりの舞踏会でした。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: A <kanji>child</kanji> who is the <kanji>grandchild</kanji> of someone else is a <vocabulary>descendant</vocabulary> of that person.
Reading Mnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.
Context 1-EN: He is a descendant of the imperial family.
Context 1-JP: <jp>彼は宮家の子孫です。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: <kanji>Three</kanji> <kanji>cups of liquid</kanji> is <vocabulary>three cups of liquid</vocabulary>, or more simply, <vocabulary>three cups</vocabulary>.
Reading Mnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well. Just watch out for <jp>杯</jp>, which becomes <jp>ばい</jp> thanks to our old friend rendaku.
Context 1-EN: I was depressed at the time, so I chugged three glasses of beer.
Context 1-JP: <jp>その時ちょっとへこみ気味だったもんで、ビールを三杯一気飲みしちゃったんだよね。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: A <kanji>death</kanji> <kanji>punish</kanji>ment is the <vocabulary>death penalty</vocabulary>.
Reading Mnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.
Context 1-EN: The execution was delayed for five hours.
Context 1-JP: <jp>死刑執行は五時間も遅れました。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: The <kanji>first</kanji> <kanji>edition</kanji> is the <vocabulary>first edition</vocabulary>.
Reading Mnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.
Context 1-EN: The first edition of his novel sold out in six months.
Context 1-JP: <jp>彼の小説の初版は半年で売り切れた。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: <kanji>Inside</kanji> <kanji>spy</kanji>ing is when you get inside enemy territory and spy on them. This is <vocabulary>scouting</vocabulary> and <vocabulary>reconnaissance</vocabulary>.
Reading Mnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.
Context 1-EN: When do the police conduct their secret internal investigation?
Context 1-JP: <jp>警察はどんな時に内偵捜査をするのですか。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: Some kind of <kanji>sleep</kanji> <kanji>medicine</kanji>? That's <vocabulary>sleeping pills</vocabulary>.
Reading Mnemonic:
The reading is <jp>眠い</jp> plus <jp>薬</jp> put together in one ... zz zzzzzZZZzz
Just remember that <jp>くすり</jp> turns into <jp>ぐすり</jp> here because of rendaku.
Context 1-EN: Did you see that? I just dribbled around three defenders! I am the man! The orange juice with sleeping pills that I gave the other team worked perfectly!
Context 1-JP: <jp>おい、お前、今の見てたか？俺、今ドリブルで三人のバックを抜いたんだぜ！俺ってば、ほんと、最高！相手チームにあげた眠り薬入りのオレンジジュースがうまく効いてたみたいだな。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.
Reading Mnemonic:
Since this word is made up of a single kanji, it probably uses the kun'yomi reading. You did not learn this reading, so here's a mnemonic to help you: 

You are the <vocabulary>grandchild</vocabulary> of your grandfather. His favorite thing is to call you a <reading>maggo</reading>t (<jp>まご</jp>). Your grandfather was in the military and is very hard on you, maggot.
Context 1-EN: Hooking up the new computer is a cinch for my grandchild.
Context 1-JP: <jp>新しいコンピューターを接続することは、 私の孫にとってはお茶の子さいさいだ。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: The <kanji>same</kanji> <kanji>accompany</kanji> means you are in the same place as someone, and you are accompanying them. This word means <vocabulary>to accompany</vocabulary>. This is only used for accompanying people.
Reading Mnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.
Context 1-EN: I thought you would be accompanied by your wife today.
Context 1-JP: <jp>今日は奥さんが同伴するのかと思ってたよ。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: A <kanji>cut</kanji> <kanji>token</kanji> is a token you cut out from a sheet of paper into smaller sheets, and each of these pieces is a <vocabulary>ticket</vocabulary>.
Reading Mnemonic: The reading is <jp>切る</jp> cut short to <jp>きっ</jp>, then <jp>ふ</jp> rendaku'd to <jp>ぷ</jp>. It's a bit of a troublesome word, so concentrate on this now a bit so you can get it in the reviews.
Context 1-EN: You can buy tickets for that tour on site.
Context 1-JP: <jp>そのツアーの切符は、現地で購入することもできます。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: The <kanji>society</kanji> (<jp>社会</jp>) <kanji>party</kanji> is the <vocabulary>socialist party</vocabulary>.
Reading Mnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.
Context 1-EN: The Socialist Party’s statements don’t seem to be realistic.
Context 1-JP: <jp>社会党の主張は現実的ではないような気がする。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: After you <kanji>use</kanji> it you <kanji>throw away</kanji> it, making whatever it is you used a <vocabulary>disposable</vocabulary> item.
Reading Mnemonic: The reading comes from <jp>使う</jp> and <jp>捨てる</jp>, combined into one.
Context 1-EN: For me, disposable pocket warmers are indispensable in winter.
Context 1-JP: <jp>私にとって、使い捨てカイロは冬には無くてはならないものです。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: Your <kanji>surname</kanji> and your <kanji>name</kanji> put together create your <vocabulary>full name</vocabulary>.
Reading Mnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.
Context 1-EN: Please don’t use my full name.
Context 1-JP: <jp>私の姓名を使用しないでください。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: <kanji>Extend</kanji> the lens nice and <kanji>big</kanji> to <vocabulary>zoom</vocabulary> in on the subject, please.
Reading Mnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.
Context 1-EN: I enlarged the photo and found out my boyfriend’s nose hairs were sticking out. I was turned off.
Context 1-JP: <jp>写真を拡大した時に、彼氏の鼻毛が出てることを発見しちゃったんだよね。どん引きだったわ。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: A <kanji>home country</kanji> <kanji>translation</kanji> is a translation to your home country's language. Since this is a Japanese word, this translation would be a <vocabulary>translation into Japanese</vocabulary>.
Reading Mnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.
Context 1-EN: Have you already taken the Japanese version of the Lord of the Ring back to the library?
Context 1-JP: <jp>ロード・オブ・ザ・リングの邦訳、もう図書館に返却しちゃった？</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: <kanji>Vertical</kanji> <kanji>writing</kanji> is <vocabulary>vertical writing</vocabulary>. That's when you see Japanese and it's written top to bottom instead of sideways.
Reading Mnemonic: The readings are the reading you learned with the kanji <jp>縦</jp> and <jp>かき</jp> (changes to <jp>がき</jp>), though the <jp>き</jp> gets smushed inside the kanji, because it wants to be confusing like that.
Context 1-EN: I want to write compositions using vertical style writing.
Context 1-JP: <jp>文章を縦書にしたいんです。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: If you <kanji>attain</kanji> <kanji>above</kanji> it means you're up above everyone, and you're looking down on them. You have <vocabulary>supremacy</vocabulary>.
Reading Mnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.
Context 1-EN: He may be a smart guy who graduated at the top of his class from an elite university, but he is obviously a white supremacist and I hate that.
Context 1-JP: <jp>彼は名門大学を主席で卒業した頭のいい男性なんでしょうが、明らかに白人至上主義者なのでそこが嫌いなんですよ。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: An <kanji>imitation</kanji> of an <kanji>example</kanji> is the <vocabulary>exemplification</vocabulary> of something. It is also a <vocabulary>model</vocabulary> of the example of what you're making.
Reading Mnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.
Context 1-EN: I’ll follow your example.
Context 1-JP: <jp>君を模範としよう。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: <kanji>Wrap</kanji> and <kanji>surround</kanji> them. We are going to <vocabulary>siege</vocabulary> the enemy. This is <vocabulary>encirclement</vocabulary> around their base!
Reading Mnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.
Context 1-EN: The building will be surrounded by the police in a moment.
Context 1-JP: <jp>その建物はじきに警察に包囲されるでしょう。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: The kanji is <kanji>wild</kanji> and the verb is <vocabulary>to be stormy</vocabulary> or <vocabulary>to be rough</vocabulary>. If something is wild, like a storm or something, then it will be stormy and rough, after all.
Reading Mnemonic: The reading comes from the reading you learned with the kanji.
Context 1-EN: My hands will be rough as long as I’m a beauty artist, there’s nothing I can do about it.
Context 1-JP: <jp>美容師として働いている限りは、手が荒れるのはどうしようもありません。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: Remember <jp>狙い</jp> and how it means "aim"? Make that into a verb, and you have <vocabulary>to aim at</vocabulary>.
Reading Mnemonic: The reading comes from <jp>狙い</jp>, so if you know that you'll be able <vocabulary>to aim at</vocabulary> knowing this word's reading as well.
Context 1-EN: Just a word of advice, it looks like he’s aiming to take over your position.
Context 1-JP: <jp>一応忠告しておくと、奴はお前のポジションを狙ってるみたいだぞ。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: To <kanji>run alongside</kanji> the <kanji>line</kanji> (referring to the train line) means <vocabulary>along the train line</vocabulary>. What's along the train line? All kinds of things if you look carefully.
Reading Mnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.
Context 1-EN: My brother is living along the Keio Line.
Context 1-JP: <jp>私の弟は、京王沿線に住んでいます。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: <kanji>Foot</kanji> <kanji>traces</kanji> are <vocabulary>footprint</vocabulary>s.
Reading Mnemonic: The reading is the kun'yomi vocab readings of the kanji, put together.
Context 1-EN: When I saw a bear’s footprints in the snow, I tightly grasped the knife in my pocket.
Context 1-JP: <jp>雪の上に熊の足跡を見つけた瞬間、ポケットの中のナイフを握りしめました。</jp>
