Context 1-JP: <jp>最初は、どんなもんかなと思って湯豆腐を食べてみただけなんですが、そしたら好きになっちゃったんですよね。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: If you <kanji>reject</kanji> and <kanji>exclude</kanji> something, you are doing <vocabulary>exclusion</vocabulary> to it. You could also call this <vocabulary>removal</vocabulary>.
Reading Mnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.
Context 1-EN: Each sewage facility needs to meet sewage removal standards.
Context 1-JP: <jp>各下水道施設は、下水排除規準を満たす必要があります。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: The <kanji>damp</kanji> <kanji>earth</kanji> is where water seems to congregate, but not so much that there's a lake or ocean or anything like that. Just damp. This is a <vocabulary>wetlands</vocabulary>.
Reading Mnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.
Context 1-EN: If I am not mistaken, there are a lot of wetlands in Hokkaido, right?
Context 1-JP: <jp>確か、北海道には湿地が多いんだよね？</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: If you have <kanji>attain</kanji>ed <kanji>summer</kanji>, that must mean you finished out with the previous season and are going into summer. This is the <vocabulary>summer solstice</vocabulary>.
Reading Mnemonic:
You didn't learn this reading of <jp>夏</jp> with the kanji, so here's a mnemonic to help:

Just think about how cute little <reading>ge</reading>ckos (<jp>げ</jp>) start to come out into the open during the summer solstice. It's too cold for them to be out in the open before that, so if you look outside at the right time, you'll see geckos popping out of the ground all over the place!
Context 1-EN: My dad asked me if I knew what to call the eleventh day after the summer solstice, so I said triumphantly "hageshou," which literally means "baldness-symptom". He laughed and told me the correct answer was "hangeshou."
Context 1-JP: <jp>父に夏至から11日目のことを何と呼ぶか知っているかと聞かれたので、得意気に「ハゲ症」って答えたんですけど、それって「ハゲ頭の症状」って意味になるみたいで。父は笑って、正しい答えは「半夏生」だよって教えてくれましたけどね。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: A <kanji>medicine</kanji> can <kanji>heal</kanji>. This is <vocabulary>medical treatment</vocabulary>.
Reading Mnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.
Context 1-EN: I want to be a doctor in Japan, so I’m studying medical terminology now.
Context 1-JP: <jp>日本で医者になりたいので、今は医療用語を勉強しています。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: A <kanji>neighbor</kanji> <kanji>house</kanji> is a <vocabulary>neighboring house</vocabulary>. That house is right next to ours!
Reading Mnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.
Context 1-EN: It seems that the people in the neighboring house wipe their windows with newspapers.
Context 1-JP: <jp>隣家ではどうやら窓は新聞紙で拭くようです。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: <jp>駆ける</jp> is "to gallop" and <jp>込む</jp> is "to be crowded." If you gallop into someone and crowd them, you are going <vocabulary>to rush into</vocabulary> them.
Reading Mnemonic: The readings come from <jp>駆ける</jp> and <jp>込む</jp>.
Context 1-EN: I was rushing onto the last train, but the door closed before my eyes.
Context 1-JP: <jp>終電に駆け込み乗車をしようとしましたが、目の前でドアが閉まりました。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: A <kanji>leg</kanji> <kanji>book</kanji> is just the legs of a book. Not a whole book. It only contains the parts that walk around and move, not so much the descriptions (things that don't move). This kind of book is a <vocabulary>script</vocabulary> or <vocabulary>screenplay</vocabulary>. These "books" are focused on actions and things people say, which is why it's just the legs.
Reading Mnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.
Context 1-EN: What the other scripts weren’t able to do, his script did.
Context 1-JP: <jp>他の脚本では出来なかった事を、彼の脚本はやってのけたんだよ。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: If you <kanji>kill</kanji> <kanji>bacteria</kanji> you are performing <vocabulary>sterilization</vocabulary>. You're killing those bacteria.
Reading Mnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own. Watch out for the shortening.
Context 1-EN: What’s the best way to sterilize a bathroom?
Context 1-JP: <jp>トイレを殺菌する一番いい方法は何ですか？</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: I am <kanji>reliant</kanji> on you and I <kanji>trust</kanji> you. Therefore, I have a <vocabulary>request</vocabulary> for you that I'd like to <vocabulary>entrust</vocabulary> you with.
Reading Mnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.
Context 1-EN: Your request may be turned down, but it never hurts to ask.
Context 1-JP: <jp>依頼は断られちゃうかもしれないけど、聞くだけ聞いてみたら。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: If we <kanji>return</kanji> and <kanji>send back</kanji> things, we will have done a <vocabulary>return</vocabulary> or <vocabulary>restoration</vocabulary>.
Reading Mnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.
Context 1-EN: I didn’t know that the championship flag had to be returned every year.
Context 1-JP: <jp>優勝旗が毎年返還されなくちゃいけないなんて、知らなかったよ。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: The <kanji>tall</kanji> <kanji>rapids</kanji> are the <vocabulary>shallows</vocabulary>. I have no idea how this makes sense, but I suppose if the water is taller, it's not going to have as much rapids going on, meaning it's just <vocabulary>shallows</vocabulary> (but not too tall to become something else, like a lake, or whatever).
Reading Mnemonic: The reading comes from <jp>高い</jp> and the reading you learned for <jp>瀬</jp>.
Context 1-EN: The river is pretty shallow around here, so I’m sure you’ll reach the bottom.
Context 1-JP: <jp>この川はこの辺りは高瀬になってるから、きっと足が底に着くと思うよ。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: A <kanji>lodge</kanji> where you will stay <kanji>overnight</kanji> is <vocabulary>lodging</vocabulary>. It is where you will <vocabulary>stay the night</vocabulary>.
Reading Mnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.
Context 1-EN: I’m still searching for a lodging place for tonight.
Context 1-JP: <jp>まだ今夜の宿泊先を探しているんです。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: A <kanji>sick</kanji> <kanji>bed</kanji> is a <vocabulary>sickbed</vocabulary>. If you're in that bed, you're probably sick.
Reading Mnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.
Context 1-EN: He laid down on his sickbed, never to rise again.
Context 1-JP: <jp>彼は病床に臥してついにまた起ちません。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: A <kanji>buzzer</kanji> that will <kanji>call</kanji> you to the door is a <vocabulary>doorbell</vocabulary>.
Reading Mnemonic: The reading is <jp>呼ぶ</jp> and <jp>鈴</jp>'s reading, put together.
Context 1-EN: The doorbell rang while he was in the middle of pooping and he rushed to the door without wiping his butt.
Context 1-JP: <jp>大便の最中に呼び鈴が鳴り、男はお尻も拭かずに玄関へ急いだ。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: If <jp>払う</jp> is "to pay" then the noun version is a <vocabulary>payment</vocabulary>.
Reading Mnemonic: The reading comes from <jp>払う</jp>, so know that and it will pay forward your knowledge to this one.
Context 1-EN: We offer 5% off if you pay with cash.
Context 1-JP: <jp>現金払いにして頂けるなら、5%引きにさせて頂きます。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: <jp>埋める</jp> is "to bury." <jp>合わせる</jp> is "to unify together." If you bury somebody in order to unify them with you, you're almost certainly trying <vocabulary>to compensate for</vocabulary> something.
Reading Mnemonic: The readings come from <jp>埋める</jp> and <jp>合わせる</jp>. Combine them into one big happy word.
Context 1-EN: Can’t we make up for this loss in some way or another?
Context 1-JP: <jp>どうにかこの損失を埋め合わせることはできないだろうか。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: Remember how a <jp>年賀状</jp> is a new year's card? This is another kind of card/letter, but this time it's for an introduction (<jp>紹介</jp>), making it a <vocabulary>letter of introduction</vocabulary>.
Reading Mnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own. Will help to know <jp>紹介</jp> as well.
Context 1-EN: You need a referral letter from a doctor to make an appointment at this hospital.
Context 1-JP: <jp>この病院で予約をするには、お医者さんからの紹介状が要ります。</jp>

Meaning: To Spill Something,To Drop Something,To Shed Tears
Meaning Mnemonic: Because the hiragana ends with an <jp>う</jp> sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means <kanji>zero</kanji>, but the verb vocab version means <vocabulary>to spill something</vocabulary> or <vocabulary>to drop something</vocabulary>. Think of it this way, if you spill something, eventually it will reach <kanji>zero</kanji>.
Reading Mnemonic: Imagine a barrel of corn <reading>cob</reading>s, spilling and dropping out corn cobs, until they reach zero.
Context 1-EN: "Did you just spill coffee on the carpet?" "Oh no! Sorry." "If sorry fixed everything, we wouldn’t need the police!"
Context 1-JP: <jp>「あんた、今カーペットに珈琲を零したでしょう？」「しまった!ごめん!」「ごめんで済んだら警察はいらないわよ！」</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: <kanji>One-sided</kanji> <kanji>kana</kanji> is <vocabulary>katakana</vocabulary>. Might be easier to do the reading first on this one.
Reading Mnemonic: <jp>片</jp> is <jp>かた</jp>, and <jp>仮名</jp> is <jp>かな</jp>. Put them together to get <vocabulary>katakana</vocabulary>.
Context 1-EN: I know Hiragana, but I’m still trying to memorize Katakana.
Context 1-JP: <jp>平仮名は分かりますが、片仮名はまだ覚えきれていません。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.
Reading Mnemonic: The reading is the same as the one you learned with the kanji.
Context 1-EN: I just don’t want to beat old people at Go.
Context 1-JP: <jp>年寄りたちと碁は打ちたくないんだよね。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: An <kanji>electricity</kanji> <kanji>pillar</kanji> is a <vocabulary>telephone pole</vocabulary>. All those wires and telephone wires going to and from those telephone poles.
Reading Mnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.
Context 1-EN: I ran my car into a telephone pole today.
Context 1-JP: <jp>今日車を電柱にぶつけちゃったんだよね。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: <kanji>Two</kanji> <kanji>overnight</kanji>s is a <vocabulary>two night's stay</vocabulary>.
Reading Mnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.
Context 1-EN: My stepmother is asking if she can stay at our place for two nights, what do you think?
Context 1-JP: <jp>継母がうちに二泊泊めてくれって言ってるんだけど、どう思う？</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: <kanji>Shake</kanji> plus "to do" is the verb version of shake. That's <vocabulary>to shake</vocabulary> or <vocabulary>to rock</vocabulary> slowly.
Reading Mnemonic: The reading comes from <jp>揺る</jp>.
Context 1-EN: It seems that my uncle shook a tree with a beehive in it because he had never been stung by a bee and wanted to try it out.
Context 1-JP: <jp>僕の伯父さんは、今まで蜂に刺されたことがなくて、どんなものか試してみたかったから、蜂の巣がある木を揺すったんだそうです。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: A <kanji>medicine</kanji> <kanji>dose</kanji> <kanji>expert</kanji> is someone who knows exactly how much dose of each medicine you should be getting. The person who specializes in this is a <vocabulary>pharmacist</vocabulary>.
Reading Mnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.
Context 1-EN: I don’t think pharmacists really need to wear white coats.
Context 1-JP: <jp>薬剤師は別に白衣を着る必要はないと思うんだよな。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.
Reading Mnemonic: The reading is the same as what you learned with the kanji.
Context 1-EN: I couldn’t really see if he stepped on the base or not.
Context 1-JP: <jp>彼が塁を踏んだのかどうか、よく見えなかった。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: The kanji is <kanji>seal in</kanji>, but the vocab noun version is <vocabulary>seal</vocabulary>. This is simply a seal (not the water kind, the kind you use to seal something with).
Reading Mnemonic: The reading is the same as one of the readings you learned: <jp>ふう</jp>. Don't be a <reading>foo</reading>l, make sure you seal your envelopes.
Context 1-EN: I know I was just a 6-year-old kid, but I got so mad when my dad opened the envelope and read the letter from my friend without asking me first.
Context 1-JP: <jp>自分が六歳の子どもだってことは分かってたけど、父さんが勝手に封を開けて友達からの手紙を読んだことにはすごく腹が立ったわ。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.
Reading Mnemonic: The reading is the same as the one you learned with the kanji.
Context 1-EN: Don’t worry, my patient. I can immediately remove your appendix with the sharp blade of my surgical scalpel.
Context 1-JP: <jp>心配は要りませんよ、患者さん。私のこの手術用メスの鋭い刃で、すぐに盲腸を取ってあげますからね。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.
Reading Mnemonic: Look inside your <kanji>soul</kanji>. You see all the bits and bobs that make up your <vocabulary>soul</vocabulary> rolling around and around, being pushed by the Katamari <reading>Tamashii</reading> (<jp>たましい</jp>). He keeps your soul nice and big and safe!
Context 1-EN: The video about the little angel and the bacon deeply moved my soul.
Context 1-JP: <jp>小さな天使とベーコンのビデオを観て、魂が震えました。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: The kanji means <kanji>pay respects</kanji> but the verb is <vocabulary>to inquire</vocabulary>, <vocabulary>to hear</vocabulary>, or <vocabulary>to visit</vocabulary>. Basically this is a humble way to use any of these verbs. It's often used in a professional context.
Reading Mnemonic: Excuse me, I'd like <vocabulary>to inquire</vocabulary> about <reading>you, kaga</reading> (<jp>うかが</jp>). You're asking questions about Chairman Kaga, the ruler over the Iron Chef kingdom.
Context 1-EN: I’d love to stay here and hear his whole speech, but unfortunately I have to go.
Context 1-JP: <jp>残って最後まで彼の話を伺いたいのは山々なんですが、残念ながらどうしても行かなくてはいけないんです。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.
Reading Mnemonic: The reading is the same as the kanji reading you learned.
Context 1-EN: Although strawberries aren’t in season, they are used a lot for Christmas cake.
Context 1-JP: <jp>苺は旬ではありませんが、クリスマスケーキにたくさん使われます。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: A <kanji>go</kanji> <kanji>tray</kanji> is a tray for playing the game "go." This tray is a <vocabulary>go board</vocabulary>.
Reading Mnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.
Context 1-EN: That’s a false accusation. I didn’t break grandpa’s Go board.
Context 1-JP: <jp>濡れ衣だよ。じいちゃんの碁盤を壊したのは俺じゃないよ。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.
Reading Mnemonic: The reading is the one you learned with the kanji.
Context 1-EN: Does this gun have bullets in it?
Context 1-JP: <jp>この銃、弾入ってる？</jp>
Context 2-EN: Can I buy this firearm with a credit card?
Context 2-JP: <jp>こちらの銃は、クレジットカードで買えますか。</jp>
Context 3-EN: My mother found my gun in my room while I was out.
Context 3-JP: <jp>外出中に、部屋に置いてあった銃が母親に見つかってしまったんです。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: If you <kanji>plant</kanji> <kanji>wood</kanji> you are doing <vocabulary>tree planting</vocabulary>, since only trees are made of wood.
Reading Mnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.
Context 1-EN: My husband and I planted a sugar maple to commemorate our marriage.
Context 1-JP: <jp>結婚の記念として、主人と私はメープルシュガーの木を植樹しました。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: If you <kanji>concurrently</kanji> <kanji>use</kanji> one thing for multiple purposes, you're using something with a <vocabulary>combined use</vocabulary>. Something that is <vocabulary>serving two purposes</vocabulary>.
Reading Mnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.
Context 1-EN: I’d call this meal brunch.
Context 1-JP: <jp>この食事は朝昼兼用にします。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: I <kanji>steal</kanji> by <kanji>listen</kanji>ing to what people say. I do this by <vocabulary>wiretapping</vocabulary> their phone and <vocabulary>bugging</vocabulary> their homes.
Reading Mnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.
Context 1-EN: Someone bugged the Tofugu office, but we have no idea who or why.
Context 1-JP: <jp>誰かがTofuguのオフィスに盗聴器を仕掛けたのですが、私達は犯人も理由も分かりません。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.
Reading Mnemonic: The reading is the one you learned with the kanji.
Context 1-EN: The glow of fireflies is pleasant for anyone who watches.
Context 1-JP: <jp>蛍の光は、誰にとっても見ていて心地の良いものです。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.
Reading Mnemonic: The reading for the vocab version of this word is the same as <jp>岡</jp> which has the same meaning and the same reading. Lucky!
Context 1-EN: On my first day of driving a stick, my car stalled at the top of a hill.
Context 1-JP: <jp>初めてマニュアルで運転した時、丘のてっぺんでエンストしてしまいました。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: A <kanji>door</kanji> <kanji>shelf</kanji> is a shelf with a door on it. What kinds of shelves do you know of that have doors on them? How about <vocabulary>cupboard</vocabulary>s?
Reading Mnemonic: These readings are the ones you learned with the kanji.
Context 1-EN: I put the double A batteries that we bought today in the cupboard.
Context 1-JP: <jp>今日買った単三電池は戸棚の上に置いておいたよ。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: To <kanji>catch</kanji> and <kanji>seize</kanji> is <vocabulary>capture</vocabulary> and <vocabulary>seizure</vocabulary>.
Reading Mnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.
Context 1-EN: In this memo pad, I’ve kept notes on all my ideas for capturing titans.
Context 1-JP: <jp>このメモ帳に、巨人の捕獲についての思いついたことを全部メモしています。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: A <kanji>fist</kanji> that's like a <kanji>bone</kanji> (hard) is a fist that's clenched and ready to punch, making this a <vocabulary>clenched fist</vocabulary> or <vocabulary>knuckles</vocabulary>, if you want to get even bonier about it.
Reading Mnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. But <jp>拳</jp> doesn't use the one you learned, it uses <jp>げん</jp> instead. Just imagine someone clenching their fist at you. You gulp and say <jp>げん</jp> instead of <jp>けん</jp> out of fear.
Context 1-EN: My dad pretended to hit me with his fists clenched.
Context 1-JP: <jp>父は、僕に拳骨を食らわせるふりをしました。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: <jp>分裂</jp> means "<kanji>split</kanji>" or "<kanji>division</kanji>." The <kanji>nucleus</kanji> version of this split is <vocabulary>nuclear fission</vocabulary>.
Reading Mnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.
Context 1-EN: Can you make an easy-to-understand slide show on the process of nuclear fission?
Context 1-JP: <jp>核分裂の過程について、分かりやすいスライドショーを作ってもらえますか。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.
Reading Mnemonic: Since this word is made up of a single kanji, it probably uses the kun'yomi reading. You did not learn this reading, so here's a mnemonic to help you to remember: You make a <vocabulary>fist</vocabulary>. Why? Because she stole your corn on the cob. "<reading>Cob! She</reading> (<jp>こぶし</jp>) stole my cob!"
Context 1-EN: He cleaned the blood off his fist with his handkerchief.
Context 1-JP: <jp>彼は拳についた血をハンカチで拭いました。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: To <kanji>display</kanji> and <kanji>indicate</kanji> something is to put up a <vocabulary>notice</vocabulary> or <vocabulary>bulletin</vocabulary>.
Reading Mnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.
Context 1-EN: Whenever Aya sees that a restaurant put up a notice about shutting down for a holiday and there is some space left on the paper, she draws doodles there.
Context 1-JP: <jp>アヤは、レストランが臨時休業の掲示をしている紙に余白があるのを見つけては、そこに落書きをします。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: Take your <kanji>rope</kanji> and <kanji>stretch</kanji> it out to show where the cutoff is. This is when you <vocabulary>rope off</vocabulary> something. It shows your <vocabulary>territory</vocabulary> and <vocabulary>turf</vocabulary>. Don't cross this rope I've stretched out, it's my <vocabulary>domain</vocabulary>.
Reading Mnemonic: The reading is <jp>縄</jp> and <jp>張る</jp> put together into one word.
Context 1-EN: Sure enough, the place was Yakuza’s territory.
Context 1-JP: <jp>案の定、その場所はヤクザの縄張りだった。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: The <kanji>employ</kanji> <kanji>task</kanji> is <vocabulary>employment</vocabulary>.
Reading Mnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.
Context 1-EN: Many companies used to guarantee their workers a job for life, but that’s no longer a common thing.
Context 1-JP: <jp>かつては多くの会社が終身雇用を保障していましたが、今ではそれが当たり前では無くなっています。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: You already know that <jp>依頼</jp> means "request." What's a "request" <kanji>person</kanji>? It's someone who requests things from you. In other words, your <vocabulary>client</vocabulary>!
Reading Mnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.
Context 1-EN: If you had a little more patience, you could have found out who the client was.
Context 1-JP: <jp>もう少し我慢すれば、依頼人が誰だか分かったのに。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: <kanji>Wrap</kanji> up the <kanji>street</kanji> and take it away. I cut it apart with my <vocabulary>kitchen knife</vocabulary> (don't ask why this word comes from these kanji). Just imagine yourself using a kitchen knife to cut up the street so you can wrap it up and take it away.
Reading Mnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.
Context 1-EN: I killed a couple hours by sharpening my kitchen knife.
Context 1-JP: <jp>包丁を研いで二、三時間潰しました。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: <kanji>Set aside</kanji> and <kanji>put</kanji> what you'll need to get the job done over there. These are the <vocabulary>measures</vocabulary> and <vocabulary>steps</vocabulary> we're taking to make sure things get done properly.
Reading Mnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.
Context 1-EN: What do you think of the next steps for that student?
Context 1-JP: <jp>その生徒の今後の措置についてはどうお考えですか。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: If you <kanji>dilute</kanji> <kanji>feeling</kanji> from someone, they have no feelings. They become <vocabulary>cold hearted</vocabulary>.
Reading Mnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.
Context 1-EN: He is cold hearted and I have no idea whose side he’s taking.
Context 1-JP: <jp>彼は薄情者だし、どっちの味方かサッパリ分からないよ。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: This is a single kanji with an <jp>い</jp> on the end, meaning you know it's probably an adjective. What's the adjective form of <kanji>sharp</kanji>? It's <vocabulary>sharp</vocabulary>.
Reading Mnemonic: Something that is <vocabulary>sharp</vocabulary> will stab someone, but they will sue you for your rude behaviors. They <reading>sue rud</reading>e (<jp>するど</jp>) behaviors...
Context 1-EN: I ran into a bear in the forest and it scratched my face with its sharp claws.
Context 1-JP: <jp>私は森で熊に遭遇し、鋭い爪で顔を引っ掻かれました。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: A <kanji>rice paddy</kanji> <kanji>field</kanji>. You'd think this would refer only to a rice field, but it actually refers to other types of fields too, making this word simply <vocabulary>field</vocabulary>. I guess that shows how important rice is, because if a field isn't growing rice, it ain't no field o' mine.
Reading Mnemonic: The readings come from what you learned with the kanji. <jp>畑</jp> uses the shorter <jp>はた</jp> reading that you learned.
Context 1-EN: Nowadays ploughing fields without any machinery is a waste of time.
Context 1-JP: <jp>今時田畑を機械を使わずに耕すなんて、時間の無駄だよ。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: If you usually <kanji>lean</kanji> <kanji>yonder</kanji>, in that direction, that will be your <vocabulary>tendency</vocabulary>.
Reading Mnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.
Context 1-EN: Japanese people tend to speak Japanese with an English accent when they talk to foreigners.
Context 1-JP: <jp>日本人は外国人と喋る時、英語訛りの日本語を話す傾向があります。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: The result (<jp>甲斐</jp>) of being your own <kanji>gender</kanji> shows your <vocabulary>resourcefulness</vocabulary>. Depending on your gender, certain things are harder than others, so your resourcefulness and <vocabulary>competence</vocabulary> will help you to overcome those hurdles.
Reading Mnemonic: This word combines the word <jp>甲斐</jp> (that you already learned) with the on'yomi reading for <jp>性</jp>. You know them both, just put them together!
Context 1-EN: I really can’t understand how such an incompetent man like that was able to rekindle her love.
Context 1-JP: <jp>どうしてあの甲斐性無しが彼女の愛を復活させることができたのか、全く理解できないね。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: Remember how <jp>戸籍</jp> is the family register? This is referring to that, and that makes this word mean <vocabulary>entry in family register</vocabulary>.
Reading Mnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.
Context 1-EN: We are planning to be entered in the family register before the wedding ceremony.
Context 1-JP: <jp>結婚式の前に入籍をする予定です。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: Because the hiragana ends with an <jp>う</jp> sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means <kanji>transparent</kanji> and the verb vocab version is <vocabulary>to be transparent</vocabulary> (since usually people can't "to transparent" something).
Reading Mnemonic: To remember the reading, just think about something that is supposed to not be transparent, but is transparent after you give it to someone for a while. You're so upset that your (dog/cat/plant/car/etc) is transparent that you <reading>sue</reading> the guy who was supposed to not make it transparent.
Context 1-EN: If you put a silver scratch card over a bright lightbulb, sometimes you can see through the silver part at what’s written underneath.
Context 1-JP: <jp>光っている電球の上に銀色のスクラッチカードを当てると、その銀色の部分の下に何が書かれてるかが透けて見えちゃうことがあるんだよ。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: I <kanji>release</kanji> and <kanji>abandon</kanji> my post. This is my <vocabulary>resignation</vocabulary>. This is my <vocabulary>abandonment</vocabulary>.
Reading Mnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.
Context 1-EN: I was a typical neglected child who grew up in an orphanage.
Context 1-JP: <jp>私は典型的な育児放棄をされた子どもで、孤児院で育ちました。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: <jp>福祉</jp> is <kanji>welfare</kanji>, <jp>社会</jp> is <kanji>society</kanji>. So, a society's welfare is <vocabulary>social welfare</vocabulary>.
Reading Mnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.
Context 1-EN: I could stop by the social welfare facility after visiting my family’s graves tomorrow.
Context 1-JP: <jp>明日なら、家族の墓参りをした後に、その社会福祉施設に寄れなくもないよ。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: Try to <kanji>suppress</kanji> and <kanji>control</kanji> the enemy. We must <vocabulary>control</vocabulary> them.
Reading Mnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.
Context 1-EN: I can’t control my emotions well before my period because of PMS.
Context 1-JP: <jp>生理前は、月経前症候群のせいで、感情をうまく抑制することができません。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: If you're <kanji>overcome</kanji> with <kanji>bright</kanji>ness, you'll be able to see all the little fine <vocabulary>detailed</vocabulary> things.
Reading Mnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.
Context 1-EN: I have detailed memories of the Chinese New Year from ten years ago.
Context 1-JP: <jp>十年前の旧正月のことは、克明に覚えていますよ。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: <kanji>Four</kanji> <kanji>small animal</kanji>s is <vocabulary>four small animals</vocabulary>. Use this to count four dogs, or cats, or whatever else.
Reading Mnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.
Context 1-EN: My four Maltese dogs had a scrumptious supper because yesterday was their birthday.
Context 1-JP: <jp>うちの四匹のマルチーズは、昨日、誕生日だったので、とても美味しい晩ご飯を食べました。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: <jp>いつ</jp> is "when" and <jp>頃</jp> is "about." Combine those together and you have "<vocabulary>about when</vocabulary>?" or "<vocabulary>how soon</vocabulary>?"
Reading Mnemonic: The reading is the same as the one you learned with the kanji, just rendaku'd.
Context 1-EN: How soon will Tofugu enter into the e-book market?
Context 1-JP: <jp>Tofuguはいつ頃Eブックマーケットに参入するつもりですか？</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: A <kanji>dull</kanji> <kanji>feeling</kanji> in your head is <vocabulary>thickheadedness</vocabulary>.
Reading Mnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.
Context 1-EN: You are really insensitive. I don’t feel like talking about Fugu right now. Take a hint.
Context 1-JP: <jp>あんたって、ほんと鈍感。今はフグの話はしたくないの。それくらい空気を読んでよ。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: Because the hiragana ends with an <jp>う</jp> sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means <kanji>praise</kanji> and the verb vocab version is <vocabulary>to praise</vocabulary>.
Reading Mnemonic: If you are going <vocabulary>to praise</vocabulary> this guy in front of you, it would have to be for his amazing <reading>hoe</reading>-using (<jp>ほ</jp>) abilities. Look at him go with that hoe.
Context 1-EN: I’m bad at being complimented because I don’t know how to respond.
Context 1-JP: <jp>どう返答していいか分からないので、人に褒められるのは苦手です。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: To <kanji>conceal</kanji> yourself in <kanji>water</kanji>, you'd better start <vocabulary>diving</vocabulary> and get under the water where it can conceal you!
Reading Mnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.
Context 1-EN: My sister got her diver’s license this summer.
Context 1-JP: <jp>うちの妹は今年の夏に潜水士免許を取得したんだよ。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: If you see <jp>即</jp> before a word, you know that it's probably something that happens really fast or instantaneously. That's why this is <vocabulary>immediate</vocabulary> or <vocabulary>instant</vocabulary>.
Reading Mnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.
Context 1-EN: I found a super cute teddy bear and immediately bought it.
Context 1-JP: <jp>すごく可愛いテディーベアを見つけたので、即買いしちゃいました。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.
Reading Mnemonic: The reading is the same as the one you learned with the kanji.
Context 1-EN: My wife gets upset with me whenever I wear my socks inside out.
Context 1-JP: <jp>靴下を裏返しに履いちゃうと、嫁が怒ってうるさいんだわ。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: Because the hiragana ends with an <jp>う</jp> sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means <kanji>presents</kanji> so if you do presents, you're giving them, making this <vocabulary>to give a present</vocabulary>.
Reading Mnemonic: If you want to give someone a present, maybe you would think about <reading>send</reading>ing/<jp>送る</jp> (<jp>おくる</jp>) it to them?
Context 1-EN: The winner of fantasy baseball will be given something as a prize.
Context 1-JP: <jp>ファンタジーベースボールの優勝者には、何か賞品が贈られます。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: A <kanji>portable</kanji> <kanji>belt</kanji> is something so portable you can put it on your belt. It is <vocabulary>portable</vocabulary>. Note, this is also a very common term for a <vocabulary>cell phone</vocabulary> or <vocabulary>mobile phone</vocabulary>. You'll learn more about that in the coming levels.
Reading Mnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.
Context 1-EN: To turn on your cell phone you need to press the power button for five seconds.
Context 1-JP: <jp>携帯の電源を入れるには、電源ボタンを五秒間長押しする必要があります。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: A <kanji>medicine</kanji> <kanji>dose</kanji> is <vocabulary>medicine</vocabulary> or <vocabulary>drugs</vocabulary> you're taking.
Reading Mnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.
Context 1-EN: Make sure you put the medicine away in the medicine case after you use it.
Context 1-JP: <jp>薬剤を使い終わったら、必ず薬剤入れに戻してください。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: A <kanji>location</kanji> where <kanji>car</kanji>s can be a <kanji>resident</kanji> is a <vocabulary>parking lot</vocabulary>.
Reading Mnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You've learned these readings already, so you should be able to read this on your own!
Context 1-EN: I’m stuck in a traffic jam in a parking lot at the mall. I shouldn’t have come here on the Sunday before Christmas.
Context 1-JP: <jp>ショッピングモールの駐車場で渋滞に巻き込まれちゃってるよ。クリスマス前の日曜日なんかに、こんなところに来るんじゃなかったよ。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: You <kanji>set aside</kanji> these <kanji>word</kanji>s specifically so you could get the <vocabulary>wording</vocabulary> right. Wording is important sometimes, like when you're trying to talk about something sensitive, or when you're writing a poem. Sometimes only certain words will do.
Reading Mnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.
Context 1-EN: I was impressed that the wording of your poem was so beautiful.
Context 1-JP: <jp>君の詩の措辞が素晴らしいことに感動しました。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: A <jp>掲示</jp> is a notice or sign. Put this on a <kanji>board</kanji>, and it becomes a <vocabulary>bulletin board</vocabulary>.
Reading Mnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.
Context 1-EN: This bulletin board belongs to the school.
Context 1-JP: <jp>この掲示板は学校のものです。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: If you try <kanji>to consider</kanji> (<jp>遣う</jp>) your <kanji>words</kanji> (<jp>言葉</jp>) you are making a <vocabulary>choice of words</vocabulary>.
Reading Mnemonic: The reading is <jp>言葉</jp> and <jp>遣う</jp> combined together.
Context 1-EN: Imitating someone’s speech can be a good way to practice a foreign language.
Context 1-JP: <jp>誰かの言葉遣いを真似することは、外国語の良い勉強法です。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: Because the hiragana ends with an <jp>う</jp> sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means <kanji>spread</kanji> and the verb vocab version is <vocabulary>to spread out</vocabulary> or <vocabulary>to lay out</vocabulary>.
Reading Mnemonic: What is getting <vocabulary>spread out</vocabulary>? <reading>Shee</reading>p (<jp>し</jp>)! Someone's been hunting sheep, because you're looking at a bunch of empty (dead) sheep bodies spread out on the ground.
Context 1-EN: I persuaded him to put a carpet in his room.
Context 1-JP: <jp>彼に、部屋にカーペットを敷くよう説得しました。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: Because the hiragana ends with an <jp>う</jp> sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means <kanji>abstain</kanji> and the verb vocab version is <vocabulary>to abstain</vocabulary> as well!
Reading Mnemonic: Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. You learned this reading already, good for you!
Context 1-EN: It’s not like you to abstain from alcohol. Unless maybe, are you pregnant?
Context 1-JP: <jp>お酒を控えるなんてらしくないね。もしかして、妊娠したとか？</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: I'm going to <kanji>twist</kanji> this <kanji>bullet</kanji> and turn it around on you. You're the one I'm going to <vocabulary>blame</vocabulary>, which is why my blame bullet is twisted back at you.
Reading Mnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.
Context 1-EN: Who do you think is to blame for this economic crisis?
Context 1-JP: <jp>この金融危機について、誰が糾弾されるべきだと思われますか？</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: With a <kanji>seal</kanji> we're <kanji>printing</kanji> everything out. The seal is what prints the words on the paper, making this <vocabulary>printing</vocabulary>.
Reading Mnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.
Context 1-EN: We should print our advertisements on nice paper with cooking recipes so that people will keep them on their fridge.
Context 1-JP: <jp>我々の広告を上質の紙に料理のレシピと一緒に印刷すれば、みんなそれを冷蔵庫に貼っておいてくれるんじゃないかな。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: Your <kanji>excuse</kanji> for the current <kanji>condition</kanji> is surprising, especially considering your <vocabulary>diploma</vocabulary> and <vocabulary>license</vocabulary> on the issue.
Reading Mnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.
Context 1-EN: I’ll give you the diploma the next time we meet.
Context 1-JP: <jp>今度お会いする際に免状をお渡ししますね。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: This is a single kanji with an <jp>い</jp> on the end, meaning you know it's probably an adjective. The adjective form of <kanji>bitter</kanji> is <vocabulary>bitter</vocabulary>, or more specifically, a <vocabulary>bitter flavor</vocabulary>.
Reading Mnemonic: Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. You didn't learn that reading with this kanji, so here's a mnemonic to help you: She gives you some food, and it's terribly <vocabulary>bitter</vocabulary>. You look at the lady who gave you this bitter food. You say, "<reading>She boooo</reading>" as in, she's no good, and she serves bitter food.
Context 1-EN: Koichi frowned at the DDOS attack and banged his fist on the table.
Context 1-JP: <jp>コウイチはDDOS攻撃に渋い顔をして、拳で机をバンバンと叩いた。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: A <kanji>one sided</kanji> <kanji>hand</kanji> is one of your hands, that means you're doing something <vocabulary>one handed</vocabulary>.
Reading Mnemonic: These readings are the ones you learned with both of these kanji.
Context 1-EN: He easily lifted up the heavy bag of rice with one hand.
Context 1-JP: <jp>彼は重いお米の袋を片手でヒョイと持ち上げました。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: A <kanji>rope</kanji> that you <kanji>hop</kanji> over is a <vocabulary>jump rope</vocabulary>.
Reading Mnemonic: The reading is the vocab words <jp>縄</jp> and <jp>跳ぶ</jp>, put together.
Context 1-EN: I’m skipping rope and listening to FM802.
Context 1-JP: <jp>FM802を聞きながら縄跳びをしています。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: Remember how <jp>揚げる</jp> can sometimes mean "to fry"? This is the noun version of that meaning of that word, making it <vocabulary>fried</vocabulary>... delicious <vocabulary>fried</vocabulary>...
Reading Mnemonic: The reading comes from <jp>揚げる</jp> as well.
Context 1-EN: Every food she touches turns into beautiful, delicious fried food.
Context 1-JP: <jp>どんな食べ物でも、彼女の手にかかれば、美しく美味しい金色の揚げ物になるんです。</jp>

Meaning: To Concede,To Hand Over,To Turn Over
Meaning Mnemonic: If you are going to <kanji>defer</kanji> to someone, you are going <vocabulary>to concede</vocabulary> something. I concede / defer this to you.
Reading Mnemonic: What are you conceding? Some delicious <reading>yuzu</reading> (<jp>ゆず</jp>). You are sad, because they're so much better than lemons and now you don't have them.
Context 1-EN: He gave me an old novel that is out of print.
Context 1-JP: <jp>彼は、絶版になっている古い小説を私に譲ってくれました。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: <kanji>Allocate</kanji> the <kanji>truth</kanji> more and more to make things better. The truth is, we need to allocate even more, until we've reached <vocabulary>fullness</vocabulary>.
Reading Mnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.
Context 1-EN: We provide good after-sales service because we want to build long-term relationships with our customers.
Context 1-JP: <jp>お客様と末永い関係が築けるよう、充実したアフターサービスをご提供しております。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: The <kanji>rapids</kanji> <kanji>door</kanji> is actually <vocabulary>Seto</vocabulary>, which is the name of a few different places in Japan. One of those places is where the famous earthenware Seto ware comes from 🍶
Reading Mnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.
Context 1-EN: Fish from the Seto Inland Sea is delicious.
Context 1-JP: <jp>瀬戸内海の魚は美味しい。</jp>
Context 2-EN: I saw Jin Akanishi in Seto City.
Context 3-EN: I found really nice Seto ware at the market today.
Context 3-JP: <jp>今日市場ですごくいい瀬戸物を見つけたんだよ。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: A <kanji>bog</kanji> <kanji>earth</kanji> place is a place where the earth is boggy. That's a <vocabulary>marshland</vocabulary> or <vocabulary>wetland</vocabulary>.
Reading Mnemonic: The readings are the ones you learned with the respective kanji.
Context 1-EN: Maybe they were telling the truth that there is a dragon in these swamplands.
Context 1-JP: <jp>もしかしたら、彼らがこの沼地にはドラゴンがいると言ってたのは、本当のことだったのかも。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: Because the hiragana ends with an <jp>う</jp> sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means <kanji>recommend</kanji> so the verb vocab version is <vocabulary>to recommend</vocabulary>.
Reading Mnemonic: This has the same reading as <jp>薦める</jp>, which means essentially the same thing. I recommend you learn them both.
Context 1-EN: Some hermit suggested that I go to Sendai.
Context 1-JP: <jp>とある仙人から、仙台に行くことを勧められたんだよ。</jp>
Context 2-EN: I always recommend starting WaniKani to my friends.
Context 2-JP: <jp>友達にワニカニを始めるようにいつも勧めています。</jp>
Context 3-EN: The cake shop in Sengawa, which Ms. Senda recommended the other day, was really delicious!
Context 3-JP: <jp>こないだ仙田さんが勧めてくれた仙川のケーキ屋さん、とってもおいしかったよ！</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: Because the hiragana ends with an <jp>う</jp> sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means <kanji>bury</kanji> so the verb vocab version is <vocabulary>to bury</vocabulary> as well.
Reading Mnemonic: You learned this reading with the kanji, how nice for you!
Context 1-EN: I’m sure someone’s already told you, but we buried the butcher in your yard. I hope you don’t mind.
Context 1-JP: <jp>きっと誰かがもう話をしてると思うんだけど、私達、あの肉屋をあんたの庭に埋めたのさ。良かったかな。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: Those who <kanji>patrol</kanji> and <kanji>inspect</kanji> on their patrols are the <vocabulary>police</vocabulary> or <vocabulary>policeman</vocabulary>.
Reading Mnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.
Context 1-EN: The policeman drank half the scotch in one gulp.
Context 1-JP: <jp>その巡査は、スコッチを一気にゴクリと半分飲み干した。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: The <kanji>luck</kanji> <kanji>sack</kanji> is a <vocabulary>mystery bag</vocabulary>. These are bags that are sold during the New Year's holiday. They contain various goods that are sold for a certain price. You don't know what's in them, but you know the minimum value of it at least. These are known as <vocabulary>mystery sack</vocabulary>s as well.
Reading Mnemonic: The reading is <jp>福</jp> and <jp>袋</jp>, put together. Also, watch out for the rendaku.

Now the occurrences of you saying <reading>fufufu</reading> is really multiplying. You might also notice that this is similar to the word <jp>増える</jp>, which means "to increase." Reading Mnemonic:
This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You haven't learned this reading for <jp>底</jp> yet, so here's a mnemonic to help you:

<vocabulary>Thoroughness</vocabulary> is important when you're making <reading>ta</reading>ter (<jp>てい</jp>) tots. Each tater has to be cut carefully into little pieces then smashed back together again. Don't even get me started on the <vocabulary>completeness</vocabulary> I feel when I finish and eat them. Mm.
